comment: "The Antiquities Act expressly authorizes the President to create a national monument, but it does not authorize a later President to revoke or modify a national monument," says Prof. Carl Tobias of the University of Richmond School of Law."Moreover, I believe that the natural resources must be used for the benefit of all our people, and not monopolized for the benefit of the few..." Theodore Roosevelt.I urge you to continue protection of our monuments.

A lot of these places are sacred to the indigenous peoples of the country. The entire reason they were protected to begin with was because of public outcry. How dare you think the public will stand by while these places lose their protection?

Access to nature is a basic human right that has been protected in this country for centuries. Rapidly, suburbanization, large-scale agriculture, and other human uses are spreading across America. While progress is good and expansion of human-centric areas is likely inevitable, there are ways for this to happen without sacrificing nature. The National Monuments established since 1996 have been identified by experts as exceptional natural areas that are priorities to protect. We aren't protecting much - only about 14% are protected in some way. We can't afford to shrink that even more, when there is plenty of non-protected land to go around. I strongly urge you to continue protecting the national monuments currently being reviewed.
Actually, Bears Ears should have been bigger. The least we should do is leave it alone.

All National Monuments must remain protected in perpetuity! One misguided administration SHOULD NOT have the power to undo previous presidential orders protecting these national treasures for generations to come."A society grows great when old men plant trees whose shade they know they shall never sit in." --Greek proverbWe are not the rulers of the earth, merely her protectors for all the generations to come. For the love of God and Mother Earth keep these precious, sacred lands free! Respect our Native American's sacred lands, they were here before all of us "immigrants" came along and stole it from them.Thank you.

All national monuments should be left as they are. I have had the good fortune to have grown up with property near Grand Stair Case Escalante National Monument and have enjoyed countless hours enjoying the many treasures it has to offer. I know many locals, including business owners, who have all reaped benefits financial and otherwise from this monument. All of the land in the monument is worth protection and any reduction in size would be shameful. These monuments belong to the American people and can serve them in no better way than they currently are.

All of our nation's National Monuments need to be protected and left as they are. Reviewing, rescinding, and reducing the size of our national monuments is a massive step backward. These wilderness areas are sacred to Native Americans, contain archeological sites, ancient native burial grounds, petroglyphs (ancient rock art) and breathtaking natural beauty. They are important for outdoor enthusiasts as well as provide income for local economies. These wild lands are also extremely fragile, and will not survive attempts by short-sighted greedy corporations to extract resources from them (minerals, oil, gas, coal, logging etc) or diminish their protected status in any way. They need to remain protected. Do the right thing. Leave them as they are.

All of our national monuments are important to Americans and should be honored, protected and retained as a legacy for future generations. These lands were designated as monuments, recognized for their importance to local communities as part of the greatness of this country where we honor our history, our wilderness, the beauty that surrounds us. I cannot imagine anyone supporting commercial development or harvesting the sequoia forest, for example, or any of our monuments - it would be desecration, a dishonorable act, a crime against humanity. There are plenty of other opportunities for development, there is no need to sacrifice national monuments that add economic and spiritual value to countless towns, cities and states across the nation.

All of the monuments should be preserved and their status protected, not sold off to the highest bidder. This is public land for us and our children to enjoy in the future. Please do not take away their federal status.

All of the National Monuments are national treasures, and I strongly oppose any changes proposed to their current status. They should remain protected for all US peoples. Those who would seek to exploit them for monetary gain should be told to go ruin their own land. As a person who loves (and uses) wild places, I believe it is short-sighted, and immoral, to endanger these irreplaceable treasures to provide opportunities for short-term gain for a few. They are our legacy as US citizens.The Bears Ears Monument is of particular significance; being designated after a period of research through the efforts of a broad coalition of stake-holders, including the original owners; the Native tribes. Comments were already sought and provided on this area, so it's not clear why this needs to be done again. I strongly oppose any reduction or other uses of the land in this monument. I travel to Utah, stay there, bring my family and spend money in Utah communities, specifically to enjoy the wonders and get out into them. I plan to visit Bears Ears in the next few years.As a citizen of Idaho, I would like to also put in a word for Craters of the Moon. This is an amazing place, much of it truly wild due to its difficulty of access. It's unique and should be preserved.But again, I oppose reduction in any of our monuments. Each was designated for it's own reasons. This is important to me, and I do vote based on issues around environmental protections versus short-sighted exploitation.

ALL of the National Monuments belong to the people of this country and are treasured resources that should be preserved. I understand that industry would like to exploit our lands, but I don't understand why we should let them. These monuments are for the public, not for corporate enrichment. Please protect and preserve them.

All of the sites listed are not only a source of national pride, but they promote biodiversity, have significant history, and include historical and cultural landmarks. They need to be protected for future generations.
All proper notice was given and all lands designated should remain.

Aloha, I live in Hawaii & Utah, and spend lots of time in the wilderness in both locations. Unspoiled outdoors locations, such as found at Bears Ears or the Marine Reserve are key for the future of our nation. We need wilderness to keep us sane, and to maintain species diversity and health. Destruction of the outdoors heritage is destroying this irreplaceable resource for future generations. Our grandchildren and great-grandchildren need these refuges and the biodiversity. Monument designations maintain these resources for all of us and our future, rather than sacrificing them to the short-term needs and desires of a wealthy, greedy few. SAVE OUR MONUMENTS FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS, AND DO NOT OPEN THEM TO DEVELOPMENT.If the outdoors can only be viewed through an economic lens, then consider the financial value of this resource for future tourists, and for Americans who want to remember what once existed in the country. Biodiversity is key for the development of new drugs, since the chemical constituents of many plants remain unexamined, and their potential for medicine untapped.I feel passionately about this issue, and the Department of the Interior should be focusing on maintaining our wilderness, not removing these monument designations. If you destroy these places, your names will be infamous, and future generations will remember you with disgust. Plus, the short comment period on this federal action is offensive.Dr. Susan J. Wurtzburg (Kailua, Hawaii; and Salt Lake City, Utah)

Although I live in the East, I have travelled often to many of these magnificent monuments, and I urge you to maintain this important protection. The wildness cannot be brought back once protection is lost. The land belongs to all of us and should not be allowed to be lost to industry and logging, both for the benefit of the public and for the wildlife.

am writing in response to the Department of the Interior's request for comments on recently formed national monuments. I support the designation of these public lands as national monuments, and encourage the Department to maintain their existing boundaries and improve access for bicycles.Public lands such as national monuments play an instrumental role in supporting outdoor recreation. While these activities, including bike riding, are of personal significance to me as a bike rider, they are also critical to local economies in the communities that surround these monuments. Bike riding alone supports $88 billion in economic activity and provides $12 billion in federal, state and local taxes each year. Without quality places to ride on our public lands, these contributions are at serious risk.Some of the monuments that are subject to the Department's review provide bike riding opportunities. Of particular importance are Ironwood Forest (AZ), Sonoran Desert (AZ), Berryessa Snow Mountain (CA), San Gabriel Mountains (CA), Canyons of the Ancients (CO), Basin and Range (NV), Bears Ears (UT) and Grand Staircase-Escalante (UT). New opportunities for riding are also being considered in Sand to Snow (CA), Katahdin Woods (ME), Gold Butte (NV), Rio Grande del Norte (NV) and Cascade Siskiyou (OR). Many of these areas provide unique opportunities to explore cultural and natural resources that cannot be replicated. I encourage the Department to recommend that these lands be maintained as national monuments, and ensure that existing and planned bike riding opportunities in these locations be created and improved.Thank you for considering my comments.

America, the Beautiful doesn't praise oil drills, strip mines, and air pollution.... so:I SUPPORT THE DESIGNATION OF BEARS EARS AS A NATIONAL MONUMENT!Over 30 local Indian tribes, including the Hopi, Ute, and Navajo people, have ancestral, historical, and contemporary ties to the Bears Ears region. Some even consider it sacred. They support the monument status, and I think that should be respected.More pointedly, I believe that removing the monument status would amount to an oligarchal giveaway to big fossil fuel companies.I ALSO SUPPORT KEEPING THE MONUMENT DESIGNATION FOR THE OTHER MONUMENTS UP FOR REVIEW, INCLUDING THE SAN GABRIEL MOUNTAINS IN MY HOME OF LOS ANGELES COUNTY!As Ken Burns said, National Parks are America's best idea. Let's keep them, please.Respectfully,Colin Rich

America's monuments are IMPORTANT not only for their wild beauty and recreational possibilities, but because they are places that preserve our history. I grew up within a mile of the Pipestone National Monument (thankfully, it is not on this ridiculous list) and the numbers of visitors to this place each summer helped to support the economy of our small town, and took with them a.sense of how important is is to honor and keep alive the culture of our Native Americans.Each monument has a story to tell, comfort to give, and wild places to preserve. These places belong to the American People land should not be exploited by corporate greed. PRESERVE THEM!Pauline CallahanJordan MN

America's national monuments and national parks are among its proudest achievements. Many of our most treasured national parks began as national monuments. They are all a boon to citizens of every stripe and should only be added to, not reduced, in number. Our park systems are the envy of people worldwide, as well as a vital part of many Americans' most cherished memories and family experiences. The potential retraction of national monument status is a slap in the face to American exceptionalism and should be prohibited for any reason. This entire review process is a wrong-headed waste of resources and no doubt just a cover to give over yet more of the country to the uses of powerful corporate interests at the expense of its citizens. The administration and Secretary Zinke should be ashamed.

Any remaining wild land currently protected for current and future generations should stay undeveloped and protected. The reason is simple, once developed it will never go back again. You have to question if what you are doing is good for the land. You cannot go wrong with conservation, there is no ill harm or damage. I'm from Pennsylvania and have seen first hand the irreparable damage that has been done to the natural resources and landscape by the Fracking Industry. My concerns with lifting the protection on the land, much like in Pennsylvania, it opens it up to the possibility of being damaged forever.

As a 5th generation Utahn, I firmly oppose any changes to our National Monuments established since 1996. These beautiful, multi-use lands are important to me and my family because they represent what is one of the best parts of America: our federal lands and how we protect them and allow everyone to use them. It is what makes America and in particular, Western America, truly special. The attack on Utah's public lands by our elected officials do not represent what the majority of Utahns want. They had their chance to establish some sort of rules for Bear's Ears but failed. Their attack has resulted in our state losing millions of dollars from outdoor shows leaving the state. Please do not change our National Monuments.

As a California native, I am outraged that Giant Sequoia National Monument is under review. The sequoias are the largest trees on earth and are hundreds -- in some cases thousands -- of years old. They deserve to be protected for future generations.

As a citizen who enjoys spending time outside in our country's great national monuments and parks, I believe it would be a great mistake to alter the status of any of these lands. The benefits of having vast amounts of well preserved lands for all to enjoy far outweighs any potential drawbacks. And while there may be some negative economic impacts created by being unable to profit from this land directly, they are largely offset by the various industries that are built around easy and open access to the land.I believe it would be best to continue to preserve these lands so that our children and their children will be able to enjoy our natural resources the same way we have for generations.

As a co-owner of our National Monuments, I must protest in the strongest way the current, unprecedented review of Monuments under the President's Executive Order 13792, a review transparently launched with an eye to eliminating or shrinking the properties under examination.As population and development pressures grow, we should be protecting more tracts of unique natural beauty, biodiversity value, or cultural history before they're despoiled. The immense historical, biological, scenic, and recreational value of our monuments cannot be re-created elsewhere but must be protected in situ. There's no "Disneyland" fix for this at a later date. As we learn about more about the requirements of intact ecosystems, it is clear that size is crucial. Without sufficient acreage, whether on land or in the ocean, biological diversity becomes too restricted to thrive. Without protection of entire watersheds, everything downstream is imperiled. A few years of carelessness and an area can be spoiled for generations.Our shared heritage must not be squandered to line the pockets of a few individuals, particularly not for the sake of exploitative activities that irrevocably damage that heritage. Raiding the property of ALL U.S. citizens for the economic benefit of a few would befit a self-dealing oligarchy, policy not worthy of our country.Extractive industry is self-limiting, as well as permanently destructive. Once resources have been removed, the place where they originated is left scarred, often in multiple and persistent ways.If we were in a fight for our very survival, we might entertain the idea of "raiding" our monuments for resources, but we're far from that situation. Coal is losing importance in power generation, timber harvest from public lands (not just National Monuments) amounts to much less than 5% of the total, and an even smaller percentage of our meat production results from grazing on public lands. So why must we trash the most precious places when there is no compelling need? Simply so someone can make a quick buck? What a short-sighted plan.Protected lands can yield sustained economic returns through carefully managed recreational activities, monetary benefits that leave intact our common, irreplaceable heritage. However, if we judge these places only by the money we can make from them, we're missing what's most important of all.
As a concerned citizen, I request the continuation of the protected status of the national monuments cited herein.

As a disabled American Veteran I fully support for the Antiquities Act of 1906 - the act responsible for so many of our wonderful parks and monuments, created by President Teddy Roosevelt - that allows so many veterans and their families to recreate.

As a local resident of Utah I am against this national designation. It is unnecessary, not wanted, and not needed. No additional federal lands need to be claimed in our state, if this area needs protections or special designations, we can and will handle it at a state level.
As a long time traveler around the US, mostly in the Northeast. I would still love to travel to places like Bear Ears. Please keep this place the way it is. Protected!

As a member of the American Motorcyclist Association and an off-highway vehicle recreation enthusiast, I applaud the U.S. Department of the Interior for the opportunity to comment on its review of certain National Monuments designated or expanded since 1996 under the American Antiquities Act of 1906, to implement Executive Order 13792 of April 26.I, along with the AMA, support the review as a way to determine whether some monument designations included more land than necessary as defined by the Act. I also believe presidents should solicit input from the public before making such designations, even though the law does not require it.I oppose sweeping monument designations by administrations that fail to consider input from all stakeholders. Such designations can restrict or eliminate opportunities for responsible off-highway motorized recreation on public lands and negatively affect the economies of the communities surrounding the monuments.The Antiquities Act grants the president authority to designate national monuments to protect "historic landmarks, historic and prehistoric structures and other objects of historic or scientific interest" that are on federal lands. The law limits the size of the designations to "the smallest area compatible with proper care and management of the objects to be protected."Previous administrations have used the broadly defined stipulations of the Antiquities Act to create monument designations. Unfortunately, these broad designations have closed larger-than-necessary territories that were previously used for wholesome recreation, such as responsible motorized recreation that supports small business and local economies.The designation of National Monuments on public lands may reduce or end access for responsible motorized recreation. Designations can be made that will benefit all groups, as long as these groups are given the opportunity to contribute their perspectives.Excerpts from an AMA guest blog written by Clif Koontz address the Grand Staircase-Escalante, Canyons of the Ancients and Bears Ears National Monuments. Koontz is the executive director of Ride with Respect, a nonprofit organization based in Moab, Utah, that conserves shared-use recreation through trail work and education.Koontz states, "The Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument closed half of the existing routes open to motorized recreation. The federal land managers even prohibited off-highway motorcyclists from riding the graded, gravel roads." He added, "Fortunately, the affected county asserted its jurisdiction over those roads, but not before having to fight the federal land managers in court."At the Canyons of the Ancients National Monument, Koontz says, federal land managers first closed the single-track trails, then prohibited motorcycles from "motorcycle trails" that actually were roads for four-wheeled vehicles. Those roads are a far cry from the actual single-track trails they had closed to responsible recreation."For the new Bears Ears National Monument, Koontz states, it "encircles many 4WD roads, ATV trails and motorcycle trails where Ride with Respect has worked. ... If history is any guide, these routes will eventually be closed due to the national monument status, despite the fact that we've made them sustainable, not to mention that they avoid archaeological sites."However, the AMA believes some previous monument designations go beyond the "requirements and original objectives of the Act."Moreover, these designations did not consider the multiple-use policy of section 102(a)(7) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act (43 U.S.C. 1701(1)(7)).The AMA and I support the protection of our national treasures by using a process that involves state officials, local stakeholders, governors and Congress.Again, I applaud the Interior Department for seeking public comments on its review of certain National Monuments.

As a researcher on wildlife conservation (I authored the recent book Wildlife Politics published by Cambridge University Press), I studied previous monuments and the overwhelming evidence is that through time, monuments achieve overwhelming support from all groups including those who live near the monuments. They spur more jobs and economic resources for nearby communities. Please do keep the Bears Ears Monument with no changes.Bruce RocheleauProfessor EmeritusNorthern Illinois University

As a resident of Maine, I was horrified to see that the Department of the Interior is reviewing some of the incredible national monuments that have been designated in the past twenty years. The Department is playing politics with some of our nation's greatest treasures. This is completely unprecedented and violates the entire point of having a Department of Interior.As the wild places in this country shrink and the threat of climate change grows, we need these monuments more than ever. Growing up in Boston in the home of my immigrant parents, I didn't have many opportunities to experience nature, let alone the spectacular places our beautiful country has to offer. In my adult life, I discovered that I loved camping and hiking. I plan my vacations around getting to see the national parks. I have been to Sequoia, Joshua Tree, and Olympic. I even moved to downeast Maine because I fell in love with Acadia. I was delighted when Maine got the honor of having the Katahdin woods and waters national monument. We need these places so all Americans can enjoy the unique natural beauty of our country.The Katahdin woods is a truly spectacular place and the designation as a national monument preserves its beauty for generations to come. Maine's economy desperately needs the jobs that would come with the tourism in that remote region. The Department of the Interior has a sacred responsibility to protect our country's most precious sites. The Katahdin woods - and all the other magnificent places under review- deserve the most protection our government can give, and that is the status of national monument. State and local parks and protected areas, Bureau of Land Management, and Forest Service designations provide insufficient protection to these places. Do not revoke the national monument status from these beautiful places. Our children and grandchildren need them.

As a resident of Southwest Colorado, I am writing regarding the two monuments I am familiar with: Canyons of the Ancients and Bears Ears. 1st let me address Canyons of the Ancients, which has been a Monument since 2000, and now 17 years later is very popular in the region. Of the hundreds of people I know that live in my region, I'm aware of none than want the monument rescinded. Selfishly, I would like it to remain a monument because I regularly use it for outdoor recreation. Unselfishly, the monument is popular locally due to the economic benefit it brings to the region through tourism (http://www.denverpost.com/2017/04/26/canyons-of-the-ancients-colorado-trump-monument-review/). If the area was pockmarked with oil/gas development as is neighboring northwest New Mexico, it would no longer be a tourist attraction.Despite the decline of natural gas production in our region (associated with lower natural gas prices), the economy of SW Colorado has remained strong, and the reason is tourism has made our economy more resilient. Conversely, the communities of NW New Mexico have been devastated by the recent declines in oil/gas production. Why? Because they do not have tourism as part of their overall economic portfolio. The reason there is no significant tourism in NW New Mexico is not because it is not scenic...it is b/c all the scenic locations on federal lands have been developed for oil and gas. There are hundreds of natural arches, steep canyons, Navajo Pueblito ruins, and ancient petroglyphs throughout NW New Mexico; however, all are in areas developed for oil and gas. Tourists simply do not want to see a ruin or natural arch from a well pad. Without Monument designation, oil/gas drilling is actively encouraged on federal lands. If Monument status is revoked, the Canyons of the Ancients will become like NW New Mexico, and our local economy will suffer.This brings me to Bears Ears. There has been much misinformation regarding Bears Ears. 1st is that it consists of a "federal land grab", which is not the case since all land is already federally owned and all existing uses such as grazing and active oil/gas development can continue. 2nd is that it was designated "last minute", when in reality the tribes that are now part of the Bears Ears Coalition has been working for site protection since 2013, only when the Utah delegation quit working with the tribes did they seek Monument status. 3rd is the idea that the Monument has no local support. There are 30 designated tribes that are the original inhabitants of this landscape that support the monument designation. Also, the Monument is very popular to residents of the area that live across the Utah State line in Colorado. Additionally, I would like to point out that one reason the monument is opposed by locals in Blanding is there are a number of people there that have been continuously looting and illegally profiting from these lands for generations (http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106091937). These people know that the Monument status makes looting more difficult, challenging their illegitimate income sources. The looting indicates the cultural sites withing Bears Ears are under a real threat. Also, the Grand Canyon did not have local support initially either. If Teddy Roosevelt had not designated it is a National Monument, it would not be a publicly accessible place. The reality is over time, all these protected places eventually gain local support, and there is no reason to believe Bears Ears will be different.

As a taxpaying, voting American citizen I urge you to protect our National Monuments. Our growing thirst for natural resources (including land) must be mitigated by other needs, including open spaces like our National Monuments, that give us a place to step away from the hectic pace of modern life. Additionally, these National Monuments are symbolic of our national identity; America is a land of open spaces and marvelously diverse ecospheres. We need to preserve and maintain these spaces if we are to preserve our identity. Please, please protect these spaces.

As a Utah native, I feel strongly that all National Monuments and Parks be protected far into the future. The current administration has no clue what they are talking about which to me, is incredibly offensive.There is not a reason in the world to keep revisiting this issue. It costs the country thousands of dollars and to what end?Please move forward instead of trying to undo progress just because you are a Republican. Be an American!

As a volunteer who worked five summers in the Sequoia National and State Parks, I have seen people from all over the world come to visit these awe-inspiring, irreplaceable treasures. It is inconceivable that man would destroy what is left of these marvels.

As an active outdoor user, I participate in hiking, climbing, camping and fishing in our national monuments. I have used both Grand Staircase and Bears Ears extensively. In the course of using these monuments I support local businesss near them providing a lasting economic benefit.I am from central Pennsylvania an area that experienced the shale gas boom and bust. For example the hotels in that area that were once full of gas workers now sit empty and are facing going out of business. While oil and gas may provide a temporary economic boost the bust comes just as quickly. Tourism generated by the National Monument and Park status provides a lasting economic benefit. You need to look no further than Moab, UT to see that benefit.Please keep Grand Staircase and Bears Ears as National Monument and provide a lasting economic benefit to the surrounding communities.

As an American citizen with an abiding love of our wild and beautiful places, I am deeply concerned about this review process. Growing up in California, I enjoyed many trips to the Grand Canyon, Sonoran Desert, Vermillion Cliffs, San Gabriel Mountains, Giant Sequoia, and Carrizo Plain. These Monuments are valuable resources for all Americans, both for their local communities, where they enable vibrant tourism and other responsible land uses, and for the country as a whole. These natural wonders deserve to be preserved, in trust to all Americans, current and future, to preserve the beauty of our country for all to enjoy for generations to come.A review of these well-functioning and beloved Monuments is simply a waste of resources, as their establishment and maintenance already requires a great deal of review and policy to ensure appropriate land use and stewardship. It suggests, as many other recent policy proposals do, that the current administration values the profits of the few over the souls of the many.And don't be mistaken, this is a question of the American soul. It is hard to get more American than these varied landscapes; whose towering trees and broad horizons have inspired generations. A challenge to the validity of these honored preserves is an insult to all of us. For shame.

As an American, I am very concerned that our public lands remain public lands. Please protect Bears Ears National Monument. Our Native American history is very important to me, and the protection of lands that are significant to Native Americans is critical. Wilderness is so important to me, I visit wilderness areas several times every year, and had been planning to visit Bears Ears this summer. Outdoor places for Americans to recreate is so important to the American soul. In addition, it provides improved economies due to dollars that visitors spend for local services.Please provide continued protection to Bears Ears N.M. to preserve the numerous archaeological sites within. Please respect our Country's First Inhabitants, their traditional knowledge, and the significance of this site, and protect it for future generations.Grand Staircase-Escalante is another place I am planning to visit this summer, once again providing dollars to the local economy. Why would anyone want to dismantle a monument where so many dinosaur fossils have been discovered? This National Monument has been in place for two decades, having gained so many avid visitors who do not want to see it dismantled. Please continue to protect Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument!!Thank you.

As an archaeologist and avid visitor to our nation's National Parks and Monuments, I urge you to keep the protections on Bears Ears National Monument. The Antiquities Act is very important to our public lands, to protect them from private development and keep some of our country's natural beauty. Preserving Native American cultural resources should be a priority. There are many archaeological sites inside the current Bears Ears designation that meet the criteria for protection under the Antiquities Act, and therefore should be protected. The area is beautiful and presents an wonderful opportunity for hiking and learning. Please protect Bears Ears and keep the current boundaries.

As an environmental professional, a registered volunteer with USFS Sandia Ranger District and a volunteer with two 501c3 organizations whose purpose is maintenance and improvement of our public lands in New Mexico, I believe the proposal to review the status of "certain" national monuments is nothing more than a ploy to exploit the tangible resources of these lands. The idea that these monuments were created and expanded without sufficient public comment is untruthful and inaccurate. The real issue at hand is that big business and industry did not like the outcome of the public comment period and therefore seek an opportunity for a "do over". The current administration seeks to enrich special interests and themselves at the expense of our nation and our non-tangible resources by discounting the future and the environmental wealth of our nation for quick profit today. Reviewing the status of these monuments and reopening the opportunity for public comment is nothing more than a shameless attempt by the current administration to tip the scales in favor of their big business partners. Any comment I or people like me make will be summarily ignored because we have nothing more than our vote and opinion to offer; paltry and woefully insufficient when pitted against the billions of dollars of influence wielded by this administration's individual cabinet members in addition to the billions wielded by the special interests proponents of this action.Do not undertake this action unless the government is also prepared to double or triple its financial commitment in order to protect these monuments while permitting the oil, gas and mineral exploitation it is proposing but not openly discussing with the public.

As an outdoor enthusiast who loves our public lands, I support the designation of Bears Ears National Monument and ask that its boundaries remain unchanged.For more than 100 years, Presidents of both parties have used the Antiquities Act-a tool signed into law by Theodore Roosevelt-to enact far-sighted protections for our common American inheritance. Bears Ears is exactly the kind of place the Antiquities Act intended to protect. It is rich in cultural history which inspired a historic coalition of tribes to band together to push for its designation. In addition to protecting over 100,000 archaeological sites, the designation preserves world-class recreation opportunities in places like Cedar Mesa, Grand Gulch, and Indian Creek.The process that led to the designation of Bears Ears National Monument was thorough and transparent. For more than 80 years, decision makers from all sides presented proposals seeking permanent protection of all or part of this incredible landscape. The boundaries were informed by both the multi-year Public Lands Initiative and by a proposal from the Bears Ears Inter-Tribal Coalition. Those boundaries do not exceed the acreage necessary to preserve the rich cultural heritage, ecological values, and recreation assets.Thank you for reviewing the decades of hard work and thoughtful consideration that culminated in the designation of Bears Ears National Monument. Please recommend that President Trump leave the current Bears Ears National Monument boundaries in place.

As many of the local business owners have attested, the national monument designation of Escalante Grand Staircase has benefited the local economy. This region was declared a national monument over 20 years ago, and the majority of Utahns support its continued national monument protection.

Aside from California's booming tech industry, the state is known for it's vast tracts of untainted, undeveloped nature. This kind of beautiful natural resource is only going to increase in scarcity globally, and we, as a leading world nation, should do our best to preserve what beauty still remains. Do not open any protected national monuments up for development, mining, farming, or any other such activity. Thank you.

At this time the Carrizo Plains are not actually threatened in any way. But what IS an immediate concern, far more than this, is the completely ridiculous gas bill that Governor Brown wan't to slap on the backs of all Californians. Who is supposed to pay for this new tax? The average middle-class citizen who cannot afford yet more taxes. Bad enough we have to pay for a bullet train that starts no where and ends no where.Where is your concern for your constituents regarding yet another tax that will cause most of us real and serious financial burden.There is no need for yet another tax -- what does need to be done is to spend money WISELY. Budgeting comes to mind.The only people who are really concerned about this Carrizo Plain review (and at this time that's all it is, a review)are people who have a plentiful income. They have the spare time and money to worry about things of this nature. But not so the average worker. We live from paycheck to paycheck.And I also hear that the Governor is trying to pass a health bill for California -- again, who will pay for this? Again -- us middle class citizens. And have you noticed that Obamacare is imploding? It has cost the average middle-class citizen a bitter amount of money. As PM Thatcher said, "Socialism works great until you run out of other people's money."I hope that you will direct your energy, time AND votes to what the average tax payer is really concerned about.Thank you

Attention: Ryan Zinke,Please do NOT let these treasured and vital public lands be decimated and forever changed as a result of further development and possible destruction by private interests. These lands must be kept as protected so future generations can enjoy the beauty of our mother Earth! Please support what the majority of the public wants. We are at a critical crossroads with our environment and cannot afford to ignore or devalue it any longer.Thank you.

Bears Ears National Monument in southeastern Utah is home to an estimated 100,000 archaeological sites, including puebloan cliff dwellings dating as far back as 3500 years ago. Remnants of the Clovis culture, considered to be the ancestors of most of the indigenous cultures of our country, have been found, including their famous Clovis arrowheads. This Clovis culture is estimated to be 13,000 years old. Bears Ears is not just a national monument -- it's a national treasure. This rich area deserves our protection, and this protection has been given. Please please please, for the sake of our childrens' futures, do not take it away. Protect our monuments; protect our future.

Because President trump wants to ruin the federal lands, and destroy the artifacts from the monuments, he is destroying nature itself. As I've done my research, I have been attracted to the Grand Canyon-Parashant located in Arizona. This park needs to be protected from any government interruptions. The Grand Canyon has sacred land that belongs to the Navajos' which is a sacred land for them, It is there native land, which means it needs to be protected form any government affiliations. The government needs to worry about making the world a better place for the people, not destroying nature, which is an essential part of life. The grand Canyon-Parashant has history and a story. we need to protect our land to preserve and conserve our resources. The Grand Canyon is immense and has so much value to it that I wouldn't want to see it get regulated by the government. The Grand Canyon needs to be protected, along with other national parks.

Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument should be permanently maintained in its entirety as a National Monument due to its significant cultural, archeological, ecologic, and economic value to local Native American tribes, the local region, the state of California, and the United States.Executive Order #13792 directs Secretary Zinke to review Monuments in part based on "concerns of State, tribal, and local governments affected by a designation, including the economic development and fiscal condition of affected States, tribes, and localities." Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument holds great value to the Bay Area region, the state of California, and the United States. Prior to its 2015 establishment as a National Monument by President Obama, Berryessa was under consideration by Congress as a National Conservation Area. Local Congressmen Mike Thompson and John Garamendi led this effort and championed the National Monument designation of Berryessa Snow Mountain, with the support of the California State Legislature, the Elem Indian Colony of Pomo Indians, local political leaders from Lake County, Yolo, and Solano, local conservationists, recreation enthusiasts, business owners, and landowners. Congressman Garamendi recently penned a public letter in support of Berryessa's continued protection in the Record-Bee (http://www.record-bee.com/article/NQ/20170504/LOCAL1/170509901). Rarely do so many diverse stakeholders express such unified support for protection of important lands. Consequently, in response to President Trump's executive order, the local area has expressed its readiness for a political and legal fight to protect the National Monument. Clearly, the "concerns of State, tribal, and local governments affected by [the] designation" are aligned in favor of the permanent protection of Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument.As a large, beautiful, protected area within easy driving distance of the Bay Area metro region, Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument will draw visitors year-round to the area, creating jobs and growing the local economy. In fact, many businesses in the local area are driven by tourism supported by the protection of these lands. Over half of CA residents participate in outdoor recreation, and preservation of areas like Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument provides important support for CA's $6 billion outdoor recreation economy. Notably, no private lands were impinged by the National Monument designation, nor were water rights, ranchers' grazing rights, motorized recreation, hunting, or fishing. The National Monument protects Lake Berryessa, which provides both water and hydro-powered electricity to the North Bay area. Short-sighted resource exploitation would endanger all of this, and would not be in the economic best interest of the region, CA, or the US.Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument is also an ecologically important location that demands protection in its entirety. Snow Mountain in particular is an ecologic hotspot, with one of the highest densities of biodiversity in the state. The region is home to California's second largest population of wintering bald eagles, as well as the nearly-extinct Pacific Fisher, golden eagles, northern spotted owls, martens, black bears, mountain lions, river otters, black-tailed deer, tule elk, chinook salmon, and steelhead, among other notable ecological highlights such as a variety of rare plants. These lands are especially in need of permanent preservation to ensure a block of contiguous, intact habitat for at-risk species.Executive Order #13792 further instructs Secretary Zinke to consider "whether designated lands are appropriately classified under the act as "historic landmarks, historic and prehistoric structures, [or] other objects of historic and scientific interest." Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument has been home to a long history of native peoples, including the Yuki, Nomlaki, Patwin, Pomo, Huchnom, Wappo, Laki Miwok, and Wintum indigenous peoples. The significance of this legacy is evident in the cultural sites that cover the National Monument, from seasonal hunting and gathering camps to ancient villages, quarries, tool artifacts, petroglyphs, and trade routes of ancient indigenous peoples. More recent remains of homesteading dating to the 1840s gold rush, milling, and railroad logging are additional important historic artifacts. This history is archeologically significant, of obvious public interest, and in need of continued preservation.Located near the Bay Area, Berryessa Snow Mountain provides the rare refuge and recreation spot that is simultaneously wild yet highly accessible to a major population center. Due to the significant cultural, archeological, and historic importance of the area, its notable biodiversity, and the strong support for its preservation by diverse stakeholders, Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument should be permanently protected under its current status.

By telling the story of our historical, cultural, and natural heritage, our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation. I am extremely disappointed by President Trump's executive order attempting to undermine our national monuments.Attempts to rollback protections for national monuments would be both illegal and terribly misguided. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.An attempt to attack one monument by rolling back protections would be an attack on them all. Sending a signal that protections for our shared history and culture are not permanent would set a terrible precedent. This would discourage business investment and community growth around all national monuments while also sending the signal that the value of our history and natural wonders are negotiable.National monuments have already been shown to be tremendous economic drivers. The $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses in gateway communities rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities. Tourism injected $6.1 billion into New Mexico's economy and supported 89,000 jobs in 2014 alone. This is a vital economic driver for our rural communities that cannot be ignored or hamstrung.Our national monuments should remain protected for future generations to enjoy - they are a gift that belongs to all.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for national monuments. I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.

Dear Decision Maker,As a lifelong Utahan, I 100% support the national monuments Bears Ears, and Grand Staircase. These monuments have created thousands of jobs in the Utah tourism industry, Utah largest employer and money maker. Not only helping to create many, many jobs but also substantial local and state taxes collected. Tourism is Utah greatest asset and tourism is at an all time high and will only get bigger and bigger creating more jobs and collecting more taxes for the state of Utah. No-one will visit or tour depleted monuments scared with mining and energy waste, NO-ONE!!. Reducing or eliminating these monuments so that fossil fuel and mining can be explored is extremely short term thinking. Fossil fuel is outdated and will be replaced by other clean energy. Remember, once this irreplaceable public land is gone and sold, it is gone forever, and can never be replaced. I urge you to consider the fact that public lands are a national treasure and should absolutely be persevered for the current and future generations to come.

Dear Department of Interior,Dear Secretary Zinke,I am writing to urge you to protect each of the 27 national monuments that Donald Trump has ordered the Department of Interior to review. These historic sites represent a crucial part of our American heritage - they protect Native American sacred ground, preserve areas of historic and scientific value, and drive local economies with opportunities for recreation and tourism.An attack on any monument is an attack on the very promise of permanent and complete protection. The authority given by the Antiquities Act is well-tested and clear, and the process by which each of these 27 monuments was designated included significant local input in conjunction with a broad view of our shared national interests.You have called yourself an "unapologetic admirer of Teddy Roosevelt" and styled yourself in his image, but actions speak louder than preening. President Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act in 1906 to protect our shared American landscape from corporate looting. You, in following Trump's order, are doing the opposite.I urge you to protect and preserve our nation's national monuments from Trump's overreaching attempts to sell off America's most precious resources to his campaign donors in the oil industry.Sincerely, Robin Salsburg

Little Sr.

Dear Department of the Interior,I am writing to express my grave outrage that President Trump is putting numerous national monuments under review for potential exploitation by business interests. I have been to many of those monuments over my years of camping with my family, and the Grand Canyon area being reopened for uranium mining or that the Giant Sequoias being put in danger or the natural beauty of the Grand Staircase being marred are developments that I never thought would happen again in the United States.Please do not open ANY of these national monuments for exploitation for money.Thank you in advance for doing the right thing.Jean McGraw

Dear Department of the Interior: Don't act the idiot, just because idiots are now leading the agency. Resist! The last thing we need is more land given over to corporations or private interests for their gain, at the expense of the public. Do the right thing. You know what it is!

Dear DOI --Protect our national parks and monuments. The vast majority of federal lands are already open to resource extraction. The remaining places that are protected from development need to remain so.Thank you.

Dear DOI,As a citizen of the US and of the state of New Mexico, I feel strongly about keeping the National Monuments status for our National Monuments. It not only preserves amazing sites but provides affordable family activities in our very poor state, and it provides jobs, not only in the park areas, but in the supporting businesses nearby.The National Monuments and National Parks help our economy in a state who ranks at the bottom in unemployment and job opportunities. Help us, and help our wilderness by keeping our National Monuments.Thank you,Judy Eckhart

Dear DOI,First, let me say that I'm appalled that you are actually having to open this type of docket. This Administration has misguided intentions and a complete lack of understanding on the value of our National Monuments and the process in which they have been designated.I support the designation of these public lands listed in this docket as national monuments, and encourage the Department to maintain their existing boundaries. I would also suggest that, instead of trying to undo these national monument designations, you begin investigations on whether these unique places deserve to be designated as National Parks.As to your question related to whether your list of national monuments in this docket were designated or expanded without adequate public outreach and coordination with relevant stakeholders - the answer is no. These monuments were legally established and outreach to potential stakeholders was undertaken in each case and factors were weighed appropriately.As to your question on whether the application of factors (i) through (vii) were correctly applied: yes they were and the DOI does not need to consider changes to these factors at this time.

Dear Friends at the Department of Interior,It is my understanding that the Department of Interior has been assigned the task of reviewing some national monuments in order to consider whether and how best to utilize these national resources.It is further my understanding that there is a question on the part of the administration as to whether these monuments might alternatively be utilized for oil/gas production, with the view that capturing U.S.' own oil/natural gas would provide jobs, create further independence from other oil-producing countries/regions of the world, and generate substantial revenues to corporations and communities.These considerations are short-sited and miss the mark on sustainable work, wealth, health and independence from foreign governments. The United States has now a rich array of viable alternative energy resources that are scaling up for mass production, including wind farms, solar, and other green methods. These resources will not disrupt the landscapes and culture and history of our current national monuments, yet will create long term energy sources, long term revenues, long term job prospects, long term environmental protection and care for generations of Americans.I urge you to maintain and preserve these national monuments and to not change their current status. These areas are rich in natural beauty and cultural history, and contribute to an ecological balance that would be lost if used for oil/gas production. Further, oil/gas production may provide short term wealth to a small number of shareholders and CEO's, but the long term and broad benefit of oil/gas production has already been shown to be short lived. Additionally, data indicates that fracking methods may be having much greater effects on geographical instability/earthquakes in areas that previously showed low if any such disruptions.The time has passed for the short term, short-sighted plans with non-sustainable benefits for some. Rather, the great America that I know is one which recognizes the inherent multi-faceted value in our nation's natural resources and assets such as these in our national monuments.Thank you.

Dear Government Representative,Living within 60 minutes of the San Gabriel mountains, I want to chime in against letting this ecologically sensitive local wilderness be removed or diminished by the new Federal budget. Please help keep this land beautiful and pristine for future generations to appreciate and enjoy with all the natural beauty and majesty it provides.Kind regards,Hector Pila

Dear Interior Secretary Zinke,It would be wonderful if both you and President Trump were to visit as many of these National Monuments as you can prior to considering any changes to the existing Monuments. By so doing you will be able to experience these amazing areas and see for yourselves why they were established in the first place and why they deserve protection from development and potential destruction.Each has physical characteristics which make them unique and valuable icons for Americans and visitors from other countries to enjoy. They have economic benefits, as well as visual and historic significance. It would be a national tragedy if their special status was tampered with in any way, and could reflect a shortsighted approach to those places which Americans fromall walks of life hold dear.Please, please don't mess with a great thing!Thank you,Ann HillStanley, Idaho

Dear Interior Secretary Zinke:Last Friday, your office released a memo of the National Monuments under review per executive order 13792. This letter is regarding that order.Much has been written about the "Western ethos." This intangible set of characteristics enabled the pioneers to settle and explore the lands west of the Mississippi. Today that same tenacity and those values live on in Westerners who eek out a living in our arid Western landscape. Perhaps more than any of the other values, vision is the one I think is the most uniquely Western. Today, just as 150 years ago, we have a vision of what the West should be; our collective actions have been an (often unsuccessful) attempt to make the landscape to conform with our vision.In the Antiquities Act, Theodore Roosevelt also had a vision for the West. The national monuments he and the presidents who have followed him have left behind for America are a tangible reminder of Western vision and tenacity. As Wallace Stegner said, the Western landscape-whose crown jewels are protected by our national parks and monuments-is what we as a people have built our very character against.Much of this land has inherent monetary value, as the men who have looted archaeological sites for years on Cedar Mesa, which is now protected as part of Bears Ears National Monument in southeastern Utah, would tell you. Or the men who want to drill oil and gas wells in Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument in Hawaii or mine uranium from Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument in Arizona, would tell you. However, some of it simply has been protected for the sake of protection.San Gabriel Mountains National Monument in southern California houses three federally-designated Wildernesses, and is home to last bighorn sheep herd in the Transverse Ranges. Carrizo Plain National Monument in California is the home of critically endangered species such as the giant kangaroo rat (Dipodomys ingens, a keystone species), San Joaquin antelope ground squirrel (Ammospermophilus nelsoni), and San Joaquin kit fox (Vulpes macrotis mutica). Finally, back to Bears Ears and moving beyond its monetary value, the monument symbolizes Native American sovereignty, and our government's heartfelt acknowledgement that indigenous tribal history is one of the threads that holds our nation together.In using the Antiquities Act, President Roosevelt personified the characteristic of possessing vision. He also showed incredible restraint, the rarest of virtues. The President would have remained vigilant of the landscape's monetary value to the people, but he would have reminded us sometimes we need to protect a place simply so that future generations can experience it. In this sense, he would have worked to compromise in the creation of National Monuments. Indeed, the men who followed Roosevelt saw that that was the case in Grand Staircase-Escalante, Gold Butte, Grand Canyon-Parashant, and the others. Borders of these monuments were carefully set, with the interests of all "sides" in mind.As a self-proclaimed disciple of Mr. Roosevelt, I'm sure you are familiar with his New Nationalism speech from 1910, in which he said, "It is of little use for us to pay lip-loyalty to the mighty men of the past unless we sincerely endeavor to apply to the problems of the present precisely the qualities which in other crises enabled the men of that day to meet those crises." Secretary Zinke, I am asking you to look not only at our past, but also how far we've come as a nation as you endeavor to begin this review of our National Monuments. To paraphrase John Sawhill, you have the ability to ensure that future generations judge us by what we have chosen to protect, rather than by what we have extracted from the earth.Keep our National Monuments intact.

Dear Mr President,I saw you and your sons being interviewed this past summer when you were still a candidate. You were being interviewed by the Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Partnership. You and your sons expressed valuing our wilderness and your sons being hunters, agreed that protecting the lands and keeping them public was important to having the accessibility to our American heritage and legacy open wilderness.Please consider this in your review of these public lands.Please consider the values they contain and that they could be lost and irreversibly compromised.Any enterprise would not compare to the richness we have enjoyed in this country. You wouldn't want to be known for the President that dissolved and degraded our great Park system. In fact our public lands should be considered for further designation into our national system, be known for that - we are discovering the continuity of wildlands increases their vigor and vitality. It takes less effort to mitigate harm to ecosystems when they are large enough to stand against development. Fragmenting public lands means more work on our part to keep them healthy and to have an equilibrium where they sustain themselves without having to do conservation interventions.We enjoy a heritage of open space and is part of our legacy, please don't close off or fragment our national treasures!Thank You,Valeria Vincent Sancisi
Dear Mr. Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument is an important result of many interests coming together. It represents so much, and deserves to be protected. Please dont change it.

Dear Mr. Secretary,I ask that you please do not allow the current administration to destroy our country's beautiful National Monuments. It is critical that protect as much undisturbed land as possible. Once this land is destroyed it cannot be rebuilt. Once it's gone it's gone. The country has plenty of interested parties making sure that farm land, cities, and suburbs are protected and expanded. The federal government must step up to ensure that our natural wonders are maintained. The current generations and future generations deserve to have access too the beautiful natural resources that have been a part of this country since its inception.I want my children, grandchildren and all future generations to be able to enjoy the outdoors and the breathtaking beauty that our country is blessed to have!!Thank you

Dear Mr. Secretary,I will be hiking in Yosemite next month, a follow up to my hiking trip in Lassen Volcanic National Park last year and to Glacier National Park the year before. I was raised in California, still have family there, and together we regularly visit National Parks, National Historical Parks, and other sites of historic and scientific interest (battlefields, wildlife refuges, marine parks, etc.) in the U.S. Our trip in 2011 to Chaco Culture and Mesa Verde was a wonderful exploration of North American ancient peoples and cultures and came the spring after a trip to Egypt to experience that country's culture and people - but Chaco and Mesa Verde held their own in their own entirely special ways. Every trip to a National Park, and there have been dozens, has been greatly anticipated and we've never been disappointed. Not once.What does disappoint me, however, is learning that this administration is questioning the value of preserving the 22 parks listed in the Executive Order, in addition to Katahdin and several marine parks. I now live in New York State, where the north woods were decimated by logging and deforestation in the latter part of the 1800s. The state, in its wisdom and with a view to future generations, designated the Adirondack Park in 1902 as "forever wild," which it has remained. The park contains over 6 million acres, an area that includes the mountains and surrounding lands. The surrounding lands are especially important because they provide a necessary buffer against the effects of development and industrialization. Drought conditions over the past 20 years have made it especially necessary to protect this land and the limited water that allows it to thrive. The State of New York has sued nearby states because pollution from coal generation to the west has damaged the trees, especially the fragile tree roots, and caused a haze over a once pristine environment. Many years ago I climbed Mt. Marcy - the highest point in New York and located in the Adirondacks - and it was troubling to see smog in the distance and stunted growth among the trees and bushes caused by CO2 and other pollutants. Visitors from the cities along the Eastern Seaboard hike in the Adirondacks to see pristine nature and natural beauty, wildlife and wildflowers, and not the results of urbanization they can find at home.This administration questions the value of protecting these 22 sites because conservation purposefully does not allow development, especially extraction and mining activities - all activities measured by money. The value of conservation is intangible, measured in experiences, education, and enlightenment. They are called "national" parks because they benefit the entire nation and all people yet to come, forever. To suggest, which this E.O. does, that there was insufficient time for comment, or to imply, which the E.O. also does, that these lands could be better managed by their respective states, does not begin to grasp the significance of these parks. We don't know what we don't know in terms of their biological, geological, historical, and scientific importance. We have so much to learn from the parks and can benefit in untold and unknown ways by their preservation and proper management. The default should be - must be - conservation.Thank you for your time and attention to my comments.Sincerely,Julee Johnson120 First St.Ithaca, NY 14850

Dear Pres.Trump & Dept. of Interior,A "top dog" Scientist not long ago revealed in a prediction for our Mother Earth that we would NOT see our planet past 100 yrs! While many predictions of world reknown Scientists & "Prophets" have not always come to fruition, many scientists concur with Stephen Hawkings prediction! Quite startling that YOU Mr. President seem to be contributing to the demise of our beloved National Monuments i.e. Grand Staircase! What then will you say if this Bill is passed and coal mining moves forward as well as many other beauties of this National Treasure become desecrated and trampled on? Or are you of the opinion Mr. Trump that it won't matter because you won't be around to see the global warming disaster you contributed to anyway? Is it the "profit" of such lucridous endeavors that keep you so richly focused on "trample not ample"? Or will you be the President remembered for preservation not desecration?What do you really wish for your posterity? Do you wish for them to know what was here before them? Or can you only be consumed for your posterity to reap prosperity?We speak out against the consumption of mining in Grand Staircase and all of our treasured National Monuments and Parks! PLEASE BE CONSIDERATE OF THE POLITICAL ENDEAVOURS OF OUR GREAT LEADERS BEFORE US WHO WANTED PRESERVATION NOT DESECRATION FOR THEIR POSTERITY!

Dear President Trump & Representatives,I am an ardent hiker, outdoor enthusiast, and lover of nature. I am writing to plead that our current national monuments retain their protected classification - specifically Sand to Snow and San Gabriel Mountains... We must support these treasures, not dissemble them...Thanking you in advance - I trust you will do the right thing...

Dear President Trump and the Department of the Interior,Thank you for asking for comment on the review of certain national monuments. I am pleased to be offered the opportunity to express my strong, unwavering support for all national monuments. Our national monuments protect areas of beauty, value to our history and culture, and create a shared sense of our heritage and identify as Americans. I urge the expansion of monuments and parks, not that they be reduced in number.I'm not rich financially, but I am rich in shared ownership of our public lands. I believe that all Americans deserve to have that wealth maintained, not diminished, and that indeed, the role of our government should be to increase that shared ownership, ownership by all the people; the role of government should not be to increase ownership and profit by a small number of individuals and corporations.Please maintain all of the monuments under consideration, and seek opportunities to establish new monuments and public lands.Sincerely,Cynthia Jones

Dear President Trump,I urge you at this time to rescind the Bears Ears National Monument.I found nothing originating from the Obama Regime, worth two lice on a corn row, including land grabs.Thank you for your consideration.

Dear Ryan Zinke,My comment is in support of Sonoran Desert National Monument. I have a personal research interest in the objects of this monument--the archaeological sites that tell the stories of more than ten millennia of human history on this desert landscape. Population growth along the Sun Corridor threatens these remarkable places. Furthermore, the rich natural environment that was important to past human use of this area merits protection today.President Clinton established Sonoran Desert National Monument through a proclamation under the Antiquities Act of 1906. Only Congress has the authority to make changes to this national monument. President Trump has no authority whatsoever to diminish this monument.This monument is important to Arizona's citizens, to visitors to our desert lands, and to the American Indian groups that still live in the Sonoran Desert and know that their heritage is present on this landscape. It also provides economic benefits to the regional economy and serves as an educational and recreational resource.Sincerely,Bill DoelleTucson, AZ 85718

Dear Ryan Zinke,Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.Sincerely,Catherine HutchinsonMansfield, OH 44907

I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.Sincerely,Robert PucBrooklyn, NY 11217

Dear Ryan Zinke,The Giant Sequoia National Park should be protected for its beautiful natures that populates the Sierra Nevada. The trees populate about 38 groves and covers a vast amount of land. Dear Ryan Zinke,This is a comment in support of Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument. I am a professional archaeologist and I have shared background information about the rich history of this area in an issue of Archaeology Southwest Magazine that I edited back in 2001. The cultural, natural, and aesthetic resources of this place are valued by large numbers of Americans. The economic and educational values of tourism have provided positive benefits in this economically challenged area and has potential for long-term sustainability.President Clinton established Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument through a proclamation under the Antiquities Act of 1906. Only Congress has the authority to make changes to this national monument. President Trump has no authority whatsoever to diminish this monument.Sincerely,Bill DoelleTucson, AZ 85718

Dear Ryan zinke, my name is devin k piephoff I am 8 years old in 2nd grade awhile back in write letters to congressman /woman please don't let me down, can you please rescind the monument for me, we use the monument for scared reason we prayer there with great grandma Betty jones we collect herbs for her and sumac willows and berries to make basket out of and to eat please help us make it right for us..may you be guided by our holy people to make the right choice.

Dear Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke,This is to plead with you to honor the intent and wishes of the people of our nation that the government protect and preserve landscapes and places that have special significance. The Utah monuments have historical value, scientific discovery value and natural beauty that cannot be duplicated! These places need full protection from development and from the encroachment of destructive forms of use.We of this generation have a huge responsibility to hold the line and stand firm against the pressures to use, to develop, and to negate the value of such places. Once these remarkable monuments are damaged or destroyed by human activities such as energy exploration and extraction, and all the things that accompany such projects, or by the careless use of the land in any other way, the damage is permanent and the scientists, the public and affected Native Americans will forever be negatively impacted by the loss.What we need in America is strong leadership that understands the intrinsic value of nature. Please, I beg of you, be that leadership! We the people are counting on you to preserve and protect our natural world!Thank you for your attention to this matter,Lynda McEvoy

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,.I am a 70 year old retired widow. All of my adult life my family and I have made use of public lands for weekend camping trips, day- hikes and longer vacations. I couldn't wait to get my Golden Eagle Pass and am still working on visiting as many national parks as possible, but I also appreciate all of the forest land in which we hike here in the Pacific Northwest and the many monuments there are to visit as I move around the country spending time with my grown children. Our public lands are a chance for all of us, no matter where we live, to absorb the natural beauty of this country and I think they should be preserved for all forever.Sincerely,Fay ChapmanSeattle, WA 98112

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,.I just hiked in Escalante Grand Staircase, Lower Calf Falls, and it was spectacular. The birds were everywhere singing in the lush green along the river, and the colors of the red rocks and blue sky and green bottomlands glorious. My husband and I enjoyed visiting with the many other people hiking that morning, pointing out the petroglyphs to each other. Wow! Please preserve this monument for everyone to see and enjoy how there is such beauty and life in the land of the red rocks. Then go and have a coffee at Kiva Koffeehouse and watch the afternoon storms roll in, blue black clouds against the red and white sandstone.Sincerely,Linda HoushowerBluffton, OH 45817
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,.let's keep public space for the public. Preserve the areas where we can be free, alone, quiet and peaceful.Sincerely,Chris NewcombWoburn, MA 01801

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,.the National Parks and monuments are the very heart and soul of our country. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,"I recognize the right and duty of this generation to develop and use the natural resources of our land; but I do not recognize the right to waste them, or to rob, by wasteful use, the generations that come after us." - Theodore RooseveltPresident Roosevelt understood that the protection of our lands for future generations was vital to the success of our great nation. We must continue protect and preserve our treasured national monuments for the future of our children, for the future of our great country.The threat to these conserved lands is an insult to the American people who protect the wildlife and ecosystems and those whom hold land sacred. Their protection is vital for the understanding of our history and heritage, and for the enjoyment of our children. These lands hold our freedom, beauty, our stories, our magnificence. They are our American legacy.- Sherry ShookSincerely,Sherry ShookLong Beach, CA 90802
