Surely there are other places we as a government can cut costs.Sincerely,Tom OconnorPittsburgh, PA 15236

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,America is beautiful and a destination for people to visit from around the world because of our awe-inspiring national monuments. Past Presidents have understood the importance of safe-guarding these treasures for everyone to enjoy. Please continue to protect and preserve our national monuments. This is critical for current and future generations of Americans to enjoy the land around them.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,America's National Monuments are a place where you and your children can breathe fresh air. Gulp it with greed. It's one of the last places on the planet where you can do that without harm. Marvel at the beauty, it is marvelous after all . That's what I do when I visit this pristine yet vulnerable resource. I breathe and I do so with greed as it may not be there, in that pristine way much longer.I love the cities for their progress, their hustle and bustle is a current of man-made energy that is electric and unyielding. It is exciting, but I can't take deep breaths without the risks that come from city living.Let's keep the natural integrity of America's National Monuments in tact. Free from the hustle, peacefully tucked away from the bustle, untarnished by our wants, naturally providing for our needs (air). Be brave, guard her, it is a risk worth taking to guard and protect. Keep America's National Monuments a place where we can simply breathe.Sincerely,Anna EricksonBountiful, UT 84010

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,America's National Parks and Monuments have been very special to me. I have a lot of great memories and I want to continue to be able to enjoy what we have preserved as a nation. I want the parks to exist for future generations to enjoy in the same way that I have. Thanks.Sincerely,Nick VivianNew York, NY 10032

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a 22-year old that has suffered from severe anxiety and depression for his entire adult life, enjoying our parks and monuments is one of the only things that brings me peace and relaxation. Taking away our public lands is not only harmful to the animals and environment that we have long pillaged and destroyed, but also harmful to the people of America who find comfort and solace in our country's beauty. As someone who has worked in the Senate and in the White House, I understand the need to adhere to the interests that elected you. But Mr. Secretary, do not destroy the few places in our country that allows me to relax and find peace within myself. My medication doesn't, but the parks do. Please do not take that away from me and millions of other Americans.SincerelyJoeSincerely,Joe JacobsonLos Angeles, CA 90024

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a child of a boom and bust oil town, I've seen the fragile economies that pop up around oil shell drilling. It's not sustainable and the bust cycles are devastating. Instead of expanding that by rescinding or shrinking size of our national lands , let's invest in keeping the monuments as they are, supporting the multitude of industries (and MY job!) that rely on it without the cyclical downturns associated with the oil, natural gas, and mining companies.Sincerely,Sarah AmosSeattle, WA 98109

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a citizen of the United States of America, I respectfully call on you to do your duty to the integrity of this nation, our past, and our future, and protect the National Monuments and keep them as they are. The fragility and significance of these honored and preserved lands, entrusted to us all, cannot be overrstated. I do not know how to impress this on you, Secretary, that we cannot possible understand the importance of preserved and protected lands.I live on the border of Colorado and Utah. I was born and raised here, as was my family for over a hundred years. I have personally seen the beauty and wonder of these monuments side by side with the irresponsible and irreversible damages caused otherwise . Please don't let this happen more than it already has. Don't let your name be attached to a potentially embarrassing moment in the history of this nation's precious soil.Sincerely,Christian StoreyHesperus, CO 81326

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a father, grandfather, surfer and nature lover, I ask that you consider our country's forefathers vision in setting aside these special national places for the people of our country.Having spent time in Yellowstone last year, I marvelled at the history, beauty and insight in preserving this special place. Our world and country is becoming overcrowded and industrialized, and National parks speak to our souls.If I was in your position, as a hunter , outdoorsman and government official , I would want my legacy to be one that protected and expanded the parks and monuments , not the guy who screwed the people and made them smaller or abolisked what was previously created.Your boss Trump, has no vision and only sees money and profit in developing land , not leaving it unspoiled. He would get lost in Central Park , which is sad for a New Yorker !Please lead and consider the future and support more parks, more monetary support, so that future generations of Americans can enjoy them.Sincerely,Stephen CummingsSan Diego, CA 92101

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a fellow Montanan, you Mr. Zinke should know best if all how much we appreciate he outdoors and how critical our public lands are for tourism dollars in our state.Sincerely,Keif StorrarHelena, MT 59601

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a mountain biker and a citizen co-owner of our country's public lands, I SUPPORT our existing national monuments. I SUPPORT high-quality recreation that's managed in lands protected from reckless development and irresponsible resource extraction.I OPPOSE the repeal of any national monument protections. This sets a bad precedent. These landscapes host high quality recreation on some of our country's most valuable landscapes. National monuments have proven to be popular attractions for tourists and locals alike, substantially contributing to local and regional economies.The San Gabriel Mountains, Fort Ord, and Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monuments in California are three critical landscapes that mountain bikers had ample voice in creating through a public process. Mountain bikers have trail plans under consideration in other national monuments including Browns Canyon in Colorado, Katahdin Woods and Waters in Maine and Cascade Siskiyou in Oregon. Likewise, cyclists enjoy riding the rural roads in Escalante Grand Staircase of Utah and Canyon of the Ancients Monuments in Colorado.These opportunities to enjoy our public lands have ALL come from being involved in a public process. Mountain bikers across the nation can visit and aspire to ride these trails in a natural protected environment.We applaud a public comment period but urge that a public process be incorporated for designating new monuments not used to roll back existing designations.Sincerely,Danny McculloughSaint Paul, MN 55126

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a photographer - I spend nearly every weekend on public land. I document the natural beauty of the southwest and boast regularly about how lucky we as Americans are to live in the most beautiful country on earth.Furthermore, my photography touches the lives of a multitude of people. It encourages those who might be otherwise causing society or themselves harm to get out and explore the land the way it was intended - public and free. I've witnessed many individuals go from uncontributing members of society to being touched so deeply by nature, that they've become activists, guides, public servants, and lovers of the outdoors.Why change the one thing that still makes this country great?Sincerely,David SadofskyLas Vegas, NV 89147

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a supporter of bird conservation and our public lands, I strongly urge you to protect all national monuments under review and to reject any changes to these iconic landscapes.The national monuments created in the past twenty years have protected vital bird habitat, helped safeguard our heritage, and benefited communities across the country. Reversing any of these designations would be a tragic mistake with harmful consequences for all that depend on our magnificent public lands.From the buttes of Bears Ears that support birds like the Golden Eagle, to the underwater canyons of the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts National Monument that support a critical ecosystem for Atlantic Puffins, to the rocky peaks of the Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks National Monument, the shrub-steppe habitat of Hanford Reach National Monument in Washington, and out to the pristine Pacific waters of the Papahanaumokuakea National Monument, all of these lands and waters are indispensable to birds and other wildlife.These monuments are a legacy of Teddy Roosevelt. He and all fifteen subsequent presidents--of both parties--have recognized the need and value of protecting these public lands with the Antiquities Act. I urge you to uphold Roosevelt's legacy and maintain these monuments for current and future generations.Sincerely,Maridell DelesandroLexington, SC 29073

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a Utahn, I feel lucky to have amazing preserved locations of vast expanse upon which I can go and know I can venture for miles and miles without having to see the blight of energy development. I understand that energy needs to be produced, and that our current infrastructure is dependent upon coal. Yet even if there are great coal deposits in some of Utah's National Monuments, it seems foolish to scrap or degrade these bastions, when the demand for coal is dropping, meaning that the coal in current mines is less needed. What rational makes sense of the economics behind that. Coal is cheap and has almost no profit margin, especially for a new mine. So lets invest a bunch into a whole new mine!!. Seems foolish to me.Sincerely,JOHN ANDERSSalt Lake City, UT 84123

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a veteran struggling with PTSD I have relied heavily on the emotional relief provided by the public lands now being threatened. I personally know hundreds of veterans that return home from stressful war zones to seek relief in the wide-open spaces currently coming under attack. As someone who has stood on that line defending this great nation I implore you to stand up and defend these natural treasures.Sincerely,Joshua ThompsonCorpus Christi, TX 78412

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As an Alaska I value and appreciate public lands, for recreation including hiking, camping, fishing, and just enjoying the scenery. Having natural places available to all people, and not locked up for private use or constrained by commercial uses, is very important. I believe this very strongly. Please do not weaken or remove access or change the status of any of these lands.Sincerely,Monica OKeefeAnchorage, AK 99524

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As an avid lover of the outdoors, it saddens me that preserving the integrity of these monuments is something that is even being examined. Please- do not touch these lands. Once the sanctity of these beautiful landscapes that nature has created have been ravanged by man for purely financial gain and selfishness, they will be gone forever. My children and grandchildren will never be able to experience and appreciate the wonders of this planet as I have and will continue to do. I urge you to strongly reconsider your stance on the environment-- there are some things that money cannot buy, and appreciating the untouched beauty of these areas is one of them.Sincerely,Jennifer FaustHamburg, PA 19526

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As an avid traveler and outdoor enthusiast, it hurts my heart to know so many national monuments are on the chopping block. Some of them I've seen and been personally moved by, and some of them I haven't yet had the opportunity. But all of them are deserving of our protection.We as people living in a developed country have a responsibility to protect and fight for this planet. It's the only one we have. If we let greed consume us, and open these sacred lands to drilling and other destructive, for-profit activities, we are essentially telling future generations that they are on their own. In a government that claims to be for the people, that's not a message we should be sending. Instead of scaling back protections, we should be ramping them up.Please make the right decision and continue to preserve these national monuments.Sincerely,Frank TreeceWyandotte, MI 48192

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As an environmental researcher, I submit we need far more protected, public land. We are in the midst of the human-caused sixth mass extinction event in Earth's history. Protecting very large, connected landscapes is one of the key steps needed to address it. Therefore, I urge you no to reduce any land protections, but to increase them by a large margin.Sincerely,John FeeneyBoulder, CO 80304

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As evidenced by the notorious events of the last decade when BLM officials seized thousands of artifacts illegally collected by antiquity traders, the states cannot and should not be left to protect Native American ruins and natural lands.Utahs.http//archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/sltrib/news/58051384-78/blm-artifacts-blanding-american.html.http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700182124/Warehouse-protects-thousands-and-thousands-of-looted-Indian-antiquities.Your wise observations and thoughtful comments about the coalition of Utah tribal leaders lead me to deeply hope you will act to protect all the National Monuments from privatization and development.The State of Utah has a dismal record of protecting the land and archeological treasures. For decades, the state has turned a blind eye to the collection of Indian burial sites by local Caucasians. Skulls, pottery, basketry and jewelry are casual items, called "trinkets and junk" are on exhibit and are for sale.Please act to protect our nations archeological history and natural landscapes from profiteering in the moment.Sincerely, Martha Jaye Rieser1646 S. Devonshire dr., Salt Lake City UT 84108Sincerely,Martha RieserSalt Lake City, UT 84108

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As I've thru-hiked the Pacific Crest Trail, I witnessed many regions that weren't protect by the government and saw the damage that was done to this land as there were no rules or regulation established over it.As an outdoorsman and a citizen who cares for health and safety of our public lands, I believe it is an extremely important to keep and protect our public lands from power hungry corrupt politicians and giant resource hungry corporation!Sincerely,Sergey PikhtotskiyPhiladelphia, PA 19114

Likewise, cyclists enjoy riding the rural roads in Escalante Grand Staircase of Utah and Canyon of the Ancients Monuments in Colorado.These opportunities to enjoy our public lands have ALL come from being involved in a public process. Mountain bikers across the nation can visit and aspire to ride these trails in a natural protected environment.We applaud a public comment period but urge that a public process be incorporated for designating new monuments not used to roll back existing designations.Sincerely,Adam GonyoHuntingtown, MD 20639

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As you know, public lands are vital to our nation's culture, history, and prosperity. As a hunter and outdoorsman, I am sure you would agree that any threat to these special places must be taken seriously so that public lands can be protected for future generations. Please ensure that our public and protected lands remain just that, public and protected.Thank you very much for your time and your lifetime of service!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,As you mull over your decisions and read these reviews, I hope you realize how important these protected lands are to the integrity of our nation.Personally, I have used the National Parks as a tool in my science classroom in order to teach my students the importance of biodiversity. By teaching brilliant young minds that biodiversity is essential for life, they begin to realize that every species has its purpose, including the human species. Without biodiversity our nation lacks character and beauty.I have used the National Parks as a way of educating them on climate and land formations. This has been a catalyst in igniting a passion for wanting to know more about our country. To see young eyes grow wide at the thought of these natural wonders actually residing within our own country is truly inspiring.Having these protected monuments, lands, forests, and parks offers more than a weekend getaway or a walk in the park. They offer our youth a chance to become proud and motivated by what our county has to offer. They understand the importance of protecting not only land nation wide, but land right outside their doors. They become responsible adults, who wish to continue to protect and preserve the nation. Instead of them dreaming to travel the world, they dream to travel the United States.To take away these lands that are protected is to take away hope and responsibility from our youth. They need something to stand for and if you're not standing for it, what makes you think they will?Sincerely,November WilliamsSylvania, OH 43560

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,At a time when our nation is divided more than ever, our country's beauiful public lands stand to be an incredible unifier. I moved across county recently, driving 3000+ miles from Massachusetts to Washington State. I had the pleasure of driving and sleeping in our nation's stunning national parks, forests and grasslands and learning about our rich cultural heritage at several national monuments. Each place I visited left me in awe, not just by the beauty of my surroundings but also the way these majestic public spaces are common ground for all Americans, from a family with 4 young children to a retired couple in their 70s. Shrinking these places in size would have devastating impacts on the environment as well as your fellow Americans that cherish them deeply.Sincerely,Molly Sullivan02794

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument is a scarce and precious rehouse. It is both ecologically rich and culturally valuable. These are the wild places we lovewhere we run, hike, camp, ski, fish, climb and spend important time with our friends and families. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole.Furthermore, rescinding or changing the boundaries of any National Monument sends an extremely detrimental message that ANY Monument or Park that we so dearly treasure is NOT permanent. Such a message would be extremely damaging to the stability, sustainability and stature of OUR public lands.Please continue to protect Bears Ears.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Dear Secretary Zinke,I'm writing to you because of the actions of President Trump, I know you are republican so you might be a supporter of him, but his actions can affect more than just one group of people or things. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Dear Sir or Madam,During my younger years my family trips got to cover much of the US, I could not count the parks visited but by the time I was old enough to drive I had visited 35 states and certainly 2 or more state or national parks in each one since we always camped and nature was part of life. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Hello!As a rock climber in the Western US, I spend more time in our beautiful national parks and monuments than I do in cities; these places are my home. These lands more than anything make me proud to let climbers from other countries know where I am from. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I *strongly* object to your the President's proposal to review the size and status of any of our National Monuments. Further, I object even more vehemently to the implication that these National Monuments might be downsized or changed in any way.Every one of our National Monuments, going back to the days of Teddy Roosevelt, has been extensively vetted both locally and nationally before any was declared a National Monument. While some sites attracted some opposition, all were approved by each President with the support of the majority of people who lived in or near each site.Contrary to the statements I have heard your Administration make, these Monuments were the *opposite* of a so-called land grab. They were all already owned by us, the public. Giving them National Monument status merely elevated the level of protection they received, saving them from greedy private interests, who have long wanted to exploit the lands we, the People, own.These lands should remain federal lands for all the citizens of the nation. You have received this public legacy from generations of public-minded, elected and appointed officials. Now it is your turn to protect them to the highest degree possible so you can pass them along to the future. Please do your duty by remembering that the future belongs to all of us, not just to a privileged few. Thank you.Sincerely,Connie SidlesSeattle, WA 98105

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am a lover of nature and am active in it nearly every day. Preserving our wild lands for future generations is one of my highest priorities. Rescinding or changing it hurts one of our nations most incredible landscapes. Our public lands are vital to our national legacy, which belongs not only to us, but also to all future Americans. These are the wild places we lovewhere we run, hike, camp, ski, fish, climb and spend important time with our friends and families. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am a native of Idaho and have spent almost all of my life enjoying the public lands of Idaho, Wyoming, Utah and the other wonderful western states. I am not a wealthy person nor a land owner, yet my family and I are privileged to have access to incredible richness of beauty and outdoor activities available on public lands provided and protected by the Federal Government through the Department of Interior.Please continue to protect our beautiful, priceless national parks and monuments. Despite the ongoing difficulties of public opinion and state versus federal control, please do not rescind or change current national monument or national park designations. I love sharing these precious places with my own children and grandchildren and I pray that they will be able to continue this tradition for generations to come.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am a Southern Utahn by birth (from Beaver) and feel so blessed to be near so much amazing public land. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am in favor of not only improving management of current public lands but of also increasing the size of national public lands. Why? Because I see them as great investment for future generations (conservative and liberal alike).Where will our children explore, hike, ride, hunt, target shoot? How will they live? The American frontier should not be owned as private property. It is an American virtue and should be a unalienable right.Moreover from fiscal perspective, what happens if in the future new profitable land uses are discovered on the public lands we already sold? (sounds far fetched but think of Las Vegas; shale gas and oil.) If we want to sell some our public lands, we should do so at an optimal time to fetch the maximum return (of the sale of our public asset). We should not be in a rush simply because our current politicians have a short-run agenda to finish ASAP. We should weigh the benefits of selling land today compared to selling it in the future 5, 10, even 50 years from now. Doing this will actually maximize our government revenue and help lower taxes (or whatever your political goals may be). Who gives the current politicians the right to sell off the assets of the future generations?Sincerely,Ian MorrallPittsburgh, PA 15224

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am married and have a daughter. My husband and I dont have that much in common if you look at us, but we love one thing, camping. We camp. My husband works hard and camping is his only release. Being away and surviving in the wilderness brings a peace that cany be achieved through any other outlet. Assateague is another beautiful place we like to camp. Our daughter is 3 and we look forward to taking her on her first camping trip next month. To share the things that bring you joy with your children, well that is life. Finding joy is the meaning of life. Please don't let them take ours.Sincerely,Molly ParkerChesapeake, VA 23322

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am urging you to take a stand against the destruction of our public lands. These lands are the places that should be saved for eternity. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I AM VERY CONCERNED AND ANGRY ABOUT THIS ISSUE!!Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.AMERICAN SAMOARose AtollARIZONAGrand Canyon - ParashantIronwood ForestVermillion CliffsSonoran DesertCALIFORNIAGiant SequoiaCarrizo PlainCascade-SiskiyouSan Gabriel MountainsBerryessa Snow MountainMojave TrailsSand to SnowCOLORADOCanyons of the AncientsHAWAIIPapahnaumokukeaIDAHOCraters of the MoonMAINEKatahdin Woods & WatersMONTANAUpper Missouri River BreaksNEW ENGLANDNortheast Canyons and SeamountsNEW MEXICORio Grande del NorteOrgan Mountains-Desert PeaksNEVADABasin and RangeGold ButteOREGONCascade-SiskiyouPACIFIC OCEANMarianas TrenchPacific Remote IslandsUTAHGrand Staircase-EscalanteBears EarsWASHINGTONHanford ReachSincerely,DEBORAH SMITHOklahoma City, OK 73112

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am writing to ask that you maintain the integrity of America's public lands by (a) maintaining the protected status of national monuments that are currently under review, and (b) resisting efforts to open public lands to corporate interests. As Colorado residents, my family and I regularly benefit from the legacy of public lands set aside by President Theodore Roosevelt and his successors. We spend summers in the Arapahoe National Recreation Area, regularly visit Rocky Mountain National Park, and hike in surrounding areas such as the Roosevelt, Arapaho, and Medicine Bow-Routt National Forests. My two daughters (ages 12 and 7) cherish their time in the mountains, and regularly cite our visits to public lands as the happiest times in their young lives. For me, time spent in the wilderness rejuvenates my work as a faculty member at a public university, preparing the next generation of health care practitioners and studying new ways to manage debilitating diseases. Our health, well-being, and quality of life are intimately connected to our public lands.Our family knows from personal experience that when commercial interests are allowed to use these lands for logging or oil and gas development, they disfigure the area's natural beauty and sometimes make parts of it inaccessible to the public. President Roosevelt's initial designation of public lands such as national forests and national parks took place over the opposition of private companies (in that case the railroads) that wanted to use these lands for personal profit without regard for environmental consequences. Those of us who live in the West chose this area of the country in large part because of its rugged natural beauty. Colorado is among the healthiest states in the nation in large part because of the many outdoor recreation areas available. Public lands are an important resource for personal and societal renewal; Thoreau was right to say that "in wildness is the preservation of the world."We are extremely concerned about the current administration's prioritization of private over public interests in the use of these lands. Public lands belong to everyone, and short-term economic gains should not be allowed to trump the urgent public interest that we all have in preserving these lands for future generations. Please don't let this vital public resource be squandered on your watch.Sincerely,Paul CookBroomfield, CO 80021

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am writing to ask you to leave Bears Ears as a National Monument.I spend a lot of time in Southern Utah and have visited the valuable historical remnants of native people, and the lands there that should be preserved and protected. This area is deserving on Monument status, and the local people and native tribes who live there have been working together for it's protection.Do not recind monument status for Bears Ears!Thank you for your consideration.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am writing to support maintaining national parks and monuments as public land. I want my tax money to go towards protecting these areas from destruction by special interest groups.Sincerely,Rachel Bowens-RubinCambridge, MA 02139

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am writing to urge you to please maintain the integrity of America's national monuments. As an avid outdoorsman, I value places like these and hope to be able to share these unruined lands with my children one day. Thank you for your time and consideration.Regards,Lisa Henning, PhDSincerely,Lisa HenningPanama City, FL 32404

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am writing to voice my concern over the future of our public lands. As an outdoor enthusiast, climber, and paleontologist, I believe that America's National Parks and Monuments are the single richest resource of the U.S. Numerous stakeholders from various backgrounds enjoy these parks every single day, and the National Parks and Monuments are known all over the world for their iconic, accessible landscapes. The parks are a symbol of the government and the people working together to preserve these places of natural beauty for the public.In addition to their recreational value, many of the areas under review (especially Grand Staircase-Escalante Monument and Bears Ears Monument) contain an abundance of extremeley important fossils. It is vital that we preserve these sites and their wealth of knowledge about the past. Even within one park, different areas contain various animals from different time periods, so reducing the size of these parks would be detrimental to our discovery of the past. In addition to preserving the protected areas, I strongly support the expansion of the Red Canyon Region of Bear's Ears National Monument, which is currently unprotected. This area includes sites with the most abundant Triassic fossils anywhere.The Antiquities Act, signed by President Theodore Roosevelt, was one of the most important pieces of legislation for protecting and ensuring public access to America's greatest natural areas. Changing Monument designations without the legistlative process undermines this important Act. Furthermore, while I appreciate that you are reviewing comments from the public, the 15 day comment period is definitely not enough time to gage the public opinion on this matter. I only found out about Executive Order 13792 a week ago, and only because a friend brought it to my attention. I have talked to several people who are stakeholders on public lands and are not aware of Executive Order 13792. When I told them about it, they voiced great concern and emphasized how much they value these parks and monuments, and how important their preservation is.I think a greater amount of public outreach and longer comment period would be extremeley beneficial, allowing more input from a wide range of communities.I sincerely hope that the review of our National Monuments and Parks results in a decision in favor of protecting America's public lands for generations to come.Thank you.Sincerely,Eva HerbstSanta Rosa, CA 95404

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I and my mother are lovers of our national parks and monuments. We take at least two road trips each year to go to these natural wonders and marvel at the beauty of what we have here in the United States. Any reduction in our public spaces would be going backward and would, I fear, be something our country would not recover from. We need these spaces for future generations but for our own as well. Whether for recreation or just an escape from the city for peace and quiet, these are national treasures and are for EVERYONE! Thank you for taking the time to read these comments and I hope they sway you in not taking any acreage away from any of our national parks and monuments.Sincerely,Jaki DodsonBonney Lake, WA 98391

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I ask that you keep all NP's and National Monuments.They represent our legacy to each generation. They define who we are and how we're connected to Mother Earth.Save them all for your children, grandchildren and their children.Thank you.Sincerely,Kevin ParksHeber City, UT 84032

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I believe that the protection of our country's most beautiful natural environments is vitally important to the wellbeing of all Americans, and all peoples. Balancing the conservation of these environments with the desire to exploit the land for commercial gain is obviously a difficult job, but I would urge that the short-term gain from the latter destroys that balance altogether. I truly hope that we are able to protect lands such as Bears Ears for future generations to enjoy. Thank you for considering the thoughts and desires of the public in this process.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I believe we need to have public lands where we can go for recreation, relaxation, and to just enjoy. I do not believe that every piece of land needs to be developed, or it's natural resources taken. We need to protect these lands not only for ourselves but for the future of our children and their children. I have enjoyed many national monuments and national parks. Many of them provide the serenity that is missing from our busy every day lives. Please protect these lands!Sincerely,JoAnn HydeRichland, MI 49083

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I do NOT think the lands of the national parks (any of them) should be sold or made non- public. These lands provide history, culture, and wellbeing to so many citizens and animals living in and around these parks. Considering the selling of these lands to private enterprise is an attack on the freedom and beauty of our country. I urge you to do what you know is right, and keep these lands in the hands of the public so we may all benefit from these places.Sincerely,Rachel QuindlenCarrboro, NC 27510

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I don't understand the 'rush to judgement' on our valuable resources. Why, suddenly, is it so important to re-designate these important national treasures? How have they, in a matter of weeks, become less sacred to the American Public?The answer, of course, is that they are NOT less than they were to us....they are only less to those who want them re-designated so that they can be raped for whatever monetary treasures the greedy can reap. Please stand up ans say 'no' -- we must preserve the land, our valuable historic assets for our children, and our children's children.Already, too much power is in the hands of the rich, too many decisions that affect ALL Americans is being made by the few. We all have children, nieces, nephews, grandchildren....will you leave them nothing of our heritage? Please consider all of the possibilities both for the present and the future as you make your decisions.Thank you.Sincerely,Teresa GilesVirginia Beach, VA 23451

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I encourage to preserve all our National Monuments and public lands as they now stand. Raised in California and now living in Northern Arizona, my and my family's enjoyment of our public lands, National Monuments and National Parks has been a life-long enjoyment. As a child, my family took a rode trip in our station wagon each summer, and I've visited almost every protected area in the Western United States from California to Colorado, plus Alaska, Hawaii, and some Eastern areas as well. As a parents, my husband and I continued that tradition of travel and outdoor recreation with our children who are now young adults. Our daughter just graduated with her degree in Parks and Recreation Management.We've marveled at the foresight and dedication of those intelligent citizens and politicians that have gone before us who fought to preserve our public lands for future generations. Please do not let the greed of the current administration and corporations destroy these places. They've been carefully reviewed before being designated, and I encourage you to not let these protected places be stripped of their protection by rash decisions.If you haven't ever watched the documentary by Ken Burns called "Our National Parks - America's Best Idea", I encourage you do so. And give President Trump a copy after you watch it.Sincerely,Mary NortonFlagstaff, AZ 86005

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I feel that Dayton Duncan has captured the essence of our National Parks and Monuments best when he said:"I think the parks are a gift in many ways. They are a gift of nature to us, to this nation that was blessed with this land. They are part of who we are as Americans. We're the people who wrote the Declaration of Independence, but we're also the people who went out and inhabited - and in a way tried to conquer - this land, this gift and blessing that was bestowed upon us. The parks are part of that, they represent what was here. They represent the potentiality of what the land was like when we, as a nation, first set out.The fact that we have set these places aside and we're keeping them special means that the boundary protecting this land is this idea that it is special. I like to think that the park idea is basically the Declaration of Independence overlaid onto this land that we inhabit. In other places they set those special places aside for the very richest in their society or for people who were of the nobility. But as Americans, we rejected that, determining that this land belongs to everyone. I think that deep down, Americans realize that, that this is not just a birthright - it is a great gift and it's also a great responsibility.We pass on our nation's concept of liberty to the next generation - the same thing is true of a park. It's there for us to enjoy, but it's for everyone to enjoy for all time. These are spectacular places. You don't have to be sentimental about the Declaration of Independence, as I am, to go to a place like Glacier National Park and be awed by what you see.The creation of a park establishes that sense of a special place. When you enter a park - you think differently. You pause and it takes you a little bit out of the rush of time and I think that is why so many families take their kids back and why those kids will take their kids back because it encapsulates an imperishable moment that you experience as a child. Then you can see that experience once again through your child's experience. There are very few things that pass across generations and across time the way that does. That's what makes it so special."Mr. Zinke, I appeal to you to visit any of our National Parks or Monuments to experience how they move your soul.If you want to broaden your knowledge and awareness of what the National Parks have meant historically, giving context to what they mean now, I encourage you to watch "Ken Burns: The National Parks - America's Best Idea", which you can currently watch on Amazon Prime.Thank you very much for your time and consideration!Jeff ValderNational Park enthusiast & REI MemberLincoln, NebraskaSincerely,Jeff ValderLincoln, NE 68510

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I have such happy childhood memories of roving Craters of the Moon, the heat off the black rock. I learned to backpack in the Escalante with deep silence of wilderness and a black velvet night sky. These opportunities must be preserved for the next generations, now, more than ever. Please act boldly and protect our lands.Sincerely,Karen JohnstonLakewood, WA 98498

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I have unfortunately not had the pleasure of much travel in my life. Even at almost 40, I have barely been beyond the few states surrounding my home state of Illinois. But that doesn't mean that I don't yearn to travel, and top on my priority list of "someday" destinations are the National Monuments. I believe that these were designated as such for a reason, and they belong to the people. I would hate for any of them to be stripped of their appellation and be allowed to fall into private hands that may want to destroy them. Please, please deny the request to drop these lands from the illustrious list designated as National Monuments. Preserve them so that I, along with my children and grandchildren for generations to come, will be able to enjoy them along with countless others. Thank you.Sincerely,Rachel HeckOrangeville, IL 61060
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I learned to love the great outdoors as a child and I'm now nearing 60. Please save our public lands and monuments safe!Sincerely,Mark KnightWayne, PA 19087

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I love our nations National Parks and monuments! I've visited more than I can remember, and just crossed off Rocky Mountain National Park last month. I see absolutely no good reason to reduce any of the land that has already been designated for such a great cause. There's plenty of places to turn a profit in this great country of ours without needing to cut into the land/airspace we've already designated as off limits. Please support our environment and keep all the land currently designated as National Parks or Monuments as is. Thank you.Sincerely,Joy PenneyFort Knox, KY 40121

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I not only make my living in the outdoor industry, I make my life there too. I believe access to places without roads, or electricity, or cell phone reception are a necessity for human kind- urban who need a dose of fresh air/perspective, rural and native who need the labs for continued prosperity. I believe protection of these monuments are paramount and necessary at the federal level.I live in the west now but grew up in rural Iowa. I do not believe this is a partisan issue. These monuments provide immeasurable value across our culture, economy, and planet.I'd like to mention some monuments in particular that I believe need extra care and protection:Bears EarsGrand Staircase - EscalanteCascade SiskiyouKatahadin WoodsGold ButteBasin and RangeThank you for stewarding the future of the lands. For all.Sincerely,Ashlee LangholzSeattle, WA 98119

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I personally believe that national monuments, parks, and forests make this country what it is. By removing, shrinking, or negatively impacting any national monument in ANY way, you personally assault this nation, its people, and its allies by reducing its worth, removing chance for the pursuit of happiness, and personally attacking anyone who values these EXISTING monuments created by any of your predecessors and all who believed their predecessors were correct.Sincerely,John BeaufortSalt Lake City, UT 84103

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I personally love all of our national parks, forests, and monuments. The outdoors is my home away from home. It's where I feel the most happy. It gives me an opportunity to relax that nothing else gives me. Taking away millions of acres of national parks, forests, and lands would take away my home away from home and the places that make me happy. It would take away places to hike, climb, bike, and run. It would take away part of the outdoor playground that millions of people dearly love. We've had monuments put up since 1996. Don't undo all the hard work previous presidents have accomplished.Sincerely,Haley MuellerPoway, CA 92064

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I recently finished an 18 month journey in a motorhome to relocate in New Mexico. As an East Coast resident for the first 60 years of my life, my visits to the national treasures of parks and monuments were pretty much limited to those near that coast. The odyssey of traveling the country for the last year and a half opened up a whole new appreciation of the beauty this country has to offer with the lands preserved through foresight and determination of our past presidents and legislators. Being a part of a buffalo "parade" in Yellowstone, cycling beneath the towering peaks of the Tetons, and wondering at the lives ancient ancestors lived and recorded with petroglyphs at so many sites in the southwest are memories I often revisit. They remind me of how precious our public lands are for every American. Seek the long vision and maintain their sacred beauty for the present and the future.Sincerely,Fay StevingSanta Fe, NM 87508

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I spent one summer of my youth in Yosemite and had the time of my life running around and hiding in giant sequoias. One of the parcels of land you are reviewing is Sequoia National Monument- please do not endanger these gentle giants. They deserve protection from the infestation of humanity and so does every other national park.Sincerely,Melissa MearesMorganton, NC 28655

While serving in the US Air Force at Holloman AFB, NM, I visited many National Parks and Monuments throughout the southwest. One of the most recently designated monuments, Organ Mountains in southern New Mexico, was not far from where I lived, and I am so glad that this spectacular landscape is getting the protection it deserves. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I'm writing strongly in support of protecting these vital national monuments. Areas like Papahanaumokuakea, Pacific Remote Islands, Rose Atoll, Marianas Trench, and Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monuments are increasingly important in light of ongoing climate change, ocean acidification, sea level rise, and chemical and plastics pollution. Maintaining and expanding these protected areas will allow our oceans to adapt to change in the strongest way possible.While like most Americans I have never dived in any of these remote and hard to access areas, I have spent many hours snorkeling, kayaking, and whale watching in adjacent waters. I'm from New England, and protection for Northeast Canyons will help our commercial fisheries and marine mammal populations rebound. Conserving these species and the local seafood and whale watching industries, is a high priority for our regional and local New England economy. Protected areas provide additional resilience to surrounding waters and the communities that depend on these resourcesHaving worked at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, I was privileged to learn about and visit many coral reefs close to shore. While still beautiful and valuable, these inshore reefs are heavily impacted by human use, pollution, and bleaching events. Protecting more remote and resilient places like Papahanaumokuakea will help us ensure that there are sources for recolonizing corals, fish, and other organisms following coral die offs or other localized events.Rolling back protections on any one of these monuments is indeed a step backwards when it is most important that we do MORE. As an ecologist I am trained to study and respect both the resilience and fragility of our natural systems. Places like our National Parks, National Wildlife Refuges, and National Monuments are there to sustain America's cultural and scientific legacy; most of us will never get to visit the ocean National Monuments, but they are an irreplaceable treasure.President Trump is setting a dangerous precedent by trying to nullify the protection of these vital monuments. The Antiquities Act, signed by President Theodore Roosevelt in 1906, safeguards and preserves U.S. public lands and waters that contain objects of historic or scientific interest. Sixteen past presidents - eight Republicans and eight Democrats - have used this authority to designate over 150 monuments, thereby preserving our special places at sea and on land for future generations of Americans. There is strong support among members of the American public to maintain fisheries and protect crucial wildlife habitat. Our diverse U.S. marine monuments protect a rich array of ocean species and their habitats, provide nursery and spawning habitats for commercially-valuable fish and crustacean populations, and offer sought-after recreational angling opportunities. Deep-sea ecosystems in the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts are home to sperm whales, Atlantic puffins, and lush deep sea coral gardens, including one of the planet's oldest organisms, black corals, and other species that may contain chemical compounds of biomedical importance. The expansion of Papahnaumokukea prevents sharks, sea turtles, sea birds, and marine mammals from being caught by longline fishing and helps safeguard the traditional culture of the Native Hawaiian community. All of these organisms as well as the marine-based ways of life are constantly threatened by human actions. If America doesn't do its part in protecting these special places, we are failing as a country and as citizens and stewards of our planet.Please consider my voice, as a consumer, a tourist, a wildlife watcher, and a scientist. Most Americans stand behind protection of these national monuments and their counterparts on land. Please do not alter or eliminate any of the protections for the marine national monuments.Please accept this letter as an official public comment for Docket No. DOI-2017-0002.Sincerely,Kelly OmandNantucket, MA 02554

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I'm writing to you as a small business owner to ask that you protect public lands and national monuments. My business hosts wilderness medicine courses throughout Arizona and the Southwest. My students are park rangers, guides, and outdoor enthusiasts. Like many businesses in the outdoor recreation industry, it's critical that America's system of public lands, national parks, and national monuments be preserved.I understand that you are receiving significant pressure from representatives of the oil and gas industry to 'free up' public lands for economic development. As you know, however, outdoor recreation contributes more to the American economy than extractive industries. If you're trying to make the right decision economically, then the answer is clear -- the outdoor recreation industry and it's minimal impacts will contribute more to the economy in both the short and long run.I also understand that you are receiving significant pressure from 'local interests' regarding our public lands. Flagstaff is completely surrounded by public lands, and I certainly want to be involved in the decision-making in our area -- I don't begrudge locals for wanting to have input. Ultimately, however, the land belongs to all Americans and not just the locals. While local input is important, it should not outweigh the interests of the vast majority of Americans that support the conservation of public lands.Instead, in the case of monuments, locals should be educated on the massive, positive economic impact of national monuments. For example, on the edge of the new Bears Ears National Monument, the community of Blanding has experienced stagnant economic 'growth' for decades while communities outside the well-established Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument have experienced huge economic growth. The small population of Blanding may not understand or appreciate the experience of other Utahns that have benefited from monuments. The Bears Ears region is incredible, and the local communities will benefit from the increased tourist traffic that results from its designation as a monument.America's public lands are the envy of the world. Why would you endanger these lands to decrease the economic benefit? Rescinding or reducing the size of monuments and selling off our public lands would clearly be a poor decision for the nation and would ensure that your reputation would be impugned in American history books for all time.Please preserve Bears Ears and our other national monuments in their current states and work to protect our other public lands.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I've explored many of our national parks. The Superior National Forest is my backyard. Our wilderness needs to stay wild. Protect it.Sincerely,Yvonne BlockGrand Marais, MN 55604
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,If you kill the trees you are a bad person.Sincerely,Mary Ushay81567

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,In our national parks I found my love of the outdoors and my love for our country. Nowhere else on Earth do we have such a vast and varied array of different climates, forests, and rock formations all under the stewardship of one country. We should continue to celebrate this crowning jewel of American identity and pride by keeping public lands public and by respecting the allocation of that land by all of the brave leaders that struggled to make our country what it is today. I am proud to be an American because we value the land we have struggled to survive on. Please fight to keep the small portion of public lands open to the public so that many other generations of Americans can experience that feeling of true patriotism and national pride.From a fellow Montanian, please preserve our national monuments, our national parks, our national forests and all of our other public spaces.Sincerely,Catherine PottsBelgrade, MT 59714

Protect our national monuments.Sincerely,Glynis MccorkleHaymarket, VA 20169

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,It would be a tragedy to repeal the Bears Ears national monument designation. The decision to protect this land was made with the utmostcare and consideration and is done to protect this priceless land for generations to come. I have personally spent many weeks in this wildness area both on land and on the San Juan river. I learned an appreciation for the outdoors and how fragile they are. Please protect this wilderness area for my kids and there kids so they to can experience its grandeur.Sincerely,Ryan McGradyEnglewood, CO 80112

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Last year I had the chance to visit many parks in the Midwest for the first time in my life. But because it helped bring my family so much more closer than what we are already, we got to experience the majesty of its beauty was together. I asked tourists there what brought them here and various were from out of the country and they all had one common answer: the parks of America is what makes this country truly beautiful. I took a step back and realized how lucky we are to have access to these beautiful resources. Not only do they attract tourism and get people to go outside but it also brings people together or help them find themselves in a moment of solitude. Let's not destroy the parks and lands but rather embrace their majesty, not for the sake of giving in to the numerous companies seeking to build their new buildings but because it's what makes our country a true beauty.Sincerely,Yerko MedinaManassas, VA 20111

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Living in Seattle, I'm very lucky to have so many national treasures near me. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,My family has made many wonderful memories enjoying the public lands in our country. I'm writing to express my hope that you will use your position to safeguard these lands in their natural state rather than open them up for private enterprises, including extracting natural resources and building developments.Environmentally speaking, I believe it is important to maintain the protections on these public lands, but there are many more reasons as well! The opportunities for outdoor recreation that these lands offer benefit the people (and visitors) in our country in many ways, including: physical recreation, mental and physical well being, as well as outdoor-industry related jobs and revenue (tour guides, gear sales, food and lodging, etc). Having access to public lands both near and far can make a difference when it comes to the inter and intrapersonal benefits derived from annual family camping trips, to a day of rock-climbing to release stress from work. Having healthy people, mentally and physically, will serve our country and world well.Please protect the public lands.Sincerely,Joylani ShibataFremont, CA 94536

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,My family live near the San Gabriel Mountains. And by "near" I mean that the mountains are in our backyard. Their worth cannot and should not be measured in coin. We spend every weekend and multiple weekdays wandering the trails and pure wilderness. We grew up on them. We are raising children of our own on them. My parents are growing old but staying physically and mentally fit on them. These mountains just like all of our national monuments and national parks are priceless. In this time where we so often price things by the dollar, I humbly ask you to consider the worth of these majestic spaces to our communities and to our grandchildren.Sincerely,Theresa ChengLos Angeles, CA 90066

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,My husband and I moved to the PNW 5 years ago and we have made it our home. We love to hang out in Seattle, drink great beer and wine and enjoy the outdoors. But, I am concerned that one day our future kids won't have the same opportunities as we have right now. Growing up, our family vacations were always to a national/state park to camp. We loved the outdoors! And it provided an inexpensive family vacation option as to not put a financial burden on my parents. With this administration trying to remove the rights of my future kids just so a small amount of people can have dying jobs is a real tragity. We need to take care of our planet and protect what we can. I'm only 26 and have seen many wonders that are in the US. But, it saddens me to think my kids will never get the chance to experience the awe of the PNW. There is always another way. It may not be the easiest way and it may take some thinking and collaboration, but it can be done and needs to be done. We need to keep the parks 100% protected.Sincerely,Lauren BoedekerSeattle, WA 98117

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,My wife and I ride mountain bikes to explore and to stay healthy. It is time finally allow mountain bikers access to the wilderness. Bikes were wrongfully lumped in with motorized vehicles. They do less harm than horses do on trails and are extremely low impact. Bikes are one of the most efficient was to explore backcountry.Please update the wilderness act to allow bikes.Sincerely,Zach BryanRio Rancho, NM 87144

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,National parks have been preserved for us by our parents, and we're preserving them for our kids. Selling them off to the highest bidder is like taking the only park in town and making a parking lot out if it. Is that what you want for your kids and grandkids? I'm not so sure they would be proud of you with that legacy...Sincerely,Alice GarofaloPuyallup, WA 98372

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,One of the joys of my life has been sharing our national public lands -- National Parks, National Monuments, National Forests -- with our children.As a citizen of the United States, I had assumed that our childrens' children, and their children, and their children would be able to have the same experience.So it is with great concern that I read of the potential for diminishing this heritage, with the Bear Ears National Monument a prime example.I urge you, and your team, to be stewards of that future, not diminishers of it!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,One of the main reason I live in Utah is because of the many outdoor opportunities that surround me. I am a dad who takes my family on several outdoor activities a year. My inlaws built a cabin in Utah because of the many National & State parks here. They entertain several very powerful & influential people from all over the world at the cabin not to mention most importantly gathering our family together several times a year. I am also a Boy Scout Leader & take my scouts camping every month. In our age of all things digital I'm doing all I can to get the boys to unplug for a couple days & experience life someplace other than cyberspace. As an American & a Republican I strongly encourage the leaders our our Nation to protect our public lands. I want my tax dollars to support State & National Parks & I do not want them to vanish! I personally invite you to come to Utah & I will take time off of work & will show you first hand why Utah & other states with public land needs to be protected.Sincerely,Steve NicholsSouth Jordan, UT 84009

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Other countries around the world followed in our footsteps, as we were one of the first to realize the importances of protecting our natural treasures. Once they are gone, they are gone.Sincerely,Joseph SimonPittsfield, MA 01201

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our amazing system of national parks and monuments is what makes America great. Some of my best memories as a child involved visiting national parks and monuments of the West with my family, getting to bond with my parents while being introduced to the incredible treasures that are our deserts, mountains, and streams. These experiences influenced my decision to become an environmental scientist, and I cannot wait to visit these wild places with my own children in the near future.We cannot let short-term desire for profit or extraction of natural resources get in the way of preserving one-of-a-kind landscapes like Grand Staircase Escalante and Bears Ears. These ecosystems evolve slowly and are fragile, such that any ecological or geological harm we do now may take centuries to repair . We owe it to our grandchildren and the generations to come to preserve these natural treasures for all Americans.Sincerely,Samantha R. WeintraubBoulder, ColoradoSincerely,Samantha WeintraubBoulder, CO 80304

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today.AMERICAN SAMOARose AtollARIZONAGrand Canyon - ParashantIronwood ForestVermillion CliffsSonoran DesertCALIFORNIAGiant SequoiaCarrizo PlainCascade-SiskiyouSan Gabriel MountainsBerryessa Snow MountainMojave TrailsSand to SnowCOLORADOCanyons of the AncientsHAWAIIPapahnaumokukeaIDAHOCraters of the MoonMAINEKatahdin Woods & WatersMONTANAUpper Missouri River BreaksNEW ENGLANDNortheast Canyons and SeamountsNEW MEXICORio Grande del NorteOrgan Mountains-Desert PeaksNEVADABasin and RangeGold ButteOREGONCascade-SiskiyouPACIFIC OCEANMarianas TrenchPacific Remote IslandsUTAHGrand Staircase-EscalanteBears EarsWASHINGTONHanford ReachSincerely,Rhyanna DeTuathanaTangent, OR 97389

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history.Sending a signal that protections for our shared history, culture, and natural treasures are temporary would set a terrible precedent. National monuments have been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities.From Maine's magnificent Katahdin Woods to the colorful canyons of Utah's Grand Staircase-Escalante to the western history held in New Mexico's Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, these landmarks, landscapes, and seascapes have value which far exceeds their physical features; they manifest the core democratic ideals of freedom, justice, and equality. They are our legacy to our children and our children's children, and a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for our national monuments. I urge you to support the following list of National Monuments and recommend that our current national monuments remain as they are today. Are you willing to die for what you believe is right? There are many Americans that are. More than you can imagine. These monuments and lands are sacred to Americans and Native Americans. No extraction company business is worth the loss of American lives for quick profits.AMERICAN SAMOARose AtollARIZONAGrand Canyon - ParashantIronwood ForestVermillion CliffsSonoran DesertCALIFORNIAGiant SequoiaCarrizo PlainCascade-SiskiyouSan Gabriel MountainsBerryessa Snow MountainMojave TrailsSand to SnowCOLORADOCanyons of the AncientsHAWAIIPapahnaumokukeaIDAHOCraters of the MoonMAINEKatahdin Woods & WatersMONTANAUpper Missouri River BreaksNEW ENGLANDNortheast Canyons and SeamountsNEW MEXICORio Grande del NorteOrgan Mountains-Desert PeaksNEVADABasin and RangeGold ButteOREGONCascade-SiskiyouPACIFIC OCEANMarianas TrenchPacific Remote IslandsUTAHGrand Staircase-EscalanteBears EarsWASHINGTONHanford ReachSincerely,Larry CowdenGilboa, NY 12076

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our National Monuments are a critical part of this country's history and future. People come from all over the world to see them. They bring tourists and visitors to states they might otherwise not have visited. Our public lands are a gem of this country - please work to preserve them. No National Monument should be eliminated, we should not allow drilling for oil in or near any of them, and they should continue to be preserved.Sincerely,Ariane LaxoSaint Paul, MN 55106

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national monuments are an important part of our history and one that needs to be preserved. I have not yet been able to venture out to see them, but I am currently planning a trip to Utah to visit national parks and monuments alike. In planning, I have been overwhelmed by how unbelievable and beautiful these sites are. I ecstatic to see them in person. And I hope To be able to tell my children about it and then bring them to see them and let them feel that same sense of just how grand and mysterious this world is. I understand that there is always a budget and a bottom line, but please do not take experiences like the one I have coming up away from people. Don't let financial matters take away that feeling of awe.Sincerely,Elizabeth CaseDowningtown, PA 19335

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national monuments are irreplaceable, and are of timeless value to our country. Once gone there's bringing them back. Please do the right thing and help protect Bears Ears National Monument-Kyle Lancaster

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national parks & monuments have been protected for a reason. What good is all the money in the world if we have nothing beautiful left to enjoy? Please don't let corporate development interests destroy these lands. Listen to the voice of the people!Sincerely,Elizabeth KaiserShingle Springs, CA 95682

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national parks and monuments are known as America's Best Idea.There is nothing more central to the idea of being an American for me than the need to preserve our precious monuments, parks, and other special places in America.These places, like similar places in other countries, define the uniqueness of America. America is known by its iconic National Parks; places like Grand Canyon, Yosemite, Smoky Mountains, and Mt. Rainier, and they are protected and cherished places for generations to enjoy and experience. Millions of visitors from other countries come to these places to experience the essence of America's natural beauty, and relive the experience of the peoples who first laid eyes on and traveled through these wonders.But monuments like Bears Ears, John Day Fossil Beds, California Coastal, Devils Tower, San Juan Islands, and dozens others are unique and special places that must be protected and cherished, too, so they are not lost to development and commercial exploitation. If ever left unprotected, National Monuments will be lost to future generations, only experienced through photographs, memories, and stories.Please hold strong to our commitment to set aside and protect National Monuments. Resist the temptation to turn these sites over to development, as once they are exploited, they will be lost forever.Sincerely,Shelby PothierSeattle, WA 98133

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our national parks and monuments frame our great land and history from sea to sea and border to border. They tell a story of a people with great ambition and hope for future generations of Americans and visitors from beyond. The integrity of our parks and monuments must remain for our own enjoyment and pride as well as our future generations to come.I think its always good to review past decisions to understand viability in face of current times. But I want to impress upon you the significance that our investment in our parks have upon the pride that is truly felt to be an American.As Winston Churchill was asked to cut arts funding to support the war effort, he replied: "Then what are we fighting for?"Indeed, our parks represent the importance of preservation of these wonderful spaces not only for the natural beauty and national historical significance, but for our own sense of what and where home is.Sincerely,craig brewerTacoma, WA 98422

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our Public Lands are too important to play games with. I have found myself and true inner peace in our National Parks and forests, and hope that you, as a Montanan, recognize just how important they are to everyone. Please don't take them away.Sincerely,Wyatt RyderDenver, CO 80210

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy, which belongs not only to us, but also to all future Americans. These are the wild places we lovewhere we run, hike, camp, ski, fish, climb and spend important time with our friends and families.Once lost these national treasures can never be regained.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to the U.S. people. I personally have very fond memories from my many hikes, bike rides, horse back rides and all other activities I have been apart of in public land areas.I have utilized National Parks, forests, and lands. It would be a shame and a disgrace if they are destroyed and not protected. We as a country do not have enoug outdoor time and places as it is. Please help preserve the land we do have.Sincerely,Aim'ee HendersonStockton, IL 61085

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands should stay public for everyone in America now and for future generations. It's important that we protect our wild places from industrialization and that we protect all the animals and plants that live there as well. Especially as we continue to burn fossil fuels and increase global warming.Sincerely,Mike JuarezPhoenix, AZ 85015

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Over the years, people on both sides of the aisle have agreed that there are some great spots in America that make it great. These are places that can't be replicated, can't be recovered after they are gone. One misplaced decision will ruin them forever - and for future generations of our children that are unable to make their decision heard now. Hiking in a National Monument or National Park, such as Craters of the Moon in Idaho, reminds us of why America is so blessed. We have natural formations and destinations that most countries could only DREAM of. These are not natural formations for us to just destroy because we can. They are treasures to be protected because WE CAN! Please do not make a decision that can't be reversed to release these precious spots of nature. It's an act that will have long lasting consequences, hence the reason so many before you have taken the time and energy to protect them over the decades.Sincerely,Kim ButtonJupiter, FL 33458

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please consider the many generations of the future and our nation, and not the immediate opportunity of finite resources, when you consider Bears Ears National Monumnet. We need this land protected, and we need to safeguard it from individuals like Donald Trump who regard this land as simply something to be pillaged for profit.Thank you.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please do not degrade our nation's monuments. These lands must continue to remain pristine and protected from business interests and other environmental threats.Sincerely,Armin AhmadiSan Diego, CA 92117

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please do not destroy these national parks. This so where young children learn about our environment and nature. There are so many animals that call these places home. Think of our ecosystem.I have been going to these parks since I was a child. My husband and I love these parks so much that we eloped at Rocky Mountain National Park.Please do what you can to save these parks.Sincerely,Heather WhitakerBoulder, CO 80302

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please do not downsize or remove any of our National Monuments. As a former resident of Utah, I know how hard many groups, including several Native American tribes worked to ensure the preservation of culturally significant areas. Do not reduce or remove Bears Ears, just because the politicians don't like it. Additionally, I am also a huge fan of the Giant Sequoias and most folks have never seen trees like this. They can only grow in a few select environments and as such, we can't replicate this in other parts of the US. This needs to be preserved as there are so few areas meeting the significance requirement. I love our public lands and as the US becomes more populated and more connected, our public lands provide us the opportunity to reconnect with nature and the more areas we have to do that, the better for us and our future generations.Sincerely,Roberta CavinessWoodstock, MD 21163

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please do not reduce public lands! We depend on these public spaces for retreat and rejuvenation.
