Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please leave all national monuments intact and secure their protection for future generations. The last thing we need is more mining or drilling. If anything, we need more protected land. Not less. Don't bow down to the oil and gas lobbyists.My husband and I spend most of our vacations exploring lands managed by the National Park Service. I proudly stamp my National Park Passport at each Park and Monument we visit. We've spent quite a bit of time traveling abroad as well, but nothing compares to America's Public lands.The national monuments allow us to escape the crowds of their more well known National Park counterparts while still explore equally unique and beautiful areas of our country. I don't like to play favorites, but, so far, White Sands might be my favorite National monument that I've visited. Our friends were amazed by our photos of the large dunes and we've even inspired some of them to take their own road trips through New Mexico.I'm looking forward to taking our one year old daughter on road trips through these public lands. Yet, I fear she may not have the opportunity given the attacks from the current Administration.Protect our national monuments. This land is our land.Ashley WhitleySincerely,Ashley WhitleyTampa, FL 33629

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please protect our public lands and the land sacred to those who have been so mistreated in the past. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please save our public lands for future generations!As a resident of Idaho, I'm am surrounded by some of the most beautiful places in the country. One spot close to home is Craters of the Moon National Monument. I love visiting at different times of the year, seeing the wild flowers in bloom peaking through the crevices in the spring, or the snow, smoothing the rough surface in the winter.The visitor center is a great place to learn about the evolution of our state.This is just one example.Please think about how important it is to save these places for all of our children!Sincerely,Sara JensenIdaho Falls, ID 83401

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please take into account the voices of the people that actually live near these monuments, since these people are the ones whose livelihoods are directly impacted. National Monuments are not the only way to protect public lands and in many cases are not the best way. Most of my favorite recreational sites are Wilderness Areas and I would fight tooth and nail to prevent them from becoming national monuments. I know there are others who feel the same in regards to other types of public land, whether it be National Forest, BLM, etc... Some of these National Monuments are ridiculously huge and could probably be shrunk without any negative impacts to the land. Just please listen more to the local people and the users of the land rather than thousands of people who had never even heard of these areas until it became the cool thing to do to post stuff on social media about how much they care.Sincerely,Brian BassLayton, UT 84041

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Please, please, please help protect our public lands. These are our sacred places. Our playgrounds. Our natural wonders of the world. They are monuments that took sometimes centuries and millennia to build but can be undone in a fraction of that time. I have been very fortunate to spend time in some of these places and the sense of wonder, astonishment and belonging that they have given me are something I hope everyone can experience.Sometimes we only get once chance to do the right thing in life so I beg you to please to not take this issue lightly. The longterm benefits of protecting public lands far outweigh the temporary gains of opening them to development.Thanks for your time.Sincerely,Joseph PasterisSeattle, WA 98105

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. It is important to make every effort to protect those special places worthy of national monument status for our children and grandchildren and future generations.Ranchers and oil company executives comprise a small minority in this country. They too have a right to make a living but haven't we already leased out enough public land for private interests? I think so and I hope you will agree and keep Bears Ears as it is. Thank you sir.

Dear secretary Ryan Zinke,Protecting our national monuments is of critical concern today. These natural places have values that are extremely challenging to understand and therefore it can seem better to remove these places from the national monument designations. These monuments however protect ways of life for thousands of people who rely on the natural goods and services provided by these protected lands. In addition lands such as bears ears national monument has immense cultural value that is greater than the monetary value that can be extracted. Rather than going to war with our public lands we should look for ways to support our public lands and improve the lives of individuals and communities near these lands. It is not an either or proposition but something that those seeking economic development as well as those seeking conservation goals can work together on. Therefore, I am hoping that you will not rescind or reduce the size of the most recently designated national monuments. That move would certainly by a step back and we in America should always look on how to improve our communities and our country. Protecting these monuments is a start.I hope you do the right thing.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public land/monuments is the crown jewel of America. It's what separates us from many European countries and classes. We the people have the privilege to use public land for hiking, camping, hunting, mountain biking and numerous other activities as diverse as America itself. My wife and I are planning on spending two weeks in South Dakota this fall exploring our public lands and national monuments. These should never be privatized or abandoned. Growing up in the shadows of the Great Smokey Mountains I can't tell you how many hours I've spent as both a child and later as an adult exploring all the wonders of the Great Smokey Mountain National Park. Please protect and preserve these national treasures.Sincerely,Tim MossJasper, GA 30143

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public lands are an amazing resource for the American people. Studies show less stress in people when exposed to the outdoors. In our stressful busy lives these spaces are more essential than ever. Living in Atlanta we have mini parks dotting the city. I for one cherished the moments I could take a short walk to one of these parks after work and feel like I was no longer in the concrete jungle. My nephew has been diagnosed with ADD and is on the aspergers spectrum has marked differences in behavior after spending time in our national parks and forests. Please keep protect our public lands for us all.Sincerely,David TanMarietta, GA 30062
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public lands are important !Sincerely,Dylan CongerBelgrade, MT 59714

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public lands belong to all of us. If their protection is removed, we lose them forever. They are then not only stolen from us, but also from our children and grandchildren.Sincerely,John EichenbergerGeneva, NY 14456

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public lands have played an important part in my life - camping, hiking, and enjoying the outdoors with my family over the years has been invaluable to me. We are lucky to have the unspoiled beauty of places like Bears Ears and the San Gabriel Mountains, and I hope that my newborn daughter is able to enjoy them the way I have throughout my life. Please don't destroy our public lands.Sincerely,Jennifer SorrowSan Francisco, CA 94121
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Raise our taxes, do what you must, but don't revoke National Monument status for these national treasures.Sincerely,Scot OrrissSeattle, WA 98122

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Secretary Zinke,I hope that in your capacity as Secretary of the Interior, you leave a legacy that keep ALL of our public lands federally protected. I am a hiker, backpacker, trail runner, and overall outdoor enthusiast. When I need a break from my life as a harried scientist, I escape to lands that our former presidents have protected for us all and for those that come after us. Every president has increased this legacy of wild lands, and yet the areas of undeveloped land are still minuscule in contrast to the rest of the developed world. I have met people from France backpacking here in the US because their leaders were not as thoughtful and considerate of the future as ours have been. As a vegan and a liberal, I have come to respect and enjoy the company of hunters and conservatives in these settings. There are very few topics that such differing viewpoints as these can come together and share a passion and unite in spite of our differences. Protect bear's Ears, protect my home, the Sonoran Desert, protect Escalante Staircase . . . protect every single one as our past leaders have done. Once this land is turned over to states, they WILL drill and develop. Sometimes we need our federal government to step up and protect the greater good and the future.It is up to you. Will your legacy be beautiful sacred lands, or will you leave us a wasteland?Thank you for your time and consideration,Katrina M RodriguezSincerely,Katrina RodriguezBaltimore, MD 21218

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Since President Trump seems to prefer a direct message, that is how I will begin. Keep you hands off of our National Monuments and National Parks! The United States system of national monuments and parks is the envy of and a model for most of the world. This system preserves for future generations areas with special ecological, cultural, historic, and/or aesthetic features.I have had the opportunity to visit these areas throughout America, and I want others to have the same option. These sites include (but are not limited to) Mount Rainier National Park, Craters of the Moon National Monument, Bandelier National Monument, Cedar Breaks National Monument, Devils Tower National Monument, Dinosaur National Monument, Jewel Cave National Monument, Arches and Canyonlands National Parks, John Day Fossil Beds National Monument, Mount St. Helens National Monument, Newberry National Monument, Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks, Oregon Caves National Monument, Statue of Liberty National Monument, Walnut Canyon National Monument, and Wupatki National Monument. Despite the length of this list, there are still more monuments and parks to see, and I want the opportunity to do so. Every site that I have visited has been a special place, and I am confident that those I have yet to visit are no different. In fact, just writing this message has brought back many wonderful memories.The establishment of the National Monument system has been a bipartisan accomplishment. These monuments have been supported by the majority of American citizens. These lands are a crucial piece of outdoor recreation and an economic engine for local areas. They are an economic resource that will last for the future - unlike extractive industries that mine or drill and then run! Those who would destroy the monuments will only achieve the destruction of their own reputations. The wisest course of action for the current administration is to leave the system alone. If the current administration feels that the creation of National Monuments, whether by legislative action or by Executive Order, is not the right thing; the answer seems obvious to me - do not create any new monuments. However, this does not mean trying to undo the achievements of others.Thank you.Sincerely,Laurence WeinbergBend, OR 97701

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Tell the Department of the Interior why you love Bears Ears and want it to remain protected. Your comment will be delivered to regulations.gov.As an avid and active outdoor enthusiast, I love our National Monuments and want to see them to be continually protected!I've been climbing for 13 years and having access to public lands where I can enjoy my personal passion is incredibly important to me.Please protect and prey the integrity of The Antiquities Act!Outdoor enthusiasts, like myself, need National Monuments and public lands protected, please!!Sincerely,Chris FinchSebastopol, CA 95472

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Tell the Department of the Interior why you love Bears Ears and want it to remain protected. Your comment will be delivered to regulations.gov.Sincerely,Lindy StephensSouth Jordan, UT 84095

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Tell the Department of the Interior why you love Bears Ears and want it to remain protected. Your comment will be delivered to regulations.gov.Sincerely,Shannon McfarlandSomerville, MA 02144

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Thank you for all you do and have done for our nation. I can't imagine how it is to weigh all perspectives to ultimately represent our nation's inhabitants.As all things can be made controversial, ultimately, it is clear what the right thing to do is for many issues. In this case, the issue I write to you is regarding the Bears Ears National Monument.Please keep this monument as is or expand as possible and necessary because it serves to preserve our nation's history and environment, meanwhile honoring the Native Americans who cherish the area. Some say that some American Indians don't even know of this land, and that is exactly the problem. The conquering mindset of the US is at fault. History and legacy of the original inhabitants of this land haven't been preserved.If the land that Bears Ears sits on is needed for extraction of natural resources, we do not need more land for natural resources. We already have enough resources extracted from the land that we can make do with what we all have. People need to be more innovative and find ways to reduce consumption and recycle others more efficiently. I do not know why people hold on to such old ways of raping the earth as mining and drilling for oil. We live in the 21st century and haven't we learned from our predecessors. We have the capacity to move towards a cleaner and more innovative future. Right now, the majority of our nation is filled with lazy people that are enslaved to old ways. We do not need more roads, more drilling, more mining, or more farmland. Instead, improve what we have. Consume less, and be healthy by eating less. Fix our crumbling infrastructure and preserve the land that we have for the public. We have freedom to do what we want, but people will always need inspiration from leadership.As for local control of land, there is not enough money, transparency, and other necessary resources in local governments to maintain and preserve sacred, historical, and picturesque land. The land does not belong to the people who live there alone but to all.We need more public land for your generation, my generation and the generation of the future. I am a 30 year old engineer who will not have children but I plan to adopt and mentor children who do not have parents. Thus I do not think of my own offspring but rather of the future and historical preservation of others. Once you think of only yourself and your family, then you are headed down a very selfish and dangerous path.Please, please, please PRESERVE Bears Ears Monument.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Thank you for serving our country. Please do not take away our public lands or national monuments. My family and I have enjoyed many hours in parks, and learned to love nature and appreciate God's creation. As I get older, it is important to me that my grown children and grandchildren have the same opportunities I had when raising my children. It is a heritage we all can leave to our future generations.Sincerely,Karen PierceRenton, WA 98059

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Thank you for your service to our country. As a life long Republican and supporter of a market driven economy and believer in smaller government, I am writing to implore you to protect our National Monuments and Federal Lands. These really are a national treasure and must be protected and maintained. Some things, simply because of what they are, are more than a means of revenue or a tool of capitalism. Our public lands represent the great diversity of this nation. It is in these places where people can get outside of themselves and leave the mundane and the business of life behind. That is something that we need more than ever. And lastly, these lands should be protected because we have a God given duty to be good stewards of what he has created for us to care for and enjoy.Sincerely,Richard HoffmanBronxville, NY 10708

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The Bears Ears National Monument designation was the only viable option for protecting this threatened landscape from resource extraction, looting and unmanaged recreation. If you will insist for Bears Ears National Monument, this is part of America's culture of impunity for the rich. To be honest, Donald Trump is not a toddler, he is a product of America's culture of impunity for the rich. So, this is influencing the supporters of Trump administration to become the products of its culture of impunity.Bears Ears National Monument has better resources than resource extraction by outdoor recreation. Outdoor recreation has been growing quickly and bigger than before. Outdoor recreation provides the healthy lifestyle for every human to escape from their reality and earn the natural meditation to develop better acknowledge back in their reality. No questions and no doubts of its benefits from outdoor recreation, Bears Ears is one of the biggest and powerful lands that provides many resources for humans. To compare which is the best economy, outdoor recreation is "underdog" by billions of $$$ than resource extraction. Resource extraction is temporary, outdoor recreation is permanent.Which resources are important for humans; extractions or outdoor recreation?When we will call your decision as important or unimportant, up to you. We still fight back for our beloved U.S. citizens for the best.Sincerely,Jerrod GrillCatonsville, MD 21228

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The Interior Department "is the steward of America's greatest treasures and the manager of one-fifth of our land," Zinke said in a statement. "Part of being a good steward is being a good neighbor and listening to the American people who we represent."As you are quoted above, I am voicing my opinion that these National Monuments not be altered.Sincerely,Erin FarinelliKilleen, TX 76542

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The most amazing moments that I have had in my life have been visiting our national parks and monuments with my friends and family. My children are 2.5 and 1. Please help save Bears Ears, along with all of our National Monuments, National Parks and National Forests so that I can share them with my children like my parents have done before me.Sincerely,Kelly TurnerChicago, IL 60618

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The National Parks are America's best idea. The National Monuments follow on a close second! The US set an example for the world when the first National Park was appointed in 1872. Preserving the natural beauty and important ecosystems for coming generations proved amazing foresight and consideration for the greater public. Since President Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law in 1906, 16 Presidents - 8 Republicans and 8 Democrats - have used the authority granted by the act to safeguard public lands, oceans, and historic sites in order to share America's story with future generations. These national monument designations are broadly supported from coast to coast and provide a myriad of benefits to local communities, including economic boosts from tourism, places to enjoy the outdoors, clean air and water, protection for ecologically sensitive areas, and windows into our country's history. The National Monuments provide such great pleasure and relaxation for countless people in addition to preserving many threatened habitats for animals and plants, for example the giant sequoia forests in Sequoia National Monument or the formerly widespread flower-fields on Carrizo Plain. Developing these amazing places for the very shortsighted profits of few people is contrary to everything the US should stand for.Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our shared historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am concerned that the recent Executive Order attempts to undermine our national monuments and to roll back protections of these public lands. Protected public lands are an important part of what makes America great. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Resources that may be found on Monument land, such as coal, gas, and oil, will eventually dry out and the landscapes changed and destr

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The national parks are treasures and I personally have visited quite a few. Being outside in these parks changes the way we view ourselves and Mother Earth. After having a child, I can't imagine these parks not existing when she gets older. She deserves to have some pristine beautiful land to visit, just like every other person in this country does. There is a reason the parks system was created, and we should not forget it. If not for ourselves, then for the next generation.Sincerely,Ash CampbellAustin, TX 78745

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The public lands are one of the most beautiful and respectable parts of our wonderful country. By showing that we respect and love the natural beauty of our country, we show the rest of the world what a wonderful place the United States continue to be. Without our public lands, we would lose the wildness that makes America, America. Don't take what was given to our future by our past away.Sincerely,Haleigh HoltmanCincinnati, OH 45231

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The public lands need to stay the way they are. People need the public lands to explore and escape from their busy lives. Closing the lands would be a huge mistake.Sincerely,Owenn DomonPhelan, CA 92371

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The wild places of this country cannot be re-created after they've been mined and drilled. These lands are unique and valuable in their present state historically, culturally and environmentally. Please honor the Monument as a permanent sacred spot for all Americans. Not just the extractive industries.As the Montana example of the last decade shows, booms and bust will come and go, but if this land is scarred, that damage cannot be undone when the next bust hits. People realize and the data is conclusive that the long term economic gain of eco tourism far outweighs short term profit for the oil and gas companies.Please keep Bears Ears National Monument intact.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,These lands belong to our children, not corporations. Please do not remove protections!!!Sincerely,Deborah MurrayUnion, NJ 07083

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,These Monuments belong to all Americans, not to private financial groups and developers. We are all watching to see what happens here, but unless we protect our land, there will be no more "America the Beautiful."We're watching!Curt CollierSincerely,Curt CollierStafford, VA 22554

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,These National and State Parks, as well as, Federally protected lands are so important in preserving history, nature, our ecosystems and environment, wildlife and beauty of our Country! Please protect these lands! Thank you for your time!Sincerely,Sarah EricksonCastle Rock, CO 80104

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,These National Monuments are our national treasures and should be protected forever from development and harmful activities like ranching and resource extraction.Management of these lands should not left up to the political winds of individual states, rather, they belong to all Americans and are legacies left to our children. Put aside your partisan perspective and do your job to protect the Nation's parks and monuments for the benefit of us all.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,To whom it may concern:I am deeply disturbed by your decision to review the National Monuments protected lands. Protecting our most precious lands should be a non partisan issue as they are part of our national heritage and once distorted for the gain of a few , they can never be restored to their original featured.The natural world is an important part of our well being as humans. I know for myself, nature keeps me healthy mentally and physically. Please leave the already protected lands intact and continue to be a world leader in the land protection. I know for a fact that the world looks up to us as the leaders in this area and it would be a shame to lose that role.Thank you in advance!SimonaSincerely,Simona LadanWalnut Creek, CA 94598

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,We cannot focus on making money--money will not save humankind. But if we protect and preserve the environment, humans will continue to survive. We need our natural public lands for the greater good. Children of today will never know the true wilderness Theodore Roosevelt worked so hard to preserve if we allow our public lands to be bought and sold. These public places are valuable just as they are. They allow us to explore and understand nature and enjoy physical activity outside in the sun. Please protect and preserve America's few remaining wild spaces by keeping public lands public.Sincerely,Annie Gordon PerkinsWapello, IA 52653
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,We need these lands for our past, present, and future.Sincerely,Jaymie ShearerSan Luis Obispo, CA 93401
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,We need to enlarge and protect our public lands and monuments, not shrink and endanger.Sincerely,Bonnie CunninghamPhoenix, AZ 85044

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,We should be interested in broadening sacred land instead of destroying land we have already spent money to protect for future generations.Sincerely,Andrew HallSwannanoa, NC 28778
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,WHAT WOULD HAYDUKE DO?

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,You have many letters to read, so I will keep this one short. I strongly urge you to consider protecting out national monuments and public lands. These places offer much more to our country than recreation. Removing federal protection from these lands would open them to commercial exploitation, which would only benefit a few Americans. The bottom line is; most Americans are not, and will never be rich. The ability for an American like me to explore our wild places is not taken lightly, and will likely be the only wealth I will ever enjoy.Don't let our country become China! Please continue to protect public lands so that real Americans can enjoy them.Sincerely,Andrew magyarSincerely,Andrew MagyarFarmington, NM 87401

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bear Ears National Monument is a treasure of the nation, and deserves to be treated as such. It has incredible importance to natives of Utah, and importance to other adventurers. It's status as a national monument cannot be revoked.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears is a special place and part of our history. Further it is a beautiful and unique landscape. Please keep this and others up for consideration in tact and preserve what America is all about.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument and our public lands should not be touched. The climate the new administration has created scares all of us who have love of the outdoors.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument deserves continued protection for the benefit of all Americans! Commercial use of public lands concentrates benefit in the hands of a few and diminishes the potential for future enjoyment of the general population.As a resident of Montana I can only imagine that you value the open, wild places that make where you live special. The legacy of publicly owned land, held in trust for the citizens of our country, needs the protection of Congress. Commercial exploitation of our collective property damages that legacy and penenantly damages our lands, robbing our future citizens of equal enjoyment and use of those lands.Please don't let short term financial benefits outweigh the long term benefit of preserving our national legacies.Thank you for your considerationSincerely,Michael Joseph

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument deserves to be protected for current and all future generations. Please consider input from all sides and weigh the options carefully prior to any decision you make. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument deserves to remain protected for as long as it's existence. I kindly ask that you do not re-designate.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears national monument is an important monument for Itah and the country. Please leave it intact. Despite what you hear from Utah representatives, the monument is very valuable and is more so as a preserved area than it would bein the hands of or state who would destroy one of the few pristine areas. For both its ecological and historical value please consider leaving it as the monument it is.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument is an important place for our community and it holds historical significance that cannot be lost. It's up to you to decide what do do, but I hope that you consider the people's opinion.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument is ecologically rich and culturally valuable.Tribal leaders and members go to the Bears Ears area to conduct ceremonies, practice healing rituals, and connect with their ancestral lands in many other ways.This place is so sacred to Native Americans that 26 tribes joined together for the first time to ask for presidential protection for Bears Ears by designating it as a national monument that would honor their connections to the land and protect priceless cultural resources.Rescinding or changing it only hurts one of our nations most incredible landscapes.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument is ecologically rich and culturally valuable. Please protect our lands!

PLEASE KEEP THIS AREA AS A NAT'L MONUMENT!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Please dont change it.Climbing at Indian Creek exposed me to the natural beauty of this area; those trips were absolutely life-affirming and life-changing experiences for me.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Please dont change it.National Monuments are a sacred tradition of conservation to protect America's beauty. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Please dont change it. It is important to protect this land from damage and development so that current and future generations are able to experience it. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Please dont change it. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Please dont change it. This land is such an important natural monument with natural and cultural resources. It is so important that we protect it. This land has important ties to many Navaho tribes and also has great archeological importance. I am a student right now but I want to have this beautiful monument long into the future.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. Please dont change it. We have to protect the beauty of this earth and find other alternatives for our energy needs.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Defend and protect Bears Ears National Monument. Not only is it an important cultural monument but it contains historic, cultural and natural resources that need to be protected and maintained for all Americans. This land should not be opened to mining, logging, drilling, or any other environmentally damaging enterprise. Protect Bears Ears for my future, my children's future and my grandchildren's future. Do not destroy it by opening it up to commerce and industry.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Having grown up in Moab I care deeply about this place.Bears Ears National Monument is ecologically rich and culturally valuable. Rescinding or changing it hurts one of our nations most incredible landscapes. Our public lands are vital to our national legacy, which belongs not only to us, but also to all future Americans. These are the wild places we lovewhere we run, hike, camp, ski, fish, climb and spend important time with our friends and families. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am an avid hiker and enjoyer of the outdoors and wholeheartedly believe it would be a travesty not to protect our beautiful land for generations to come.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I am reaching out to you not as an enemy nor as a critic, but as one outdoors man to another. In doing so I intend to make this brief and to the point. Public lands are what make this country so unique and great. I believe as Americans it is our duty to take care of the land we call our home. This is the land which our troops protect, our children play in, and people from around the world come to admire. I believe that neglecting these parks will result in us losing our identity as a country. No one goes to admire pipelines, oil fields, etc. you can't have fun around them and needless to say they are an eye sore. So please, as a leader, make a difference that will benefit this country for generations to come. More than ever we need some hope as a country, we need something positive to happen. Be that positivity.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I have had the pleasure of visiting Glacier National Park in your home state of Montana. The snow capped mountains and electric blue lakes are unlike anything I have ever seen. I have seen similar majesty across our great nation from the Everglades to the Pacific Northwest. It deeply troubles me that the current administration is seeking to remove the monument status from Bears Ears.Please do the right thing and protect our national monuments for future generations.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I have serious concerns that the desires of the fossil fuels industry are being heard over the voices of the local population, 85% of whom are Native American. Bears Ears National Monument matters to those who value cultural heritage. It is an important landmark and should remain in it's current form.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I think we ought to reconsider our goals here and realize how detrimental public lands are to the people of this world, to animals and plant species as well as the betterment of this world we are currently destroying. We need to save places like this. It is our duty to this earth that we keep some of this land as we found it. If we don't we really will feel the consequences. Hell! We already are through climate change, limited resources and biodiversity loss. Public lands help bring people together to better understand themselves and the world around them. Who would want to be responsible for stopping this? Really think about it.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I urge you to listen to your constituents and the majority of the American people. Bears Ears National Monument should have been protected 50 years ago and deserves to be protected for all future generations. Please dont rescind or change its designation. These are national treasures that deserve to be protected.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I urge you to respect the legacy of our public lands. Once abandoned by our federal government, which is supposed to protect them, they will be developed or otherwise lost forever to future generations. Please do not let such an act of abandonment be a legacy of your term of stewardship.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I visited Bears Ears three years ago and knew then it needed to be protected for current and future generations. The National Monument is ecologically rich and culturally valuable. Rescinding or changing it only hurts one of our nations most incredible landscapes. Moreover, honoring the traditions and wishes of our Native peoples is paramount to our honor as a nation.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,I was eager to bring my family (and tourist dollars) to southeast Utah, including Bears Ears, this summer. I got excited about getting off the beaten path and exploring hidden places. But we had to postpone our trip. Will Bears Ears still be unspoiled for us to enjoy in a few years or will it be crisscrossed by drilling infrastructure like so many other places I've loved?Please protect Bears Ears National Monument and all the economic opportunity outdoor recreation holds for Utah communities.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,In a time when this country seems determined to destroy everything that makes us great, the preservation of Bears Ears National Monument (along with all of our National Monuments) is a critical move in preserving our wilderness heritage for generations to come. We as a country must realize that in order to guarantee our children a future, that our days of greed, where everything that is valued or sacred is also exploitable are over. We need to protect these sacred places. Thank you.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,It is my opinion as an American that Bears Ears is worth protecting. Please keep it a national monument.

Dear secretary Ryan Zinke,National monuments are a huge part of America as a whole, and are something that we as Americans have pride in as they enrich our countries' history. Bears Ears National Monument and the other 26 national monuments are beautiful part of our country, and by damaging them you are hurting the scared lands that give the people of America pride.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are a very important part of our national history. They provide local communities a better economy as well our nation entire nation. In addition to providing benefits to our communities and country as a whole, these places provide freedom for outdoor enthusiasts. These national monuments provide professional and amateur climbers a place for business and recreation. Taking this away would be taking away their freedom. Please listen to our voices! These public lands are part of us and having access to them is more than important, it is something we need.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are just that, public. They should be protected and preserved for all people to enjoy.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are some of the last places where we can witness the beauty of nature. But beyond that, they provide habitats for rarebit species. Protecting land is important for future generations, who do not have a say but will need the clean air and green spaces more than ever. Save them for your children and mine.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our economics and overall well being. We must protect them now so that future generations can enjoy then as much as we have! Please help us fight back for the environment!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy and the history of many cultures. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole.National Monument designations should never be revoked. This goes against everything our country stands for.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole. However, 'economic value' should not be the criterion used to determine whether public lands should remain public or become a source of exploitation and revenue for government or corporations. Quality of life, and integrity of the ecosystem that supports non-human life should be the main criterion used in determining whether public lands should be protected or industrialized. In case you are unaware, there is much scientific research now that studies how large top-of-food-chain animals on both land and in oceans are critical to maintenance of the food sources that humans favor. Please be courageous and do not be a typical politician who acts for his pocketbook rather than for integrity of life on this planet.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole. Please do not allow this precious resource to be squandered. The public land system is a unique aspect of America that allows all people equal access to beautiful glorious wilderness all across our nation. If we lose our public lands they will be gone forever and future generations will miss out on experiencing this great natural treasure. Please hear our voices and protect our public land system so that my kids, your kids and grandkids may enjoy this stunning nation the way it was intended by our forefathers: unspoiled unrelenting wilderness for all to enjoy. Thank you sir, for doing the right thing.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, and to our nation as a whole. We all rely on them to show our children the great outdoors, promote tourism in remote places and enjoy the beautiful spaces around us. Please help protect them!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to our national legacy. Theyre economically beneficial to our local communities, veterans, and to our nation as a whole. Re-evaluating the designation of these monuments is unacceptable. Generations of Americans will look at this decision and note that this decision is on the wrong side of history. I do NOT support any changes to the designation of these 27 national monuments, and will continue to resist at every front.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands are vital to the well being of our nation and the well being of the American people. We need to preserve open spaces for ourselves and for future generations so that we may take solace in outdoor recreation. Growing up on an island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean has taught me the importance of land and the impact that accessibility to open spaces has on the health and productivity of communities around the country.If we don't have wide open spaces and natural beauty to enjoy - then what are we left with? Please see the island of Oahu and City of Honolulu as a warning of the dangers of over development and putting the interests of foreign investors over the well being of a community.Bears Ears and the other National Parks that the 26th President of the United States, Theodore Roosevelt, established in the early 1900s become increasingly more crucial as the world continues to turn and change.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Our public lands have served so many Americans and visitors from across the world, that to take the protection away would be detrimental to our current and future selves. These are the places that we go to explore, bond, breathe, revitalize, and escape the stresses that belong within our everyday lives. Please don't take that away from us.

Do not take away our national treasures. Remember, this is America the Beautiful! Let's keep it that way.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are a part of our national heritagean attack on this monument, or any monument for that matter, is an attack on America.I have a step-son who's heart is in nature. We climb, backpack, snowboard, hike, and soak in the true natural beauty of this world. I want him to grow up (as well as my future kid) seeing and knowing the beauty of this land. I want him to understand that environmental stewardship and protection of these lands are key to preserving them. I don't want his kid's kids to learn about these public lands in history books, I want them to experience it first hand. Please, for the sake of our future generations, don't destroy the land that was given to us. Protect it as you would your own children.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are a part of our national heritagean attack on this monument, or any monument for that matter, is an attack on America.There is a reason we protect cultural and environmental treasures. We protect them so a 5th grader from Chicago can see Native American resources for the first time. We protect so that a you couple can create memories outside together. We protect so that a grandfather can take his grandkids to his favorite public lands. Please continue to protect.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are a part of our national heritagean attack on this monument, or any monument for that matter, is an attack on America. Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are a part of our national heritagean attack on this monument, or any monument for that matter, is an attack on America. Please don't put profit before sensibility.I know the lure of selling off our public lands for big corporations to exploit for huge profits can be enticing, but the problem is that once these lands are scarred, they will never be the same. Wild public lands are not a "federal land grab," it is a way of preserving some of our most pristine resources.And by the way, many communities survive off the tourism that these lands generate. Please do not favor giant corporations over the interests of these communities and future Americans who deserve to have these lands saved in their name.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America.Climate change, and it's denial is the number one threat to our species, and the Department of Interior should be focused on reducing CO2 emissions throughout the US. By opening this national treasure to further carbon extraction, you are robbing our children and grandchildren of the right to clean air, and eventually a habitable environment.Please drop this misguided effort to give away our public lands to fossil fuel companies, and start protecting our people.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America.Please do the right thing and Defend Bears Ears!The legacy of this nation and its originary peoples depends upon it.Thank you -

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. There is only so much land and no more is being made protect what we have. Thank you.George DeWolf

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America.PLEASE CONSIDER FUTURE GENERATIONS WHO HAVE NO VOICE IN THIS MATTER!!!!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America.The protection of national monuments matters to all Americans now and for the future.I urge you to leave Bears Ears national monument as it is.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America. I believe the current administration's consideration to downgrading Bears Ears is a mistake for our current and future generations. Please, Sir, allow Bears Ears to remain a national monument.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America. Please preserve Bears Ears as-is.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America. We are obligated to protect our public lands for future generations. We are lucky to benefit from those generations ago who had the foresight to preserve these lands. Let us be remembered as the generation who maintained the legacy of these beautiful spaces - not as those who took deprived our children of a precious gift.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on America. When all the national parks, oceans, trees and such are destroyed, or built up or burnt down... then what?

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national monuments, is an attack on Environmental Ethics. There is no ethical reason to just give up such beautiful areas for the sake for money to make more money.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. An attack on Bears Ears, or any of our national parks or monuments, is an attack on America.Keep Federal protection for these parks and monuments.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are part of our national heritage. I strongly believe that protected public lands belong to all us--most importantly, future generations--not any individual or company. I strongly favor keeping Bears Ears (and all current monuments) intact and firmly with the public.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Protected public lands are protected for a reason. They are part of what makes our country so special and beautiful. They need to be protected for future generations. Thank you.
Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public land and National parks are known world-wide, they attack tourist, the US can be proud to have them.Protecting Nature and the environment has no price tag.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Public lands are a national treasure. Our national monuments represent critically important wild places where we enjoy the freedom to recreate while protecting the natural beauty of America's diverse and incredible landscapes. These national monuments come with economical benefits as well, as they bring jobs and tourist revenue to rural areas. PLEASE protect our national treasures by maintaining the existing designations of our national monuments.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Right now our son and five of his friends are on a hiking trip in Utah. They have planned and researched their trip for months. With every phone call and text I get, he tells us about just how beautiful the parks and land are and how much he wants to thank us for giving him the opportunity to take the time to take the trip. Another comment is "I can't wait to get you two out here to see this.". Bears Ears National Monument is on the list of places to visit while they are out there. Now, I am wondering will there be the opportunity "to get us out there to see this " or not. Will this be the trip of a lifetime because it will be his only chance to freely visit this extraordinary area of our country? We have protected areas of our country for over 100 years with our national parks and national monuments. We have truly been blessed to be able to take our children to some of the most spectacular places on this planet, thanks to someone's foresight. The very idea that our government would decide that taking this designation away from these public areas and then essentially offering them up for development is incomprehensible. We do not need to turn a buck on every inch of our country. I hope that you use the knowledge and wisdom that God gave you and make a decision to keep our national parks and national monuments as they are and ensure the rest of us that yes, we will be able to someday go see and enjoy that beautiful landscape.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,States Rights! States Rights! States Rights! The federal government does not run large departments well (unless they print money or borrow from other designated funds) but states can and do and will manage lands to the benefit of their citizens and visitors. How's the US Post Office balance sheet? Social Security? Medicare?

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,Thank you for all you do and for your careful consideration of this area. I appreciate you taking the time to hear my thoughts. Bears Ears National Monument should have been protected 50 years ago and deserves to be protected for all future generations. Please dont rescind or change its designation. I have been hunting, camping, biking and enjoying this area and others in Utah for most of my life. It is very important to me that it remains protected and pristine so that my children and grandchildren may enjoy it and build amazing memories as I have. Again, thank you for all your hard work on this issue.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,The decision to remove the designation of national monument does not only affect people now -- it affects all of the generations that follow. Once these monuments are lost, they are gone forever. Whose path do you want to follow, Trump's or Teddy Roosevelt's?

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,What is a place that is special to you and your family? Even the thought of that place- your place-likely conjures up a fullness of heart and stories of times spend with people close to you. Bears Ears National Monument is that place for many people. It is a landmark of cultural heritage and exceptional beauty. A place of fullness. Connection. Deeply personal memories. There is only one place like this in the whole world and we are fortunate enough to have it in our country. Therefore, it is our duty as Americans to protect this land and honor the Native Peoples and the important spaces of which we are still guests. The immeasurable and intangible worth of Bears Ears is to be celebrated, experienced, and protected for generations to come. Now is the time to take action to preserve this place and protect not only land, but the sense of place that is woven into the stories of so many lives within the community and beyond.

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke,you CAN'T just strip away our country of what makes it beautiful. I know ALL you care about is making money; but it won't stand!! our country is beautiful and God has made it this way for a reason. you cannot just go and destroy it for your own benefit!! stripping out beautiful country of its parks and many animals, is outrageousness!! the fact that I have to write this is ridiculous. you absolutely cannot strip these parks of their protections. businessmen with no person regards for others, hellbent on making money, will destroy these places!! I have personally visited most of these parks, and I'm going again this summer. it's ridiculous I have to even write this!! what a shame!! NO!! do not destroy our beautiful country!!

Dear Secretary Ryan Zinke:Bears Ears needs to be preserved and protected. Paleontologists have uncovered rock layers dating back to the Triassic Era as well as a wealth of dinosaur fossils. In addition, there are important archaeological sites for the Pueblo people in this area. Public lands should not be developed for economic gains through mining, fracking and drilling. These areas have been set aside for their special qualities and beauty and need to be left for all of us and future generations to enjoy and cherish.

Dear Secretary ZinkeI am writing to comment on the current review of the status of the Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument. I feel that Grand Staircase / Escalante should be maintained in its current state with no areas removed from protection. I have visited and hiked in this area numerous times and find it to be one of the most spectacular wild regions left in the USA. It is unique and the visitation value to the economies of local communities has been significant. Proposals to detach certain areas so resources, especially coal, can be mined make little sense. Coal is clearly becoming an obsolete resource and the expected closure of the nearby Navajo coal fired power plant and associated coal mines in Arizona clearly illustrate this point. Maintaining national monument status as is makes the most sense from several points of view: Environmental, Scenic Beauty and Recreation, and Economic. Please do not detach areas from this most special National Monument.David Fell

Dear Secretary Zinke -I live in northern Arizona and am an avid explorer of the outdoors. I have personally explored many parts of the Bears Ears National Monument over the ast 15 years and it protects some of the most remarkable cultural resources in this country. The landscape is breathtaking and offers outstanding opportunities for peace and solitude in a natural environment. It is a crucial piece of our nation's heritage and deserves continued protection in it's current state and scope. I urge you to leave this area protected so that future generations can explore and enjoy it in perpetuity.Not all Americans believe that every inch of our nation's wild areas need be exploited in order to produce more worthless stuff that we can buy and throw away.These lands, these wild and open spaces, hold an inherent and irreplaceable value.Thank you for listening.Sincerely,David LoganFlagstaff, AZ

Dear Secretary Zinke - I am writing to express my deep concern about the current review of national monuments, particularly the expedited review of the Bears Ears National Monument in Utah. There is no good reason for a shortened calendar for Bears Ears other than to concede to the demands of elected officials in Utah who have ignored public demands for permanent public lands protection for many years. They are simply seeking to open up our special national heritage lands to private companies for private benefit, depleting resources instead of ensuring that our children and grandchildren can visit Bears Ears and other special places in the future.This unprecedented review of 27 national monuments is a significant threat to our public lands that will forever alter the ability of future Presidents to protect America's special places. There is significant pressure from Utah's politicians to undo the permanent protections afforded Bears Ears in December. I implore you to ignore that pressure and uphold the Bears Ears monument designation. Please do not authorize a reversal of the Bears Ears monument or reduce its boundaries, as doing so will put all monuments - not just the 27 under initial review - at significant risk. An attack on Bears Ears is truly an attack on all monuments.I hope that your visit to Utah demonstrated that there is tremendous local support for monument designations at Bears Ears and Grand Staircase Escalante. There is also substantial economic value generated from these monuments and many others also under review. In fact, a tourism brochure produced by the state of Utah's highlights Grand Staircase Escalante as one of Utah's most wonderful public land areas. And the American people have responded by visiting and spending their hard-earned dollars in the local area. The same is now happening in Maine as a result of the Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument designation in August 2016, providing the hope of a sustained economy in a region that currently has very little to count on.I appreciate that you went to Utah and hope you will visit the other monuments under initial review. I am confident that you will be moved by the variety of protected lands now available to all Americans through these national monument designations, and that your support for public lands will be renewed and restored.In sum, I oppose the review of national monuments and urge you to resist all pressure to undo the protections of the Antiquities Act. Please leave Bears Ears alone, and then don't undo any other designations either.Thank you for the opportunity to submit comments.Sincerely,Kathy DeCoster

Dear Secretary Zinke (and whoever else this matter concerns),Please do not take the unprecedented action of stripping protections from any national monuments. As somebody who grew up and has lived most of my life in Southern Utah, I am grateful for monuments such as the Grand Staircase-Escalante and Vermillion Cliffs. These are some of the most breathtakingly beautiful lands in this country - every bit as gorgeous as the much more popular national parks.This isn't being written by someone living hundreds of miles from the nearest monument under review. Utah is home for me. I have explored many miles by foot on several of the monuments that are under review - and many more are on my "bucket list." I know many other people in my area that feel the same way.Of course, this isn't all about me and the people that I personally know. These national monuments attract visitors from across the world. These people play a major role in bringing money to local communities by staying at hotels, eating at restaurants, buying groceries, etc. These monuments are visited for their natural and cultural value. Stripping protections on these monuments to allow oil/gas exploration (or other forms of resource extraction), motorized use in sensitive areas, and increased livestock grazing all would not only be bad for the land and the environment, but it would also create eye sores that could decrease the scenic and recreational value of the land. In turn, this could harm our local communities if visitors decide not to come.I oppose any changes to the powers of the Antiquities Act, and I vehemently oppose any effort to modify, weaken, or downsize our current national monuments.As someone who has lived almost my entire life in the western United States, I honestly believe that the scenic value of our public lands cannot be overstated. Native Americans consider land within some national monuments to be sacred. I echo this sentiment, as I have felt a connection to many of these lands that is difficult to put into words. Allowing these lands to persist under the protection of national monuments is critical in our increasingly populated world, where fewer people are connecting with nature.Ultimately, I trust that the right decision will be made, and that future generations will have the same opportunities to enjoy our national monuments and their natural beauty. The consequences of stripping our monuments of these protections would be far too great.Thank you for taking the time to read.Sincerely,
Dear Secretary Zinke,

Dear Secretary Zinke,As a life-long resident of Utah, I respectfully urge you to rescind the Bears Ears National Monument designation. It is very unfair that we in western states are the only areas in the United States with large areas of federal land in our borders. The use of the Antiquities Act by presidents to designate millions of acres of land as national monuments disparately impact all western states. The Bears Ears National Monument is almost twice the size of the state of Rhode Island; maybe it's time to reclaim and designate some areas in the east for a change!We are trying to make a living in rural Utah, too!Thank you for your time.Respectfully,William Brock

Dear Secretary Zinke,As a mother, concerned citizen and worker in the outdoor industry, I respectfully urge you to keep our public lands public and preserve the Bears Ears and Gold Butte National Monuments. These areas provide economic benefits in the form of travel tourism and jobs. And, they are stunningly beautiful. When I take my son camping and to spend time in the outdoors, I want him to experience the pure joy and amazement that these lands provide - free of man-made obstructions. We have so many other areas where we drill, mine and extract. Please, you have the opportunity to set aside some of our beautiful spaces for protection and outdoor recreation. There must be a balance, and I think these two areas in particular should be protected. All sides have had a say, a place at the table. There are other places to for resource extraction. Please be level-headed and preserve these sacred, beautiful sites.I truly believe today's children do not get outside enough. Hunting, hiking and exploring the outdoors are such a truly healthy way for kids to learn, satisfy their curiosity and grow into healthy, strong human beings, building on our culture. The health of our country's future lies, at least somewhat, in access to the outdoors, of which protected public lands plays a vital role. Please. Protect these monuments and leave a legacy that will matter for generations.

Dear Secretary Zinke,As Teddy Roosevelt, my personal hero, said of the grand canyon, "Leave it as it is...the ages have been at work on it and man can only mar it." This is also true of all of the national monuments created by the past 3 presidencies, most especially the Bears Ears National Monument. Each was as carefully selected for conservation and they need to remain as they are. America is the greatest country in the world, not least because it has protected so much national land. Let's keep it this way.Thank you.-Will Grover

Dear Secretary Zinke,Don't touch Bears Ears National Monument! It was created through a process of public input and diverse interests coming together for a common goal. I support its existence and continuation. Any attempt to shrink or eliminate it will only further divide our country and result in expensive and divisive litigation. Please dont change it.

Dear Secretary Zinke,I am a retired Biologist who moved to Las Cruces NM in 2009 because of the wonderful beauty and local access to hiking and exploration in Southern NM.The establishment of the Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks National Monument has helped spur our local economy while preserving unique biology, geology, archaeology and history. We the citizens of Dona Ana County overwhelmingly want preservation of these fantastic treasures. Our economy is fragile in Southern New Mexico and any change to this monument - whether decrease in size or eliminating its designation as a monument - would be detrimental to not only our economy but also our outdoor lifestyle we enjoy.Please do not change our Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks NM.Thank you for your consideration.Sincerly,Jim Enright

Dear Secretary Zinke,I am very concerned about the potential reduction in size and loss of protections for the National Monuments designated since 1996. I have personally visited several of them, some repeatedly, both before and since their designations. In each case that I have examined, it is clear that the designations were made after careful thought and much input from local people who advocated their protection as among America's most treasured lands in the face of new or continued destruction of the natural resources for the short-term profits of a few. Most of these lands were already managed by the Federal government as part of the National Estate, seized from the Native Americans and Mexican inhabitants by violence and coercion many years ago in the interests of westward expansion, the interests of the few who would profit, and the grasping of political power by the elites of the time. Most of these lands were held in sacred esteem by the Native Americans who lived on them for centuries. It is only just that these lands be managed as part of the sacred trust lands of the United States and protected from those who would reduce them to short-term profits and minor political points. Please do everything in your power to protect the full designated boundaries of all currently existing National Monuments and Parks, including, and especially, Bears Ears, Sonoran Desert, Ironwood Forest, Grand Staircase-Escalante, Parashant-Grand Canyon, and our protected oceanic monuments.Kenneth J. Kingsley

Dear Secretary Zinke,I am very disappointed and concerned that this Executive Order threatens our national monuments, especially Bears Ears in southeastern Utah. Bears Ears was exactly the landscape the Antiquities Act - a law that has been used by 16 Presidents of both parties to safeguard this and other national treasures - was enacted to protect. Rescinding the Bears Ears National Monument would be unprecedented. I strongly urge you to uphold the monument's current boundaries.Bears Ears is a sacred landscape with more than 100,000 Native American cultural sites. The proposal to establish it was developed by a coalition of five sovereign Tribal Governments (Hopi, Navajo, Ute Mountain Ute, Ute, and Zuni). Bears Ears is also home to scientific wonders, irreplaceable wildlife and biodiversity, and recreational opportunities that form a vital base to the local economy. That is why Utahns and Americans across the country - sportsmen, business leaders, Native Americans, veterans, conservationists, recreationists, and members of the faith community - have agreed it should be protected for future generations.This designation received an enormous amount of scrutiny, including years of debate and discussion. Dozens of community meetings and public discussions were held throughout 2016, including a well-attended public meeting with then-Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell. The final monument designation boundaries are very close to what was proposed in the Utah delegation's Public Lands Initiative (PLI), and much smaller than the Tribally-led proposal. Please leave Bears Ears National Monument's boundaries intact so that future generations will be able to explore, enjoy, and learn from this national treasure.

Dear Secretary Zinke,I didn't grow up in a family that loved the outdoors. I was 18 when I visited my first National Park. Ten years later, I'm playing catch up and visiting every park, forest, and monument I can get to. I've been to a handful of the 27 on the list that is under review. I've seen dust devils dance on the lake at Carrizo Plain, a few years before the rest of the world saw its magnificent superbloom on Instagram. On my first solo trip a month after I graduated college, I spent several weeks exploring your home state of Utah. I remember gazing up at the night sky in Grand Staircase Escalante--surrounded in every direction by that vast, mystical desert--and thinking this is the place that sets my soul free. I had never felt more excited to be alive, to be American, to be part of this great country. Being in that quiet and beautiful corner of the world filled my mind with a limitless sense of possibility and excitement at the dawn of my own career in public service. Just yesterday my best friend and I inadvertantly wound up in the Sonoran Desert (car troubles in the Grand Canyon left us near Phoenix).. we woke up at 4:30am to watch the sunrise over those perfect jagged mountains. My friend has never been awake at 4:30 but watching the sun paint the desert every shade of pink, seeing birds wake up and take flight off of the saguaro, and feeling the hot breeze against our cheeks was an experience neither of us will ever forget. It's the kind of experience I hope to share one day with my children and grandchildren, and they theirs. Our national parks and monuments--our country's reverence for preservation and awe for nature--is deeply linked to our national heritage. I hope that reverence for these spaces endures for all generations.There are few things I cherish more than our national parks and monuments. I absolutely do not support any reductions or changes to existing national monuments. I fear that any rollback or reduction of these areas would open the spaces up not only to damaging resource extraction practices, but would also set a dangerous precedent for how all our public lands may be viewed and managed in the future. National monuments should be preserved in perpetuity for public enjoyment and environmental protection. They are our national treasures and I believe the federal government should continue to serve as a leader in these values and a steward of these spaces. I still haven't been to Bears Ears but I can't wait to get there at the next opportunity. I can't wait to visit all 27 of these monuments on this list and experience the unforgettable wonders each has to offer.

Dear Secretary Zinke,I write to express my strong support for keeping Bears Ears, Grand Staircase-Escalante, Grand Canyon-Parashant, Vermillion Cliffs, Basin and Range, Craters of the Moon, and all the other national and marine monuments you are reviewing just as they are. These places were legitimately set aside by former presidents using the Antiquities Act of 1906 and they should not be undone, reduced in size, opened to new resource exploitation or other development, or allowed to have activities that were not identified when they were created. These lands belong to you, to me, and to every other American. They should not be sacrificed for the benefit of a few powerful companies and individuals whose activities would forever compromise them through development and resource extraction. Those activities are not compatible with preserving the integrity, natural beauty, scientific value, solitude, plant and wildlife habitat, archaeological sites, Native American sacred sites, clean air, natural night skies and much more of these special places. The existing national and marine monuments should be kept as they are for the enjoyment of all citizens now and in the future.I have lived on the Colorado plateau most of my adult life. I have spent time in most of the western monuments under review, some before they were even monuments. I have actually lived and worked in quite a few of these places doing research for the National Park Service, Bureau of Land Management, State of Utah, etc. For many of these places, I know how special and unique they are from first hand experience. I feel they DO reflect "The requirements and original objectives of the Act, including the Act's requirement that reservations of land not exceed "the smallest area compatible with the proper care and management of the objects to be protected". I have spent the most time in Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante. These places have values and characteristics that are unmatched anywhere else on earth. While some of our elected officials and a small cadre of people who live in southern Utah feel the monuments are too large, one could actually argue the opposite for they preserve only the heart of the best of canyon country in southern Utah.The Grand Staircase-Escalante has not harmed the local economy or taken money from our public schools as some would have you believe. It has brought jobs and economic growth to the area. The land was federal land before the monuments and federal land now, so the monument designationwas not a land grab and did not affect school funding or take away jobs. Traditional activities, such as grazing and Native American herb collection continue as they always did. I know you didn't have time to speak with the Escalante Chamber of Commerce while you were out here, but please take the time to reach out to them now, to learn of the new jobs created by the monument and the fact that people who had to leave for jobs have now been able to come back home and find local employment due to the monument. During your visit to our amazing monuments, you also did not meet with the Native American led Utah Din Bikyah group, which is fighting for protection of Bears Ears. Please reach out to them now. They are a group of 5 Native American tribes with ties to the land. Bears Ears encompasses the ancestral homelands, including many ceremonial sites, burial areas, sacred herb gathering areas, and Traditional Cultural Properties of at least four of these tribes.According to the news reports, you spent most of your time with the governor, members of the Utah congressional delegation, and some county commissioners, all of whom oppose anything to do with monuments and the federal govt owning land in Utah. Despite being elected officials, they do not represent what the majority of Utah residents feel about the monuments. For Bears Ears, there was a long process called the PLI where some of our congressional representatives tried to push through an unacceptable alternative for Bears Ears. There were endless hearings and meetings, but the opinions and wishes of many, including the Tribes (who are sovereign nations), were not heard or respected. President Obama patiently waited for the Utah delegation to find a good solution and make compromises, but when they did not and could not, he acted. There was plenty of public input. Unfortunately, Congressman Bishop and Chaffetz did not want to hear it or act on it so Obama came up with a compromise. The Bears Ears is actually closer in size to the PLI than what the environmental groups wanted.Also, please remember, the people who live by the monuments are not the only locals. Many of us in central and northern UT visit the monuments often and they do belong to ALL Americans. Please do not sell out for short-term gain for a few, but keep the monuments as they are for the benefit of the many, and the benefit of current and future generations. Thank you.

Dear Secretary Zinke,Many of the national monuments under review were designated after extensive local input and review. Why do you feel you have to undo what's been done? you promised us here in Montana that you would protect our public lands. you did not say except for the ones designated under a non-republican president! i am so tired of elected officials being so contrary. there are intelligent thinking people in both parties, let's listen to them. Not everything President Obama accomplished was "bad". I could list all the numbers about jobs loss etc, but I'm sure you are already aware of the numbers!Please rethink your stand on National monuments.thank you!

Dear Secretary Zinke,Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am extremely disappointed that President Trump has signed an executive order that attempts to undermine our national monuments. Attempts to rollback protections for national monuments would be both illegal and terribly misguided and I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.I understand that you are doing an expedited review of the Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, whose priceless historic, cultural and natural wonders are exactly what should be permanently protected as a National Monument. Monument status for Bears Ears protects 100,000 archaeological and cultural sites as well as stunning mesas, canyons and arches and the incredible outdoor recreation, hunting, fishing and general solitude and peace they contain -- these treasures are irreplaceable.
