The designation and boundaries of the monument honors the voices of five sovereign tribal nations who joined together to seek protection of their shared ancestral lands and traditions, Bears Ears National Monument should remain protected permanently.Additionally, a threat to one monument is a threat to them all. Sending a signal that protections for our shared history and culture are not permanent would set a terrible precedent. This would discourage business investment and community growth around all national monuments while also sending the signal that our history and natural wonders are negotiable. National monuments have already been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses in gateway communities rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities. Whether at Bears Ears or other monuments across the country, our national monuments should remain protected for future generations to enjoy - they are a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for National Monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.Sincerely,Robin Mark

Dear Secretary Zinke,Please leave the Bears Ear National Monument as is. I am a registered republican. However I do not agree with many republicans on the environment, or our protected lands. The majority of our native Americans want this monument and I agree.Thank you,Russ George

Dear Secretary Zinke,Please maintain and protect the designation of Bears Ears in Utah as a National Monument. Bears Ears is a national treasure that belongs to all of us, and is especially sacred to the Native Americans.No president has ever revoked the designation of national monuments. This goes back to President Theodore Roosevelt, a Republican champion of our national lands.I am thoroughly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for Bears Ears or any other national monument. Thus I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.Thank you for standing up for the American people by protecting Bears Ears and other National Monuments.Nancy Phillips36A Rice St.Cambridge, MA 02140

Dear Secretary Zinke,Please preserve all national monuments that are being reviewed, including Bears Ears in Utah. Preserving our national monuments will help retain the 7.6 million outdoor recreation industry jobs in the US. These jobs are ongoing and won't leave an area as they would if we allow drilling or other activities in our beautiful lands. The $887B contributed to our economy by the outdoor recreation industry is not a trivial amount. People from all over the world travel to the US to see our natural wonders. Please do not rescind or shrink any of our public lands.

Dear Secretary Zinke,Please remove the national monument designation for Bear's Ears as well as the Grand Stair Case. The antiquities act is meant for small parcels of land, not for land areas larger than the state of Delaware. Please leave it to the people of Utah to make decisions regarding their own land.Thanks,Tanner Savage

Dear Secretary Zinke,President Trump has directed the Interior Department to review the use of the Antiquities Act to create National Monuments after 1996. This review threatens the protections Monument status affords, and the heritage and character of the rural west. I urge you and the Department of the Interior to maintain all existing National Monument statues, including Bears Ears as originally issued by previous administrations.Consider the following:Senator Hatch's statement calling the Bears Ears National Monument a "federal land grab," is patently false. The land was already owned by the federal government; managed by the BLM and the USFS. Furthermore, all land in the west was acquired by the federal government though treaty or purchase. This was not a land grab, the Antiquities Act was used as intended to protect a place important to western culture.Our National Monuments and public lands represent the heritage and character of the west. Us westerners love wide-open spaces and wild places. Our public lands are the buffers around our homes. Public lands spread us out and create places to roam, climb, hunt, fish, camp, bike, hike, and 4-wheel.President Trump has no understanding of life in the west or rural America. He is a New York city slicker, and now a Washington elite. He knows nothing of our way of life or how we use our lands. Do not let a city slicker like President Trump take away our public lands.Previous Presidents have used the Antiquities Act to create National Monuments, this was not interference in our way of life. This was an effort to protect our way of life from exploitation. In the case of Bears Ears the forces pushing on President Obama to issue the monument declaration were westerns.As a fellow western I except you to understand our way of life and the importance of protecting our public lands. Protection of our lands, both public and private is something we all agree on in the west.In closing do not let President Trump rescind or change any existing National Monuments status. Have the courage to stand up to President Trump and protect my home and your home. Help all of us in the west maintain our wide-open spaces and wild places; they are important to our way of life.Sincerely,R.D.C.Four Corners, U.S.A

Dear Secretary Zinke,The Bears Ears National Monument comprises some of the most unique and precious land in the world. From both an ecological and cultural standpoint, we owe it to current and future generations to maintain these irreplaceable assets. Our family has many close friends on the Navajo Nation and we know well the spiritual and cultural importance of this place. We also know personally just how special the landscape of Bears Ears is. Please maintain the designation of National Monument and the protections it affords.Sincerely,Corey Brinkema

Dear Secretary Zinke,The cultural, historic, and natural resources of this area must be protected. In addition, the native ancestral ties to this land must be respected. We need to preserve this land for all. Please protect the national monument status of Bears Ears.

Dear Secretary Zinke,The Department of the Interior should be in the business of protecting our national monuments, not choosing which ones are no longer fit to have that designation. None of the monuments listed should be eliminated.

Dear Secretary Zinke,As a resident of the west and frequent user of our beautiful natural heritage, I am writing to tell you I strongly support the protection provided by recent National Monument designations includng the Organ Mountains, Rio Grande del Norte, Bears Ears and Grand Staircase Escalante. It would be a tragic to allow "for profit" special interests, such as mineral extraction and development industries to spoil these remarkable areas, our public land, for short term gain, when long term irreperarable damage is certain. I understand to politicians in Washington DC, these areas mean nothing other than dollar signs and political favors, and most have never seen them. However myself and many like me love this land and want to take care of these cherished areas.Please preserve these remarkable areas for future generations to enjoy, when they're gone, they're gone.Sincerely,Steve Hanes

Dear Secretary Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument has already begun to cause problems and I don't agree that such a large portion of the county/state should be swallowed up as a monument. I know people think monuments protect the land but has everyone forgotten about Fossil Cycad National Monument where all of the fossils were removed by visitors and it was eventually rescinded because there was nothing left to protect?There were so many protections on this land already. I know that many have said if it is not a monument then it will be sold off. This is not true. The area that has been designated a monument was already public land that was being managed by the BLM and NPS or it was Trust fund land which funds our schools (do people really want to take money away from our children's education?). There is not any oil to be drilled, it has been tested already. There is not any oil.The area within the Bears Ears National Monument designation that is most dense with ruins is on Cedar Mesa. The Antiquities Act states "the limits of which in ALL cases shall be confined to the SMALLEST AREA compatible with proper care and management of the objects to be protected." 1.35 million acres is NOT the smallest area compatible with the objects to be protected nor is it going to receive the proper care and management. The National Parks Service reported a total of $11,493,168,182.00 deferred maintenance log for 2014. $278,094,606.00 was the total deferred amount for Utah and that was before Bear Ears National Monument was designated (from NPS Facility Management Software System data). If there is not enough money to maintain the national monuments and parks in the U.S. and Utah prior to Bear Ears NM designation, then how can it receive proper care and management?Native Americans, local residents and many others across the U.S. are in support of rescinding Bears Ears National Monument. If nothing else Bears Ears and Grand Staircase should be greatly reduced in size. These monuments are a federal over reach by the presidents that declared them as monuments and they do not follow the laws under which they were declared.Please listen to the people who's lives are the most affected by it. Please Rescind or severely decrease the size of Bears Ears National Monument and Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument. Please allow the residents surrounding these monuments to not have our livelihood and our way of life be destroyed by cutting us off from grazing land, wood and food.Thank you, Ashlie

Dear Secretary Zinke,First, I implore you not to decrease protections to and for existing national monuments, including Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante in Utah. Second, I ask that you (YOU) research and understand the bipartisan legacies of the Antiquities Act, in that Republican presidents also designated national monuments (some of scale of millions of acres). And, third, you must recognize and honor tribal sovereignty regarding Bear Ears. Please listen to ALL Americans and not be tied to short-sighted or biased agendas supportive of quick oil-and-gas gains aren't worth the devastation to ecosystems, scenic values (and thus TOURIST $$), or the cultural heritage.To see a list of the national monuments set aside under the Antiquities Act, go to https://www.npca.org/resources/2658-monuments-protected-under-the-antiquities-act#sm.000cs64gw1au8de3w9j1v6j170mpv.Thank you.

Dear Secretary Zinke,I am writing in support of allowing all national monuments to retain their current borders. I am particularly passionate about Grand Staircase Escalante and Bears Ears in my home state. People in my state and around the country spoke out in support of making Bears Ears a national monument, including tribal leaders. Please respect the will of the American people and protect our national monuments. They preserve our nation's heritage for future generations.This article further demonstrates the ecological importance of Bears Ears: http://www.csp-inc.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/CSP-BENM_Landscape_Assessment_032717.pdfThank you.

Dear Secretary Zinke,I am writing to ask you to rescind the Bears Ears Monument. It needs to be kept as a multiple use area. I was born here in Blanding 76 years ago. We raised our 7 children here. Our family's best memories are of our many camping and jeep trips over the years. We love our mountains and have always taken good care of whatever area we camped, hiked, and jeeped in. We heat our home with wood from the mountains and BLM land. We make a family outing out of our wood gathering every year. The best way to protect this area is the way the locals have always protected it. We take care of it because we love it.When Secy. Jewell was here and met with the tribal group in favor of a monument they left trash strung about. That is not how the locals treat the land. Thank you for coming here and listening to those of us who have a stake in how this area is used.Sincerely, Claudia Orr

Dear Secretary Zinke,I am writing to urge you to maintain the current protections in place for the 22 National Monuments and 5 Marine National Monuments being reviewed as per Executive Order #13792 and as listed in FR Document #09490. To date, I have only visited the Vermillion cliffs and Grand Staircase-Escalante Monuments. The visit to Grand Staircase included car camping and backpacking.When previous presidents designated these monuments, they utilized research and input from scientists to determine the minimum size needed for each site to facilitate the proper care and management of the objects/wildlife or plant life to be protected. Believe the science!The designation of these lands and marine environments were properly classified by under the Act using input from the scientists who researched the biological or cultural resources of the designated monuments. The current President's proclivity for development and industrial interests should not be used to revoke the designations for these areas. Believe the science and the indigenous communities!While mineral extraction and other consumptive interests decry the monument designations; local economies are better served by the tourism industries that develop when these areas are protected. The tourism economies are long term, sustainable and serve to protect the area's soils, waters and other resources. This is in contrast to the short-term economy of mineral extraction which leaves behind scarred landscapes as well as contaminated soils and waters that cause lingering health hazards for area residents. The positive impacts of tourism are increased when multiple Monuments, Local, State or National Parks and other public lands are found close together. Visitors plan longer stays and spend more money in the area when there are several sites to visit within a few hours of each other.While I, and many others who utilize land based Monuments, may never visit the Marine Monuments listed in the Executive Order, I realize their importance. Seafood comprises 16% of the animal protein consumed worldwide. Research by Nature Conservancy scientists, and others, shows that marine reserves, such as these monuments, where fishing is either restricted or more tightly regulated; are important tools for building (and even rebuilding) sustainable fisheries populations. They also serve as important management tools for endangered species such as whales.I also urge you to advocate to Congress for adequate funding for the appropriate management of these Monuments. Once we have squandered our land, water, air and the species that depend on these resources; all the coal-fired power plants, fuel guzzling vehicles, second homes, and latest version smart phones we can make by using up natural resources will not sustain our human lives.Sincerely,

Dear Secretary Zinke,I'm writing today to comment on the Antiquities Act, and how it has been, in my opinion, a very positive thing for the management of public lands in the western states and Alaska.I've lived in Flagstaff, AZ for 35 years now and before that that for awhile in Alaska. I remember the great uproar when President Carter created a large number of new national monument in Dec. 1978, two years later congress acted to designate most of the lands as new national parks, monuments, and wildlife refuges. When I have returned to Alaska in recent years, I see that these areas are now central to the identifies of many of the rural communities surrounding these parks and monuments.Certainly we see the same pattern here in Flagstaff, where the use of the Antiquities Act by Teddy Roosevelt, was originally decried by local interest, but now more than a century later, Grand Canyon National Park is a huge part of the local tourist economy and has strong support, here and across the nation.I have also had the opportunity in my work as a professional nature and travel photographer to visit a number of areas both before and after becoming National Monuments. This would include Upper Missouri River Breaks in your home state of Montana, Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante in Utah, Grand Canyon-Parashant and Vermillion Cliffs in Arizona, and most recently Carrizo Plain in California.All of these places have an exceptional natural beauty, that can be easily marred by further intrusions of new roads, mines, oil wells and other developments so common in most of the rest of our country and the world. My belief, in the benefit of having these large public lands monuments is based on decades of watching these controversies arise and then gradually become faded as the local communities come to embrace these designations as part of what makes their communities special places.Please preserve the long term legacy these landscape size national monuments will provide for the management of our public lands for future generations of the citizens of these communities, states and the rest of the nation.Thank You for the consideration of my opinions.Tom Bean4680 Lake Mary RoadFlagstaff, AZ. 86005

Dear Secretary Zinke,My wife and I just returned yesterday from a trip to southeast Utah which included the Bears Ears National Monument. The establishment of this area as a national monument is a continuation of the uniquely American tradition of setting aside areas of federal land for protection, management and enjoyment of future generations. The stark beauty of this area with its high mesa canyons, ancient pueblo dwellings and remote solitude is worthy of continued national monument status and the protection such a designation affords.As a 40 year resident of Idaho I am aware that some in the West believe that limitations on the use of federal lands that a national monument designation brings is seen in a negative light. However, I believe such limitations are for the greater good of our country and all of its citizens. The ability to experience the vastness of the West and to know the feeling of being in a place where few, if any have been before is priceless. Just the knowledge that such places exist, even if never visited, is part of what America is about.I urge you to recommend the continuation of the Bears Ears National Monument and support the necessary funding to protect and preserve this unique area.

Dear Secretary Zinke,My wife and I recently traveled to Utah and Arizona, visiting National Parks and Monuments. In particular, we visited Grand Staircase-Escalante and Bears Ears National Monuments. Both of these unique landscapes and geological formations are stunning, and contain a rich history of native cultures as well as their scenic beauty. If development is allowed in these areas, parts of them will be destroyed forever. Please take the long-term view and protect these unique lands so that all Americans can enjoy them for generations to come, rather than bowing to the pressure of the selfish few.Thank You,John Sims

Dear Secretary Zinke,The protection of our lands via national parks and national monuments is one of the brightest points in our American heritage. Our dedication to preservation has given us some of the brightest jewels of wilderness parks in the entire world, and they'll be available to all generations of Americans to come. It would be a tragedy to not give Bears Ears this protection. Please do the right thing and continue to protect this fantastic monument.

Dear Secretary Zinke, I am a retired archaeologist who lives in western Colorado. I have worked extensively in a large part of the west, and I know that the Bears Ears is truly worth of protection, not only for its archaeological sites and traditional Native American traditional use areas, butt also as a world class area for tourism. I travel through southeastern Utah on average 6 times a year, and have done so for several decades. During that time I've seen growth in the tourism and outdoor recreation, while during all that period agriculture has remailed more or less stable, and the extractive industries have been depressed.De-listing the Bears Ears is not going to solve the economic issues depressing oil and gas or mining, nor is it going to address the concerns of citizens who complain about government overreach. I issues like grazing closures for sensitive species and many others are not tied to Monument status. Rather these issues already existed, have not changed due to monument listing, and won't go away were the Monument to be de-listed.Tourism and outdoor recreation are the future economic engine for southeastern Utah. And the public process leading to Monument designation was open and fair. I urge you to affirm you commitment to public lands by leaving the Monument in place.

Dear Secretary Zinke, please stop this Federal intrusion into State Lands. Bears Ears National Monument is just another example of a Federal land grab to stop development of State lands. Get rid of most of these so-called "National Monuments" designated solely for the purpose of Federal interference in our lives and to satisfy extreme environmentalists.

Dear Secretary Zinke:This comment is to urge you to preserve the new BEARS EARS National Monument in its entirety from any proposed changes in status or in size reduction. Interested parties in Utah and throughout the country have worked tirelessly to bring this jewel of Southwest topography and cultural treasure to monument status and protection. Let's all stand firm in maintaining it for future generations!I write this as a lifelong Montanan and a resident of Helena....and a supporter of public lands. I hope you will recognize and honor the significance of BEARS EARS for not only the citizens of Utah but also for all Americans.Thank you for keeping BEARS EARS intact!Sincerely,Carolyn Adams Helena, MT 59601

Dear Secretary Zinke: As a Montanan, I have long valued the place that a public lands play in our lives. When it comes to preserving these unique places, there is more at stake than economic development. I urge you not to deprive all Americans in future generations of these irreplaceable treasures.

Dear Secretary Zinke: I live in western Colorado and have visited Bears Ears National Monument during the past 25 years. If ever there was a national monument that requires protection for its fantastic archeological sites, scenery, and cultural ties to Native Americans, THIS IS IT!I would ask that your final report reflect the sincere sentiments of the majority of Americans that Bears Ears NM truly deserves the protection given it by its status and that no reduction in its size is necessary to protect these treasures.Thank you.Rein and Jan van WestRidgway, CO 81432

Dear Secretary Zinkie,As a life-long resident of the State of Utah I feel that it is imperative for the heritage of this state and of the Western United States to continue to protect our public lands with National Monument designations through the Antiquities Act. These wild and untamed lands are an integral part of the experience of all Utahns and our native populations. Additionally, these monuments and locales offer extensive and sustainable economic opportunities for nearby cities and counties to tap into the growing outdoor tourism market.I urge you to look farther beyond the short-term gain of natural resource extraction and think long term for the sake of these communities and for folks who live out west. Do not rescind any of the national monument designations in the state of Utah and do not shrink the protected areas within these monuments.Thank you.

Dear Secty. Zinke,Bear's Ears National Monument needs to be protected and preserved. According to the Navajo, Hopi, Zuni, and Ute Nations, the area is filled with burial grounds and cultural sites. "In the spring and summer of 2016, there were six confirmed theft incidents from the Bears Ears area, according to The Washington Post. This vandalism could be shocking in its disrespect. In one case, someone erased an ancient carving from a rock face using an electric saw. In another, someone dug up a centuries-old ceremonial chamber that had been previously left pristine." The Atlantic, Dec. 30, 2016. The tribal consuls should be consulted before any changes are made to the Bear's Ears National Monument.Some corporations and legislators want the area opened for commercial development or natural-gas extraction. Opening Bear's Ears National Monument to commercial development would further destroy the Native burial grounds and cultural sites and mining, drilling, and similar technologies will disrupt and destroy the environment protected by the Bear's Ears National Monument.

Dear Sir,I am completely and utterly opposed to removing ANY national monuments from the protections afforded to them by their status, and am completely and utterly opposed to using the lands of ANY national monuments, national parks and national forests for any additional corporate or private entity extraction of our natural resources.I call for the reduction in the current levels of allowed corporate and private extraction of our natural resources from all lands associated with our national monuments, national parks and national forests.These lands are unique to our cultural heritage as Americans, to the cultural heritage of our native peoples and should be protected to the greatest degree possible for the benefit of future generations.Thank you,Nancy Fahy

Dear Sirs:The National Monument in Katahdin is a jewel that promises to serve the public, instead of remaining in private hands. A private owner could close the area entirely to the public, subdivide it, or do whatever.The gift of this beautiful land to the nation is one of the most generous gifts for Maine and the nation, for generations to come. The fact it abbuts the Baxter State Park makes this monument even more precious. It is already generating substantial tourist traffic and investor interest in a region that needs it the most after losing paper mills and other factories.I served on the Kennebec Chaudire Commission under Governor King (now Senator) and saw the value of attracting tourism to the interior regions of Maine that are uniquely beautiful. This monument will serve Maine in similar fashion.This monument is unique in that the Quimby family has listened to the local population and allows traditional uses on the land. In addition, the Quimbys are donating millions of dollars for the upkeep of the park. How can anyone even think of refusing that donation????We, as Maine and U.S. Citizens, are most grateful for their generous bequest and wish the rest of the nation to benefit from this unique land preserve.Sincerely Yours,Sylvie CharronProfessor EmeritaUniversity of Maine at Farmington.
DEFEND ALL NATIONAL MONUMENTS!

Do not let our president, who has not spent a day in his gilded life under the wide open sky of nature, or fallen asleep while lying in his sleeping bag under a sky glistening with stars take away these National Parks for the sake of promoting business and his interests.

Do not rescind or shrink any of our existing National Monuments. I encourage the administration to create more. We need open land it is part of being American. The world is becoming a smaller more crowded space. Protected land may just keep us sane.
Do NOT reverse the designation or boundaries of our national monuments. Especially not to access nonrenewable energy sources and destroy the land we should be trying to protect.

Doesn't America have enough money? How large do these corporations have be? Lastly why are you allowing the resources of this country to be looted?The last few months I am seeing the Federal government being destroyed. I do not know if it will ever recover. I think that the trrump presidency is lazy, and working for the lobbyist that they "like". Poor and disabled will be reduced to the lowest standard of living since the Great Depression. Maybe they will call them trumpvilles before the governments destroy them.

DOI Secretary Zinke,"Heaven is under our feet as well as over our heads" Henry David ThoreauThis awareness of our spiritual connection to both the sky and the land is at the very core of my desire to keep the Bears Ears Monument protected and in tact as is. It is my firm belief that the Native Americans are correct and justified in taking action over the past years to preserve these sacred lands. The multi-tribe efforts to initiate dialogue and engage collaboration as a means of protecting the Bears Ears stands as testimony to the land's importance to their culture and all future generations in the United States.This land is finite and when it is desecrated and destroyed it will be gone forever. The price we pay for the immediate "use it up" and make money mentality of the extraction industries is short term gain with a long term negative impact, emotionally and physically for future generations.I urge you to keep the Bears Ears Monument in tact as currently designated.Diane Carpenter

DOI-2017-0002-This is what I believe to be the proper number to comment on Bears Ears.. I did not see my comments in those already posted....Here they are again:Please do it now.... go to https://www.regulations.gov/I am adding my 'voice' to the thousands already 'recorded' and beg you to please 'hear' US and heed what we say:Bears Ears National Monument status must be upheld and preserved forthe sake of Native People, ours, the real tax payers of theU. S. and for future generations to have an unspoiled example of howthis country/land used to be. You would actually be followingBiblical injunctions to let indigenous people return to the land theywere forced to leave. It is far past time to let those who survivedattempted extermination who are now full of determination, to worktogether to preserve and protect and share this sacred area, full ofremnants of their almost completely destroyed heritage.The actual value is far above the monetary/materialrealm. However it is important to recognize that tourists, archeologists, environmentalists, birders, zoologists, botanists, students and many others from all over the world cannot resist the lure of such sites. It is well documented that they flock to experience the unique atmosphere and thus are known to spend lots of money in nearby towns, camp grounds and recreational areas and thus are quite welcome sources of income.Please don't succumb to thegreed of the current administrations corporate fossil fuel and other private capitalist profiteers seeking to 'steal' OUR money and pour it into the bottomless pit of the Pentagon's and misnamed Department of Defense's un-audited war mongering, death dealing budgets. If just a fraction of the trillions of dollars was redirected to the lIfe affirming National Monuments, including Bears Ears, it would sustain their preservation,maintenance and expansion for years to come.I would really appreciate your actual concern for what the majority of us, the real people, want. I hope you pay close attention to every bit of expression of the need formore designations and continuous protection, preservation and maintenance of Bears Ears and all other current National Monuments. Additions to existing sites is also desirable such as the ones Congresswoman Judy Chu has proposed for California's San Gabriel Mountains National Monument.Respectfully submitted,Margot EiserMontebello, CA 90640

Every national monument deserves to be protected. They are here to educate, preserve, and bring people together. I have seen many of the wonderful parks/preserves that are under review. Do not jeopardize what is protected!

Every year I go with friends to the canyon country in Utah. I just returned from 9 days in the Escalante-Grand Staircase National Monument. Last year we were in the Paria Canyon-Vermillion Cliffs National Monument. Next year we plan to backpack in the Bears Ears National Monument. Therefore, I'm deeply concerned about protecting these valuable natural resources for people like me who enjoy the many outdoor activities which these areas provide.More specifically in regard to Bears Ears, I have researched a great deal about this area. It has significant historical, geological, and scientific resources as well as holding many sacred archeological and spiritual sites for the Native American peoples who inhabit and have inhabited the area.Most of the people of Utah support the Bears Ears National Monument and other valuable monuments in their state. These areas preserve the wildness of Utah. The economic future of western states like Utah lie in protecting their natural resources and encouraging tourism, not selling off their public lands for extractive industries like fracking and oil and gas extraction. The economic benefits of protecting these priceless lands and creating a modern, diversified, service-oriented economy. Each year as I visit the various monuments in Utah, I'm struck by how many opportunities there are to enjoy the land protected by these monuments. Hunting, fishing, rafting, caving, rock climbing, backpacking, hiking, birding, guided tours featuring biology, geology, archeology, Flora/Fauna, Paleontology; just to mention a few.It would behoove the DOI to protect the Bears Ears National Monument and not allow a few voices supporting narrow industry views in the short-term to overshadow the long-term benefits of protecting these lands for generations to come.
Federal monuments and lands are to be kept IN PERPETUITY for ALL PEOPLE FOREVER. PERIOD.Don't even think about allowing privatizing or disturbing in any way.

For more than a century, the President of the United States has had the power to unilaterally designate federal lands as a National Monument without the consent of Congress, local governments or affected citizens. National Monument designations, under the Antiquities Act of 1906, are meant to ensure the proper care and management of historic landmarks and other objects of historic or scientific interest. The Act also states that the monuments shall be confined to the smallest area compatible with proper care and management of the objects.In recent decades, presidents from both parties have used the power of the Act to designate hundreds of thousands of acres, and in some cases millions of acres at a time. This scale of designation goes far beyond the executive authority that had Congress originally intended. Such abuse restricts or even prohibits economic opportunity and removes decision making from the states and private citizens. These designations have affected water rights, grazing rights and access to state and private lands.Use of the Antiquities Act for large tract designation does not provide reasonable notice to the public, and has gone well beyond Congress' original intent to designate the smallest portion of land needed to protect certain objects of genuine historic and scientific interest. Because there is no requirement to determine what the impact of the designation would be on communities and the local economy, these executive actions can lead, and in fact have led, to devastating reductions in economic activity and the loss of jobs in resource-dependent communities. We urge the executive branch to discontinue designation of any national monument under the Antiquities Act until the proposal is first vetted and approved by Congress, landowners and local governments affected by these decisions.Since 1906, 145 national monuments have been designated for federal protection. 105 are managed by the National Park Service, 23 by the Bureau of Land Management, 10 by the USDA Forest Service, 7 by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and 1 by NOAA Fisheries.In Oregon, the Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument area must be addressed. The national monument designation of 48,000 additional acres in January 2017 will have devastating effects on the farm, ranch and timber community. The monument, spanning nearly 87,000 acres, links the Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument to the Oregon Caves National Monument and the Siskiyou Wilderness Area.Declaring a Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument appeared to be a good idea to some because it seems to have a positive connotation, but it is fundamentally irresponsible, as it works directly against the best interests of the local environment, community and the very industries that support the local economies.Proponents of the monument maintain it would have no impact on private lands or landowners. Nothing could be further from the truth. The declaration of the monument has had a direct impact on the natural resource industry, which makes up much of the economy in Southern Oregon.In parts of the Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument, the land is checkerboarded, meaning it is intertwined with private property. Other private property is directly adjacent to those federal lands. There is no reasonable or realistic way to expect that those landowners will be able to continue operations as they current exist. Wild areas need to be protected, but maintaining healthy forests and other natural areas over the long haul is a complex process. The taking of an area and a state that is so desperately in need of jobs and dollars it is blatantly irresponsible.Finally, as farmers and ranchers, we care deeply about the land. Not only to we live on the land, we enjoy and depend on it. At a time when we are desperately trying to revive our rural communities, this designation and future possible designations will be a huge stumbling block. If one can't provide for themselves or a family there is no hope of attracting youth back to this area. This has and will continue to further decimate communities across rural Oregon and nationwide.

Grand Staircase-Escalante is one of our favorite "go to" spots here in Utah, both for my family and for visitors from other states who come to visit us. Please do not take it's National Monument status away!Linda Carr-Lee Faix and Roger Faix

Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument is one of the most beautiful wilderness areas in the world. This area should not be opened to any sort of mining at all.I have hiked and photographed in the area since 1978. Keeping the remoteness of the area is paramount. Protect it al all cost.

Grand Staircase-Escalante was designated in 1996. Since then, it has come to be known as the "Crown Jewel of BLM monuments" and the "Science Monument"yielding several new species of dinosaur and other paleontological finds and providing habitat for 650 bee species, many that are endemic to the area.Grand Staircase-Escalante has incredible camping and hiking opportunities, which my husband and I have enjoyed going back to 1997. Places like Calf Creek, Peekaboo and Spooky Canyons, Coyote Gulch, and the Hole in the Rock Road are known the world over.Polling shows more than half of Utahns want Grand Staircase-Escalante left alone.Please protect Grand Staircase-Escalante.
Great trees help us breathe and remind us of our deeper roots. We must save them
Hands off OUR national parks,they belong to the American people,they are not the personal property of a few greedy politicians to sell.

Hands off our parks! We need to boost renewables rather than rape our parks. Our clean air, earth and water depend on it. Our future generations depend on it. Our mental health depends on it. Protect the Parks.

Having spent many days hiking and backpacking in national monuments, especially the Grand-Staircase Escalante and Grand Canyon Parashant, I am opposed to removing their designation as National Monuments. These are invaluable natural landscapes that would be permanently and forever destroyed by mining and development. By destroying the monuments now, you would be cheating your children and grandchildren of some of the few great natural resources left on our planet.Please do not destroy these national monuments.

Hello,I am embarrassed for the leadership of the US federal government and the Department of the Interior for even allowing the review of national monuments. I, along with many friends have lists to visit national parks and monuments. We are a more beautiful nation for having public lands which it's citizens can hike, bike, camp, explore, photograph and where my family has the best memories. We were not a family which ever visited Disney or theme parks but we had our national lands to enjoy. So please keep the lands protected, give me my special place to see new flowers, hike new paths, bond with my family and friends and a place to grow individually. Bear Ears is beautiful and should be enjoyed by all and not owned by a single person. There are so many more sunsets and sunrises to witness over this land.

Hello,I wish to express my deep concern for our national parks and resources. The move by our current president and the Dept of Interiors puts our land, water and other natural resources in danger. We are the stewards of this land and our job is to protect it. I do not agree with the current protections to be under review or to be altered. In fact, we should have more natural resources inder national protection - not less.As a citizen of this nation, I urge you to not withdraw the current protections of our national parks, waterways and other natural resources.Thank you.

Hello, I am writing to voice my strong opposition to any review that would lead to the dissolution or diminishing of any public lands or national monuments, including sale to state or private entities. As a tourist to Utah and other states in which national monuments exist, I have found communities that depend on public lands and national monuments for jobs and income in tourism and recreation.Furthermore, the federal (and only federal) administration of public lands is the tradition and policy that will ensure that public lands remain the birthright of all Americans for generations to come. Shrinking or dissolving national monuments in the interest of political convenience or short term profits would be a fool's errand and an abhorrence to our forefathers who toiled to protect America's greatest treasures.Thank you,Garrett O'Brien

Hello! I am writing in support of maintaining the current state of our nation's National Monuments. I believe the long-term, future benefit of protecting these beautiful areas in their natural (or close to natural) state outweighs many fold the short-term benefit that may be gained from revoking their protections. One of the things that makes the US such a beautiful country is our wilderness areas of all kinds. Please please protect these for the coming generations of America to partake in and enjoy. Thank you.
How can you condone this. It is a land grab by politicians to make public lands available for exploitation in an increasingly fragile wild United States. Please don't do thisEric Simonsen

I absolutely do not support any reductions or changes to existing national monuments. Any rollback or reduction of these areas would open up not only damaging resource extraction practices, but would also set a dangerous precedent for how all our public lands may be viewed and managed in the future. National monuments should be preserved in perpetuity for public enjoyment and environmental protection.

I advocate protecting as much of our wild lands as is possible. I have traveled extensively through many areas of the U.S. and it's sad to see so many areas desecrated by development, oil exploration, and other travesties against the environment. These areas cannot be replaced once they are destroyed, unless humans go extinct, which is certainly a possibility these days, due to disrespect of natural wonders. At least let us enjoy these areas while we still can! Sometimes I'm thankful I don't have grandchildren, because we aren't leaving much of a world for the next generations to enjoy.

I am 67 years old and thanks to my parents love of road trips I have visted many of our National Parks, Monuments, and Forrest. As an adult I have shared the beauty of these wonderful places with my child and later my granddaughter. I hope to visit with my 2 great grandsons. Our National Monuments are a priceless gift to future generations. Their beauty and natural slendor are awe inspiring. Nothing preserves our heritage as Americans like these irreplaceable wonders of nature. I pray that these Monuments will continue to exist forever as symbols of this country.

I am a 61 year-old lifelong camper, backpacker, and serious hiker. I climbed Kilimanjaro in 2015 and trekked in New Zealand earlier this year. I grew up in Kansas and spent the summers of my youth in the wilds of Colorado, much of it in National Monument properties. In the last ten years, I have hiked extensively in Southern Utah and now consider the area the crown jewel of the American West. The varied terrain, the history, the incredible sandstone formations are not duplicated anywhere else in the world. While I enjoy the National Parks, I find them to be too crowded. I much prefer BLM and National Monument properties where a little effort gets you into pristine wilderness. An example is Coyote Buttes North and South which straddle the Utah/Arizona state line west of Page. This area resembles a lunar landscape. And I could go on and on.As you can see, I highly value the National Monument and BLM properties and as a taxpayer and avid user, am very supprtive of any and all efforts to protect these irreplaceable lands. I am not thinking so much of myself but of my children and grandchildren and future generations. Thankfully, Teddy Roosevelt had foresight to protect Federal lands. That is why many of the fellow hikers I encounter are from foreign countries where they have nothing like we do in America. I appreciate any and all efforts to continue our sacred tradition and protect our National Monument properties. Thank you.Mark ZuercherOrinda, California

I am a conservative American writing to ask that you preserve ALL current national monuments, including Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument in Maine, Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine Monument off New England, and Papahānaumokuākea Marine Monument off Hawaii. These national monuments are an important part of our American heritage and must be fully protected.National monuments are a Republican idea. A Republican wrote the Antiquities Act (the law that authorizes monument designation), a Republican controlled congress passed it, and a Republican president, Theodore Roosevelt, signed it into law. Rolling back monument protections would be an unprecedented move to undermine that GOP legacy.Like Secretary Zinke, I am an unabashed conservative admirer of Theodore Roosevelt. He recognized that to adequately safeguard our natural and cultural heritage we often have to protect large areas. Roosevelt himself used the Antiquities Act to safeguard the 1.2 million acre Grand Canyon.That is why I am asking Secretary Zinke and the Trump Administration to honor his legacy and hold fast to his values by upholding the protection of existing national monuments in their entirety. These special places represent America's natural and cultural heritage protecting them is our moral duty.Please do not bow to the wishes of anti-public land zealots like Senator Hatch and Congressman Rob Bishop. These lawmakers represent narrow special interests, not the people of Utah. The truth is that national monuments are proven economic drivers that enjoy broad public support, even in Utah. Contrary to claims by Hatch and Bishop, recent polling shows that a majority of Utahans support the recently established Bears Ears National Monument.Please stand with TR and safeguard our national monuments. These special pieces of our national heritage that deserve all of the protections they currently have under the Antiquities Act.

I am a conservative American writing to ask that you preserve ALL current national monuments, including Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument in Maine, Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine Monument off New England, and Papahānaumokuākea Marine Monument off Hawaii. These national monuments are an important part of our American heritage and must be fully protected.National monuments are a Republican idea. These special pieces of our national heritage that deserve all of the protections they currently have under the Antiquities Act.

I am a huge fan of the Antiquities Act of 1906, I enjoy having national monuments and lands set aside for the masses to enjoy. I think every decision since 1996 is valid and justified, whether a new designation or an expansion. I do not think denying the public masses of these lands to cater to minority special interests is ever a good way to conduct business. I have voted along party lines in the past but the current administration has already changed this. In the future I will look into each candidate and their stance on environmental issues. If they are not good stewards of our lands and resources they will not only not receive my vote, but they will become the focus of a very vocal opposition.

I am a New Mexico resident and I am thrilled with our National Monuments, including the more recent designations for Organ Mountains - Desert Peaks and Rio Grande del Norte. My husband and I visited the Rio Grande del Norte last fall and had a wonderful time hiking trails that skirted the river and the confluence with other tributaries. It was beautiful, as all National Monuments are, in its own unique way.I am disheartened by efforts to review the designation of recent National Monuments to appease special interests. This tarnishes a gift that benefits and belongs to all Americans.

I am a resident of New Mexico and have spent much time in backcountry BLM lands and national monuments in NM, UT, CO and AZ.Do not shrink the size or extent of the protections of the existing National Monuments, including (but not limited to) Bears Ears, Escalante, Rio Del Norte and the Organ Mountains. I have visited all of these places and others should have the same opportunity. Preserving these shared lands is an obligation we owe as Americans, most effectively done via our federal government.Altering the current protected status would only serve to temporarily enrich a few special interests, while causing permanent damage to irreplaceable landscapes, ecosystems, ancestral and historic sites that belong to everyone. These lands are invaluable in their current state, and industry has done fine without significant commercial development of them thus far. For these sorts, there will never be enough, until it is all gone. Current political and economic profiteering which seeks short-term, exclusive gain is nothing more than snake oil salesmanship. Short-term profit cannot compare with the long term value of these lands when left largely untouched.The States alone cannot afford to protect these lands, which belong to all Americans, and it is our shared responsibility to preserve them. I have seen first-hand the destruction when such land is leased for income. Commercial "development," such as mining, obliterates the landscape into bizarre, barren debris, leaving nothing behind but a lot of toxic tailings and NO JOBS.It is also inexcusable to allow for the continued misunderstanding by the public that these lands were "taken" from private landholders by the government, instead of the reality, that these monuments were established to further protect pre-existing federal lands or lands that were voluntarily sold or granted to the government by agreement for the express purpose of obtaining federal protections.

I am a resident of Utah and greatly believe in reserving land for preservation. Please leave the national monuments as they are. Future generations should be able to have the opportunity to appreciate the beauty of our land.

I am a strong proponent of the National Parks and National Monuments. They preserve our history and our lands for future generations. The idea of selling off or closing them is just plain wrong.I am in favor of restoring budgets to both National Parks and National Monument for much needed staff and repairs. The repair list is very long and has been ignored and some parks and NM sites have serious repair issues.The recent pay freeze and the cuts for employees is also a very bad idea. I worked at Death Valley over the winter as a volunteer and could see the need for staff and repair money. Repair project such as Scotty's Castle will take much longer the way the money is being doled out in small chunks and then not having enough staff to proceed with the repairs is also very bad.As a volunteer for the parks I have had the privilige of working there beside many fine and intelligent people. TO lose those quality people should not be allowed to happen. They work hard with little help from Washington DC and there is a burn out level that is fast approaching.My wife and i will continue to volunteer as it is some of the best times of our lives,

I am a Utahn in favor of Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument, Bears Ears National Monument, Nevada's Basin and Range National Monument, and all other monuments being reviewed. Secretary Zinke has not given adequate time to both sides of the discussion and has instead spent most of his time in Utah visiting with anti-monument Republicans. He did not give equal time to meeting with Native Americans, nor did he meet at all with the Boulder-Escalante Chamber of Commerce. These monuments have well-documented economic benefits which anti-monument arguments conveniently ignore or reject. The monuments were created with careful planning and after other attempts were unsuccessful, not rammed through as other arguments claim. I have grown up scrambling up mountains in the Basin and Range National Monument and wading in Calf's Creek in Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument: these areas must have protections so that not only my children but everyone who wishes can experience the same wonder from the beauty of American lands. Do not remove any existing protections that these national monuments have.Truthfully though, my arguments are not the reason you should keep all existing monuments intact. The reason you should keep all existing monuments is because Native Americans--like the Navajo, Hopi, Zuni, Ute Mountain Ute, and Uintah Ouray Ute--have requested these protections due to the sacred and historic nature of the area, as well as the many artifacts which remain there and are at risk. My voice should not be on an equal scale as theirs, which must be considered with the utmost respect and gravity. Overwhelmingly, they want these monuments. Listen to them, for once.

I am absolutely opposed to reversing any of the National Monument Designations at any of the sites listed. I am absolutely opposed to opening these sites for any transaction other then restoration or upkeep of these sites. National Monuments and Parks are a legacy that we leave our children and are more important then momentary gain or business development.

I am appalled that our treasured national parks and monuments, like the Bears Ears National Monument, are up for review at all.Bears Ears is one of our nation's newest monuments -- the American people are very lucky to now call this ancient site covering an expanse of 1.3 million acres a public resource protected for future generations. The monument protects ancient sites that are sacred to the Native American tribes in southern Utah's red-rock country.Utah is greatly enriched by the Bears Ears National Monument. Bears Ears National Monument also provides incredible spaces for outdoor activities-- it is one of best places in the world for rock climbing and bouldering. These public lands need to stay in public hands.No president has EVER attempted to abolish a national monument, and an attack on one park is an attack on all our parks. Secretary Zinke, I am adamantly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for Bears Ears or any other national monument, and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.

I am concerned that the greed of our American Corporations are influencing our history protections of open lands and monuments that were created on the spirit of our great nation and national leaders. If we allow this to happen, we will be doom and be the cause of world wide chaos. Just look at other countries that are killing off species of animals, land and natural habitats. Once we do this, the human race will surely perish as our oceans and our water supply vanishes because of the almighty dollar. We need to protect our historic and monumental parks and open spaces. Money should not be the ultimate deciding factor. Greed should not accompany decisions. We need to focus on our own infrastructures, old buildings, commercial plots, and places that have deteriorated over time. Not our wilderness that our great past leaders recognized as important places for the human health and vitality. We we were blessed with these magnificent places for future generations as my grand children and their children will enjoy. If we ever suffered a tremendous disaster, where would people go? It can happen, just look at other places, mud slides, floods, fires, earthquakes and WAR. I am sadden that our forefathers and past presidents are being reduced to nothing great. I am sadden that our Present President has no clue into this matter. I am sadden that the buck doesn't stop there. Please stop this madness. If we continue on this path of drilling, mining, developing, we as a human race will surely die and leave nothing but destruction for the future. Once you change the geographical beauty of our earth, you cannot bring it back. Backward thinking is not the solution. Who will be watching these greedy corps and others while they destroy our American heritage.

I am for undoing the Bears Ears National Monument and reducing the size of the Grand Staircase National Monument. Neither of these designations took into account the smallest amount of land needed to appropriately protect treasured areas in Southern Utah. Many throughout the nation do not realize that these designated areas are huge, larger than some of the actual states in the United States. While parts are exceptionaly beautiful much of the land is simply sage and juniper, simply not in any need of protection. It does have great multiple use potential and was used appropriately for this before the designation. In the past, the area surrounding Escalante supported families, many who were able to live there for generations. They cared for the land, and loved it. Now with tourism becoming the main source of income the main jobs involve housekeeping, waitressing and similar positions. They do not not provide for families. Families have moved away, the schools are shrinking and this spells the end of functioning communities. This does not need to happen. Keeping the ares under BLM protection provides for the multiple use for all and certainly does not mean the end of the scenic vistas so valued by visitors. Certain voices only provide part of the story and twist the facts to accomplish their desired outcome. The careful and lawfull process used by the elected Representatives of the State of Utah to protect this land listened to all voices and has come to a common sense conclusion taking into account the needs of those most affected. This is the voice that should be valued. My husband and I lived in Garfield County for years, and still visit often. We are very familiar with the area and saw the destructive consequences of the poorly planned and political designation of the Grand Staircase National Monument. The designation of National Monuments should never become a political move. Thank you for your consideration.

i am horrified at the blatant attempts by the trump administration to destroy all legal protections of natural wonders that previous presidents and congresses have seen fit to enact for future generations. it appears to me that if it isn't made of steel and glass, and it doesn't generate megaprofits for megacompanies. trumpdom has slated it for extinction. i suppose a man who came from the canyons of new york city, whose idea of nature is a manicured golf course, would not appreciate the priceless beauty of a place like bears ears. but this turns my stomach. add the gutting of the epa, the assault on the scientific community who refuses to submit to politics, the refusal to acknowledge the fact of global warming, the abandonment of the paris accords, and the complete disregard for native american (excuse me - all americans) rights to an unpoisoned safe environment and i am truly scared. this greedy megalomaniac can do damage that can never be repaired. didn't we learn our lesson with hetch hetchy? add my voice to the cries of horror from all who love the fragile, yet majestic beauty of unspoiled nature, created by powers far greater than puny humans: STOP! gaia, the earth, is your mother! what are you thinking? is money really all you care about? what of future generations who you deprive of this precious heritage that should be their birthright as american citizens? i scream at you: STOP!!! YOU HAVE NO RIGHT!!!! these places are not your private property to destroy at your whim to enrich further your already filthy rich buddies in big business!!! SSSTTTOPPP!!!!!

I am in love with all our public lands and think we need more, not less. The proposals to mess with the water-based monuments are especially scary. Please do everything you can to protect these treasures.

i am not a citizen of Utah. I am an American and have been to Utah. This is a very fragile and beautiful part of this country. Escalante National Monument is Federal land , that belongs to every citizen of this country. any assault on that land is an assault against all Americans. The state of Utah does not speak for all Americans and tha Interior Dept. is supposed to represent all Americans. Leave our National Monuments alone

I am not in favor of changing current use options for national monuments. They should be protected and preserved for all future generations to enjoy with minimal impact from hunting, oil, development, farming, etc. I am an Arizona resident that loves to explore all the national parks, state parks, and national monuments in the West to learn about our diverse history and reconnect with nature. Please continue to protect our most valuable resource.
I am not in favor of returning these lands to the private sector. It is very important that these beautiful spaces remain public lands for all to enjoy.

I am opposed to any alterations to Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve.Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historic, cultural and natural heritage. I strongly urge you to maintain the size of and protections for our national monuments, including Craters of the Moon in Idaho.Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve protects some of the best and most exposed examples of volcanic basalt rock in the world. The national park's distinctive landscape has many lava tubes and cinder cones and was used for the training of American astronauts in preparation for future trips to the moon.Originally designated by President Coolidge in 1924, the monument was expanded by President Clinton in 2000 and partially designated a national preserve by Congress in 2002. Today, over 250,000 park visitors are spending an estimated $8.9 million in local gateway regions while visiting Craters of the Moon.An attack on one of America's national monuments is an attack on all of them. I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Craters of the Moon or any one of our country's national monuments.Thank you for considering my views.

I am opposed to any alterations to Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument.Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historic, cultural and natural heritage. I strongly urge you to maintain the size of and protections for our national monuments, including Grand Staircase-Escalante in Utah.Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument is home to colorful badlands, sagebrush basins, remote ridges dotted with pinyon pine and a natural quiet seldom found in the lower 48 states. The Grand Staircase connects three major national park sites, protecting the ruggedly beautiful landscapes and maintaining wildlife habitats between Bryce Canyon National Park, Capitol Reef National Park and Glen Canyon National Recreation Area.An attack on one of America's national monuments is an attack on all of them. I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Grand Staircase-Escalante or any one of our country's national monuments.Thank you for considering my views.

I am opposed to any alterations to Mojave Trails or Sand to Snow National Monuments.Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historic, cultural and natural heritage. In light of your department's review period, I strongly urge you to maintain the size of and protections for all of our national monuments as they were originally designated, including Mojave Trails and Sand to Snow National Monuments in California.For nearly 20 years, supporters across the California desert and beyond have urged for the protection of areas of cultural and historic significance, critical wildlife corridors and lands rich in recreational values. This support ultimately led to the designation of Castle Mountains, Mojave Trails and Sand to Snow National Monuments.The monuments connect lands between Death Valley and Joshua Tree National Parks and Mojave National Preserve and form the second-largest desert preserve in the world, home to Native American spiritual and archaeological sites, Historic Route 66, pioneer trails, iconic desert wildlife corridors and unusual geologic formations.An attack on one of America's national monuments is an attack on all of them. I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Mojave Trials, Sand to Snow or any one of our country's national monuments.Thank you for considering my views.

I am opposed to any alterations to Mojave Trails or Sand to Snow National Monuments.Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historic, cultural and natural heritage. In light of your department's review period, I strongly urge you to maintain the size of and protections for all of our national monuments as they were originally designated, including Mojave Trails and Sand to Snow National Monuments in California.For nearly 20 years, supporters across the California desert and beyond have urged for the protection of areas of cultural and historic significance, critical wildlife corridors and lands rich in recreational values. This support ultimately led to the designation of Castle Mountains, Mojave Trails and Sand to Snow National Monuments.The monuments connect lands between Death Valley and Joshua Tree National Parks and Mojave National Preserve and form the second-largest desert preserve in the world, home to Native American spiritual and archaeological sites, Historic Route 66, pioneer trails, iconic desert wildlife corridors and unusual geologic formations.An attack on one of America's national monuments is an attack on all of them. I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Mojave Trials, Sand to Snow or any one of our country's national monuments.Thank you for considering my views.

I am opposed to any alterations to Mojave Trails or Sand to Snow National Monuments.Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historic, cultural and natural heritage. In light of your department's review period, I strongly urge you to maintain the size of and protections for all of our national monuments as they were originally designated, including Mojave Trails and Sand to Snow National Monuments in California.For nearly 20 years, supporters across the California desert and beyond have urged for the protection of areas of cultural and historic significance, critical wildlife corridors and lands rich in recreational values. This support ultimately led to the designation of Castle Mountains, Mojave Trails and Sand to Snow National Monuments.The monuments connect lands between Death Valley and Joshua Tree National Parks and Mojave National Preserve and form the second-largest desert preserve in the world, home to Native American spiritual and archaeological sites, Historic Route 66, pioneer trails, iconic desert wildlife corridors and unusual geologic formations.An attack on one of America's national monuments is an attack on all of them. I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Mojave Trials, Sand to Snow or any one of our country's national monuments.Thank you for considering my views.

I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Mojave Trials, Sand to Snow or any one of our country's national monuments.Thank you for considering my views.

I am opposed to any attempts to rescind or alter the size of Mojave Trials, Sand to Snow or any one of our country's national monuments.And what I wrote before in my previous e-mail about continuing to protect our national monuments and public lands, and having a future of this planet for all that exist on it.Thank you for considering my views.
