I am opposed to the increasing appropriation of land by the federal gov't under the guise of "national monuments."The people of America are the national monuments of this country.I do not oppose monuments, but their geographic scope should be very limited in order that the majority of land remains for the citizens to purchase and use for their purposes.I have noticed that the federal gov't has been making most of its huge land grabs in the West--why not declare all of the area of the 13 original colonies as a national monument?! It would disenfranchise people, that's why: remove from them their property, their means of livelihood, their freedom. Well, it does the same thing in the West.

I am opposed to the reduction in size of any of the National Monuments listed for review. "I believe that the natural resources must be used for the benefit of all our people, and not monopolized for the benefit of the few," as Theodore Roosevelt said. It is clear to me that reducing the size or protections of these public lands is for the benefit of companies who wish to profit from the gas, oil or water that are found in these areas. I am outraged to hear that the Gadiz Water Project is seeking to drain the aquaifer underneath the Mojave Trails National Monument. These lands and the natural resourses contained within and beneath them need to be protected from short-sighted exploitation and destruction.

I am outraged that President Trump is considering stripping protections from the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument -- the only marine monument in the Atlantic Ocean -- and from dozens of other national monuments.The canyons and seamounts monument is home to endangered whales, sea birds, ancient corals and thousands of species of rare and unique wildlife, which are threatened by industrial fishing, oil drilling, climate change and other dangers.Please stand strong against President Trump's attempt to roll back protections for this important national monument, and fulfill the mission of your agency by protecting all of America's national monuments for the good of the American people, not corporations and polluters.

I am sending this email to you to voice my support to protect the monuments and parks that fall under the Antiquities Act of 1906 - the act responsible for so many of our wonderful parks and monuments, created by President Teddy Roosevelt - that allows so many veterans and their families to recreate.We must protect the Antiquities Act and the extraordinary lands it has protected over the years. Personally I want my grandchildren to be able to visit these places and to enjoy them in their natural unmarred state as I have been able to.

I am stating my support for keeping the designation for Bears Ears as a National Monument.With reference to the designation criteria I would like to highlight the historical importance of the preservation of Bears Ears. The ancient buildings and pictographs within Bears Ears are incredible and are on par with Mesa Verde, which is protected as a National Park.More generally, as a Utah resident I want to mention the economic benefits of preserving public lands such as Bears Ears and Grand Staircase Escalante with National Monument status. People from across the country, and the world, visit southern Utah to see our amazing landscapes that are protected as National Parks and Monuments. The residents of southern Utah that feed, house, transport, equip, and guide these visitors are dependent on the continued protected status of these lands for their livelihood. I urge you to assist these visitors and workers by continuing the protection of these priceless resources.Sincerely,Simon Currie

I am submitting comment as a journalist who works with environmental and cultural heritage tourism issues; a publisher who is based in communities that directly benefit from some of the national monuments under review and whose publications and television series include in our coverage; the former president of the California Deserts VIsitors Association; and, a parent and grandparent with a long history of benefiting from our national parks, national monuments, and public lands.I strongly object to this review, the grounds upon which the "need" for this review is being conducted, the manner in which this review is being conducted, the false statements used to justify the supposed need for this review (ie: not enough public comment, etc., when there was extensive public comment - we call this "lying" where I come from), and the stance that a current president even has standing to dismantle national monuments designated under previous presidential administrations.Our current president appears to believe that our public lands belong to him to do with as he pleases, to lease or sell for natural resource extraction as a favor to the oil/gas, or mining industries. His agendas are transparent to anyone paying attention, and as this president has virtually no relationship with, nor appreciation for, our public lands as anything other than a way to curry favor with industry and special interests, he has no interest in their natural or cultural value. None. He would be happy to sell them off, or permanently destroy them by fracking, drilling, and open pit mining, letting the taxpayer pick up the tab for any attempts at mitigation after these lands have been ruined.This is simply unacceptable on all levels. From Bears Ears to Sand to Snow, these monuments have been studied, planned, discussed, and contemplated. At a time when preservation of our natural and cultural/historical resources needs to be a priority, we simply cannot allow this rogue president to strip the work of previous presidents so he can push his own agenda.As an American, it is of vital importance to me that our federal government works to preserve these national monuments to support the natural ecosystems they protect, the wildlife dependent upon them, the historical sites and culturally significant areas contained within them. It is of utmost importance that Native American cultural, historical, and sacred sites are respected and protected, and these are not sites that can be isolated and kept out of context of their surroundings. There are numerous aspects to preservation of these lands that must be taken into consideration that the president himself either cannot grasp, or simply dismisses out of gross ignorance and blatant pandering. He simply cannot be allowed to destroy the work other presidents have done to preserve these national public treasures.To allow such reversal and destruction of these national monuments is the true definition of obscenity. As someone who lives among these lands, draws strength from their beauty and richness, has gotten to know and understand how much they have to offer, and wants to ensure my grandchildren and the grandchildren of other Americans grow up in an America where our natural and cultural treasures are not treated like commodities, raped of their monetary value and left behind as wastelands, I simply must insist that the president's agenda must be halted. Our national monuments up for "review" must be left intact. Our president, whose idea of experiencing nature is to play golf, must have his ignorance and lack of appreciation for real wild lands and areas of Native cultural significance, as well as historic importance, take a back seat to preserving these lands for Americans now, and into the future.These reviews must be halted, and if not by those hired by the American people to manage these lands responsibly, then through the courts and the court of public opinion. I will do all I can personally and professionally to frustrate this administration's highhanded abuse of these national monuments. This is simply, and utterly, unacceptable. It is something I must object to in every way possible, from a deep level. For once these places have been allowed to be raped and destroyed for profit, there is no getting them back. Ever. And our president would never even notice they were gone. But he will not be in office long, and it is imperative the Department of the Interior, and the American people, prevent him from wreaking havoc while he is in office. If there is to be a review, let it run for four years without resolution so the next president can halt it and let sanity return to federal decision making.

I am writing about Bear's Ears National Mounument. There is no reason to abandon this site -- it is exquisite landscape and one that should be protected for all future generations. This, and others on the chopping block, need to be retained. Our populations continue to grow and we need wild and beautiful places in which to restore our souls in.Keep Bear's Ears National Monument. This is a no-brainer.Penny Otwell

I am writing AGAIN as my first set of comments, it seems, are not heard by my government. My husband AND myself are OPPOSED to a change in the BEARS EAR national monument designation.ALONG with OPPOSITION TO CHANGES IN THIS DESIGNATION: we also OPPOSE changes to ANY of our designated public lands and National Monuments.We want our government to PROTECT OUR PUBLIC LANDS FOR ALL.RAYMOND AND KRISTI GIBBS98036

I am writing in particular about the Katahdin Woods of Maine. This was a magnificent, generous gift that there was plenty of discussion about before it was made. It has already produced more tourism for the area and even people who were originally opposed to it have recently asked Governor LePage to back down from his opposition because we see positive results. Please do not send our progress backwards because of our shortsighted governor.

I am writing in response to executive order 13792.I do not support revisiting the status of national monuments established since 1996. One of America's most amazing features is the incredible diversity of our natural landscapes. We have amazing natural resources, and fortunately we started preserving much of it (especially in the west) very early.Visiting national monuments and national parks is one of my favorite pastimes. I've had the good fortune to visit at least one of the national monuments under reconsideration - Giant Sequoia. I visited during graduate school, and it was simply awe-inspiring. Please do not further endanger these majestic trees.As my children get older (currently 2 and 4 years old), I can't wait to share the beauty of their country with them. Please do not reconsider the status of beautiful places that have already been protected. Americans are creative and innovative, and can meet our energy needs without plundering our most precious outdoor spaces.

I am writing in response to the Department of the Interior's request for comments on recently formed national monuments. I support the designation of these public lands as national monuments, and encourage the Department to maintain their existing boundaries and improve access for bicycles.Public lands such as national monuments play an instrumental role in supporting outdoor recreation. While these activities, including bike riding, are of personal significance to me as a bike rider's daughter, they are also critical to local economies in the communities that surround these monuments. Bike riding alone supports $88 billion in economic activity and provides $12 billion in federal, state and local taxes each year. Without quality places to ride on our public lands, these contributions are at serious risk.Some of the monuments that are subject to the Department's review provide bike riding opportunities. Of particular importance are Ironwood Forest (AZ), Sonoran Desert (AZ), Berryessa Snow Mountain (CA), San Gabriel Mountains (CA), Canyons of the Ancients (CO), Basin and Range (NV), Bears Ears (UT) and Grand Staircase-Escalante (UT). New opportunities for riding are also being considered in Sand to Snow (CA), Katahdin Woods (ME), Gold Butte (NV), Rio Grande del Norte (NV) and Cascade Siskiyou (OR). Many of these areas provide unique opportunities to explore cultural and natural resources that cannot be replicated. I encourage the Department to recommend that these lands be maintained as national monuments, and ensure that existing and planned bike riding opportunities in these locations be created and improved.Thank you for considering my comments.

I am writing in support of Browns Canyon National Monument and to comment on the Review of National Monuments currently underway.In Colorado, Browns Canyon National Monument protects exceptional fishing and recreation resources. The popularity and productivity of the Arkansas River has earned 102 miles of the river Gold Medal status, a class bestowed to only a handful of waters in Colorado. Browns Canyon not only conserves an important stretch of this river, but it provides ample public access for recreation, including fishing, rafting and hiking. The size of Browns Canyon National Monument is the minimum to support these resources of significant value to local communities, hunters and anglers, and businesses.Browns Canyon was designated as a national monument with broad support and as a locally-driven conservation initiative. As national monuments, public lands such as those included in the Browns Canyon National Monument will help to sustain our outdoor traditions for future generations of sportsmen and women. National monuments are a part of our public land heritage that deserve to be celebrated, not jeopardized.I oppose any efforts to rescind or diminish Browns Canyon or any other national monument. Instead, I hope that the Department of the Interior will help to ensure the sound management of our nation's public lands by defending our national monuments and supporting the responsible use of the Antiquities Act.

I am writing in support of Browns Canyon National Monument and to comment on the Review of National Monuments currently underway.In Colorado, Browns Canyon National Monument protects exceptional fishing and recreation resources. The popularity and productivity of the Arkansas River has earned 102 miles of the river Gold Medal status, a class bestowed to only a handful of waters in Colorado. Browns Canyon not only conserves an important stretch of this river, but it provides ample public access for recreation, including fishing, rafting and hiking. The size of Browns Canyon National Monument is the minimum to support these resources of significant value to local communities, hunters and anglers, and businesses.Browns Canyon was designated as a national monument with broad support and as a locally-driven conservation initiative. As national monuments, public lands such as those included in the Browns Canyon National Monument will help to sustain our outdoor traditions for future generations of sportsmen and women. National monuments are a part of our public land heritage that deserve to be celebrated, not jeopardized.I oppose any efforts to rescind or diminish Browns Canyon or any other national monument. Instead, I hope that the Department of the Interior will help to ensure the sound management of our nation's public lands by defending our national monuments and supporting the responsible use of the Antiquities Act.

I am writing in support of the Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument in Maine. The monument protects tens of thousands of acres of vital habitat from development and hunting. We just got this park and the public, even many who initially resisted, have settled on taking advantage of this opportunity for tourism and business growth. Thanks for your time and consideration.Leslie Linder, Penobscot, Maine (zip 04476)

I am writing this comment in favor of keeping all monuments in tact and complete. There is no reason to change them or even review them. This entire process is a waste of taxpayer money. Countless hours went into the crafting of these monuments, there is no need for review. The current monuments are all beautiful places that need protection from mining, logging, drilling, grazing and development. They should be left in as close to their natural state as possible so that all people can enjoy them for generations to come. They must remain under the control of the federal government because they are owned and enjoyed by the entire nation, not just the people in adjacent states.The antiquities act should remain in force so that more monuments can be designated and more wild places can be protected. The only thing I would consider changing in Bears Ears National Monument, if anything should be changed at all, is to make it a national park to eliminate grazing. Grazing is an inefficient use of land and it is incredibly destructive to desert lands.I have spent countless hours walking through many of these monuments and I can attest to their beauty and the need to keep them as they are. The ones that I have not seen, I would like to remain in tact because one day I would like to have a chance to see them in their natural state. I would like to share them and enjoy them with my nieces and their children. I would like all the people in this nation, their children and their children's children to have access to these beautiful placesSadly, from what I can see of the monuments I am familiar with, you are considering the ones near oil, natural gas and mining possibilities. These monuments were created to prevent just that. These industries are destructive and focused on profit for the few. Any jobs created would be short lived in comparison to the recreation industry and jobs created by the existence of the monuments themselves. These are long term jobs as long as the monuments remain in tact and protected. Once you drill or mine or graze or frack, there is little left to enjoy. I lived near a mining super fund site, there is no such thing as clean up. The company went bankrupt and left the area a toxic mess. One day the toxic chemicals will enter the water table if a solution is not found and funded. Is that the future we want for our beautiful places?Headwaters Economics of Bozeman, Montana is an independent, non-partisan research company. Their specialty is economics and according to their studies, people living near monuments, parks and other protected lands on average make more money and enjoy a higher standard of living. Here is there website url (https://headwaterseconomics.org/). I suggest you contact them and look into their studies on economics and the west. Here is one great example of a study that shows the long term gains of protected lands in the west. (https://headwaterseconomics.org/public-lands/federal-lands-performance/)Thank you for your time. I would highly recommend that we protect these monuments, add more monuments, turn some of the existing monuments into national parks, and protect every single one of them completely and unconditionally.

I am writing to beg that our National Monuments be saved. My family and I have visited many of these lands through the years. We have gained historical insight, inspiration and wonder. We have been so lucky to have been able to visit these special places. I know that the first deadline is on the Bear Ears National Monument. We have been to those lands many times. There are wonderful ruins and sacred places that are found there. It would be a tragedy to ruin them forever. These are the peoples lands. They don't belong only to commercial entities to use to extract resources. I ask again for you to consider what you are doing and to keep these national treasures for all of this country's citizens.Thank YouJudie Dobner15820 NE 141st PlWoodinville, WA. 98072

I am writing to express my disapproval of the DOI's review of National Monuments Established Since 1996. In particular, I am commenting relative to Bears Ears National Monument in Utah. This National Monument was established in 2016 after then President Obama established its creation. This designation was done thoughtfully and carefully after understanding the cultural and natural history of the region including over 1000 cultural sites associated with Native America Tribes in the region which were being destroyed by the uses of the land. The designation of the area as a monument allows for oversight and protection of these historical sites. At the time of its designation, additional lands had been requested to be included by tribes and others but were ultimately excluded to find balance between the interest of protection under the antiquities act and public access.In addition to its protection of cultural and natural history, the designation as a monument ensures that the general public will have, unless this administration abuses its power and reverses the designation, access to 1.35M acres of land for recreational and access to the cultural history of the tribes of Southern Utah instead of the land being destroyed and access limited by companies with commercial or personal objectives to exploit and destroy these natural resources for short-term profit. Though I have not yet been able to enjoy Bears Ears personally, as an avid hiker and outdoors man, this national monument is on my list for future visits when I have the opportunity to next vacation in Southern Utah.In summary, I oppose this administrations attempts to remove National Monument Status from Bears Ears National Monument and request that its designation be left in place. Protect the public lands and cultural historic sites not commercialized them. You are the Department of Interior not the Department of Commerce. Act like it.

I am writing to express my support for Bears Ears National Monument. I would like to make several points. 1) The Monument encompasses extensive historic and prehistoric structures that would not be adequately protected if the Monument did not exist or was a smaller size. 2) Extensive public outreach and coordination with relevant stakeholders was conducted before the proclamation of Bears Ears National Monument.

I am writing to oppose opening national monuments to energy development. Executive order 13792. Americans are creative and can meet energy needs withoutdestroying the purity of wild space. the assumption that our national monument aren't profitable is false. Annually, the oudoor recreation economy supports 7.8 million jobs and generates $887 billion in consumer spending.Our national parks and preserves were set up to protect these timeless institutions from the effects of greed. everyone should be able to see and enjoy these wonderful feats of nature. We need protected space. . Our citizens did not wasn't tax dollars going for more military spending, when citizens won't have adime to protect everything we love about this country.

I am writing to oppose opening the 27 National Monuments to commercial use, such as logging or mining. These properties belong to nation and its citizens. No private gain should be allowed from national resources. These areas were set aside for the enjoyment of all, not the profit of a few. Please, protect our national treasures from desecration. We will not get any more.

I am writing to oppose the de-listing and/or de-regulation of ANY of our National Monuments, most especially Bears Ears and Grand Staircase / Escalante. These two wild places are significant environments for unique wildlife and are the repository of thousands of Native American artifacts and and important, historic fossil remains. This wildlife and these artifacts are irreplaceable and need protection. I visited Bears Ears a few years ago and hiked to the most remarkable cliff dwellings. It was breathtaking. Just recently, I visited Grand Staircase / Escalante, and again, it it a remarkable, extraordinary place.Americans have always fiercely supported wild places and wilderness values; the National Park movement started in this county. Even those who cannot get to wild places and National Parks and Monuments support them; they are valuable to Americans, just knowing they exist. Americans are also visiting National Parks and Monuments in record numbers. These places are becoming over-crowded. WE DON'T NEED FEWER PARKS AND MONUMENTS; WE NEED MORE! Americans obviously love them and treasure going to such places.We also do not need to open such magnificent places to gas and oil development. We have enough other places to obtain the gas and oil we need. We should protect wild places and OUR COUNTRY from climate change by discouraging use of oil and gas as much as possible. This country and the rest of the world must become independent of the need for oil and gas. While we will always need some oil and gas; we should leave as much as possible in reserve for future generations and quit our ridiculous and greedy consumption. The science is clear and EPA and the Department of Interior should lead the charge to reduce climate change emissions.

I am writing to urge the continued protection and National Monument status of Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks and Rio Grande del Norte National Monuments, both in New Mexico and Bears Ears National Monument in Utah. All three are areas of striking natural beauty, wildlife habitats and places that present unique educational opportunities. I have hiked and explored each of these areas and know what they have to offer us, our children, and our children's children. We are currently seeing suburban civilization and upscale housing is not creeping, but rampaging, into many previously undisturbed areas. This is not the time to give up our National Monuments, new or old, especially those as unique as these three. At the very least, hold public meetings, and conduct a much more inclusive, including tribal engagement, process before rushing to an unprecedented decision to reduce or repeal any of our national monuments. The rush and false urgency behind this process goes against our democratic ideals.I know many people both in New Mexico and in Utah use our public lands for hiking, hunting, fishing, and other outdoor traditions, both new and old. The National Monuments also create revenue and jobs with visitors from both within and outside the United States staying, eating and shopping nearby. As a hotel manager, I know firsthand that conservation and growing the economy can go hand in hand.

I am writing to urge you to continue full protection for all of America's National Monuments, including the spectacular Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument along the Oregon-California border. Our National Parks, National Monuments, and other protected public lands are a critical part of what makes America great already!The Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument is gem among Oregon public lands.The Monument is at the rare intersection of three mountain ranges, the Cascades, the Siskiyou, and the Klamath Mountains. The unique mix of plants and animals in the Monument makes it an unparalleled treasure of diversity. Without the monument, scientists conclude that this treasured diversity would be at high risk of irreversible loss.The Monument is a perfect example of public lands supporting a variety of uses.The Monument supports a wide range of recreation, like hunting, fishing, driving, biking, bird and butterfly watching, mushroom hunting, and hiking, including along the Pacific Crest Trail. It also supports clean water, scientific research, educational programs, and is the beautiful mountain backdrop to Ashland and Talent, OR. Together, these uses are critical to Southern Oregon's growing tourism economy and all the jobs and taxes that result.The Monument has wide support throughout the local area and beyond.During its original designation and again when the Monument was expanded, it received overwhelming local support, including dozens of landowners with in-holdings and adjacent lands bordering the Monument; the local mayors, city councils and chamber of commerce boards of the two closest towns to the Monument; Tribal officials; Oregon's Governor, local state legislators; and Oregon's two U.S. Senators. The list of thousands of supporters from surrounding communities and others across the U.S. continues to grow.We need to keep public lands in public hands. Rolling back Monument protection is the first step in the anti-public lands agenda of handing over America's treasures to corporations. Our first step must be to leave all of America's National Monuments protected as they are.Thank you for the opportunity to comment,-Paris Conwell

I am writing to voice my concern and fear over Secretary Zinke's review of our country's treasured national monuments..I am an avid hiker in the San Gabriel National Monument and am devastated that this beloved part of my home county is threatened. This is my city and I value this wilderness area greatly. The San Gabriel National Monument is not only important to Angelenos, but this land is home to innumerable oak trees, native flora, and animals that are essential to preserving a healthy ecosystem.Furthermore, I am in disbelief that Sequoia National Monument, home to 30 giant redwood groves, is under review. These thousand year old trees deserve better. It is our job as Americans to protect our national treasures- such as the trees of Sequoia National Monument, the mountains in San Gabriel National Monument, and the the rock formations at Bears Ears.Please continue to protect every single one of our National Monuments.

I am writing you in support of Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument and to comment on the "Review of Certain National Monuments Established Since 1996."Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument protects a sensitive population of native redband trout and one of the country's most unique ecosystems. The Cascades-Siskiyou region hosts one of the most significant concentrations of biodiversity in North America. The monument was originally established in 2000 with significant support from the public to protect the region's distinctive flora and fauna, including old growth forests and a native redband trout population in Jenny Creek.Once again with overwhelming support from the public, an additional 48,000 acres of public land was added to the monument on 2017, which will better protect habitat for this population of native trout. The size of Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument is the minimum to support these natural resources of scientific and cultural significance.As national monuments, public lands such as Cascade-Siskiyou National Monument will help to sustain our outdoor traditions for future generations of sportsmen and women. National monuments are a part of our public land heritage that deserves to be celebrated, not jeopardized.I oppose any efforts to rescind or diminish Cascade-Siskiyou or any other national monument. Instead, I hope that the Department of the Interior will help to ensure the sound management of our nation's public lands by defending our national monuments and supporting the use of the Antiquities Act when and where suitable to conserve public lands for current and future generations of Americans.

I am writing you in support of our national monuments and to comment on the Review of Certain National Monuments Established Since 1996.Over a century ago, the Antiquities Act was signed into law by Theodore Roosevelt and has since become one of the most successful, bipartisan conservation tools in American history. Typically, national monuments do not make major changes to how multiple use public lands are currently being managed. Rather, they help to keep public lands and traditional uses the same into the future without the threat of new development that could harm fish and wildlife habitat and recreation opportunities.As national monuments, public lands will remain great places to hunt and fish for generations to come. National monuments are a part of our public land heritage that deserves to be celebrated, not jeopardized.I oppose any efforts to rescind or diminish any national monuments. Instead, I hope that you and the Department of the Interior will help to ensure the sound management of our nation's public lands by defending our national monuments and supporting the responsible use of the Antiquities Act.

I believe that national parks are an important part of our country. I believe they do exactly what they were meant to do ...... preserve and care for the beautiful environment and all the wildlife/plants in them. They also provide a place for recreation, relaxation and enjoyment ....open to everyone. Maine is a beautiful state. I have lived here all my life and I want to see the environment preserved for my children, grandchildren and their offspring.St. Clair and his family owned this land and could have chosen to keep all people off of it. Instead, they are opening it up to everyone by making it a National Monument. I appreciate being able to visit there and enjoy Maine's natural beauty.Please keep this National Monument.

I believe that our national monuments are in fact national treasures deserving of protection for the benefit of all our citizens. Removing national monument protection is an unprecedented action. I see no evidence of any value or benefit to the country at large by this action. Selling off public land or leasing it for oil/gas/mineral extraction would only benefit a very few, and the beauty and cultural significance of the land would be lost forever. Please do not withdraw national monument status from any of the monuments created in the last 20 years.

I believe that we should not take away bears ears national monument, because that is land that has important history to the naitive americans. Bears ears also has a lot of land that should stay intact and not destroyed for other purposes.
I bet you that on the 1.35 .million acres of land is probably where Isis /Muslims are training on our land...if I were you I would have it check out for the safety of the American people. Thank you

I can't think of 1 good reason to have a "review" of these National Monuments except to appease someone who has a financial interest in repealing the designations. I don't hear about Italy "reviewing" their historical and natural treasures, or any other nation with similar cultural, historical, or natural monuments.

I do not believe that the true intent of the Antiquities Act is being observed. As small an area as is possible is what the law states, yet we see two presidents who apparently believe that it's a contest to see who can steal the most land. Sorry there aren't more archeologists, but I seriously doubt that the people of Utah care very much. I was in Utah just after Pres. Clinton designated the Grand Staircast-Escalante monument. The people were very unhappy to have millions of acres of land stolen from them. That was my impression of most peoples' feelings on the subject.. End this stupid contest, use the law sparingly, without pandering to special interest groups.

I encourage the President and Secretary Zinke to maintain the current designations of all monuments in question. Our public land is our heritage and our legacy for our children and grandchildren. Overturning any Antiquities Act designations is un-American and would be a great disappointment for generations to come.

I encourage you to protect these Monuments so that all Americans can continue to enjoy them in the years and generations to come.Each Monument has a story. Each is a special space belonging to all Americans and with meaning to Americans around the country. I'd like to share some of what the Giant Sequoia National Monument specifically means to me and to my family. It is a place that we have returned to many times over the years, enjoying its beauty and taking spiritual solace from our sense of connection to the land and natural world there.The protections Giant Sequoia has as a National Monument are vital to preserving that peace and beauty. They help support a thriving local tourism economy depending on visitors like my family who are drawn to the spectacular landscapes.But most importantly, they help preserve those landscapes for all Americans, now and for generations to come. I hope to bring my children to see Indian Basin Grove and The Trail of a Hundred Giants and all the other beautiful places of the Giant Sequoia. The National Monument status means I can count on them still being there for us.

I find it hard to believe many of the remarks of the preservation of land for the opportunity of ourselves and our children to be able to enjoy the beauty of the monuments that will or are made available to us. If we are expecting the big hand of the Federal Government based in a lot of offices in Washington and no experience with the lands that area involved to manage the beauty, majesty and sacred nature of the land, we are so very wrong. They do not know how or what to do, only limit traffic to these wonderful lands. We will not have the opportunity to visit or see because of the restrictions that will be placed on us. The major point is if others really want to see and be a part of the land, why have they not taken advantage of it in the past. We know this is not happening because of the tourism count is so low that it is nonexistent in most cases. The lands and resources are and have been managed with greater love and care by those who do live by and on the lands, with cooperation of all, we don't need BIG BROTHER and his bullies to make regulation and rules that they only dream up while in the office in the center of millions of people who really don't care what happens to our lands that we love. Remove the government from our lands and let the locals manage the Land That They LOVE.

I fully support all national monuments created under the Antiquities Act, especially Bears Ears and Grand Staircase, both of which I have visited and enjoyed. I am angered by the audacity of the president, elected by technicality, to presume to judge the monument designations of former presidents. I am apalled that Zinke, who professes to admire Teddy Roosevelt, would aid in trampling on the Antiquities Act, made so famous by TR. I am shocked that Congress has not more vigorously pushed back against this incredible abuse of presidential authority. Leave the national monuments alone. They belong to all Americans, so of course all Americans get a say in their creation, not just locals. And we got that say by electing past presidents who created them. To rescind their designation is to tred on democracy.

I fully understand that not all of the citizens of the world give a hoot about national monuments or what they mean to those who do visit them, but trust me the owls-the wise old ones-do. As Leopold (I think it was) said, 'in wilderness is the preservation of the world". Call it a park, a wildlife preserve, a wilderness, an open-space or a monument they all do the same essential thing-protect the land and the inhabitants of that piece of land or body of water and give people a place to escape from the ever-madding world. We need refuges to remind us that mother earth can heal herself when left alone and we can receive relief and healing from much that ails us simply by moving through these protected places being mindful of all that they offer.Protect the status of all monuments and do not mess with the Antiquties Act. Leave Bears Ears forever a protected monument, perhaps some day a national park.

I grew up in New York City knowing nothing about the vast beauty and natural wonders of America. My introduction to American park lands began when I joined the US Navy and left New York. Over the years I traveled our beautiful country for business and always visited nearby National Parks. My family and I also visited National Parks on our vacations where we camped and introduced my children to the beauty and wonders of unspoiled nature.Please do not open these beautiful park lands to exploitation by the lumber, mining, drilling or other development that will damage the beauty and environment they provide for the enjoyment of present and future generations of Americans.American park lands need the protection of the National Monuments Act. Please continue this protection.Thank you

I have been camping, hiking and backpacking my entire life. I find it appalling that our nation is considering selling of this land to developers. This is an act that cannot be reversed unlike other acts that can be modified. Once the treasure land has been developed, it is game over.Parks allow families to be together to camp, hike, bike or just see the land of national battles. It is low cost way to have families vacation together. For me personally, my dad was in a wheelchair and we went camping all the time. Some of my best childhood memories were on these trips. We would not have been able to go to resorts or other trips living on disability income.As an adult, I backpack and it keeps me active and goals to keep in shape so I can go on these trips. In a society that needs to loose weight, why would be taking away lands where people can go exercise?

I have been hiking, backpacking, and camping in Grand Staircase-Escalante and Bears Ears, among many other parks in our parks system. These lands are unique and irreplaceable, and they must be protected and preserved for future generations. The rich diversity and splendor of America's public lands distinguishes us from all other countries, and a potential loss or reduction of these public lands would diminish the cultural and environmental richness our country. These lands belong to the people, and keeping their status as National Monuments is the best way to ensure that all Americans can use and enjoy them.

I have been very fortunate to grow up near the some of the great national treasures that are our national monuments they have always provided a sanctuary for me to go and enjoy the world in its natural state. From walking through Texas canyon in the now Bears ears national monument looking at the ancient ruins of the Lewis ruins with my family to getting engaged to my fiance at Indian Creek on a climbing trip that I have made for over 10 years. These places are sacred to me and those that i love. Having seen the change in camping and land disturbance in recent years has been a step in the right direction with the new paid camping areas at Indian creek a more maintained camping area helps keep the are clean and concentrating the use and impact of the land in small areas. When driving through some of the small towns around the bears ears national monument there is talk of the great good that this area will have for the local economy in the long term with the tourism that it will bring. Although the local UT government is calling for the land to be given back to the state it should be preserved for the people and not given away to a few at the top to decide what is most beneficial for them. These great spaces are the reason why I live in Utah and happily pay my fair share in local state and federal taxes to help ensure that these places will be protected, and kept open to the public to enjoy. Please consider the fact that there are more uses for this land in preserving the ancient history and outdoor recreational activity than for industrial uses. As a geologist I understand the need for producing raw materials for industry and infrastructure but there needs to be land set aside from the never ending production otherwise we will lose our connection with the world that we live in all together. Please leave these national monuments as they are.Thank you

I have hiked and camped in The Grand Staircase/Escalante area for years. As a citizen, scientist and professor, I know we all need this space and this place.This irreplaceable landscape is unique in the world. It is well-used by citizens who need a healthy space to escape. It is a place that makes me proud to be a citizen of the United States, a country that knows and values this place.Do not allow any change of status, any fracking or mining in The Grand Staircase/Escalante.

I have never been to the grand canyon but I desperately want to one day. For that to happen it needs to be protected, not only for me, but for future generations. Please protect all national momuements.
I have relished the southern Utah wilderness since my youth. Please preserve Bears Ears and the other monuments and parks as they are! They are irreplaceable. Please don't be short-sighted!

I just came back east from several weeks camping on public lands in Co and UT. Most recently the area around Grand Staircase. There are some beautiful places protected by our monuments and parks. There are public lands that many people from the region, other parts of the country, and even the rest of the world can enjoy.I love that we have been able to keep so much land open for so many years. As the population expands, new towns pop up, small towns become small cities, etc. As we exhaust mining and drilling in one area, we continuously look for new places.These tracks of land are something we've been given by generations before us. Even lands that became monuments and parks much more recently. We will never go back, there is no going back once these lands are developed. Having these gorgeous places to get away, get out in desert, out in nature and reconnect is amazing.When I was hiking near Grand Staircase I hitched a ride back to my car with two Danish girls. They were on a 2 month road trip across our country. They absolutely loved south eastern Utah from what they had seen so far.It saddens me that the money to be made off of opening up these lands to development seems to be greater than any will by some in our government to protect them for future generations.Look at what happened with some of the more amazing features close to the east coast. Niagara falls is a perfect example of what happens when a beautiful place is left unprotected.We have managed to set aside some vast sections of land and keep them beautiful all these years. May they forever be wild, forever be beautiful, and forever be protected.Thank you for your time

I know Trump wants to turn America into an industrial hellscape where HAZMAT leaking from pipelines poisons the drinking water of the evil poors and whatever but I like looking at pretty things and keeping a little bit of space for wildlife to maybe hunker down and wait out their eventual extermination peacefully so please leave at least a tiny spot for us to remember what the earth looked like before we covered it in refineries and sludge pools, you insane monsters (this insult is intended for the leadership, not the people who actually want to preserve monuments and are stuck doing this stuff against their will)

I live in Grand Junction Co and often visit Canyonlands and Bear Ears with family and visiting friends.With the increased use of our National Monuments and National Parks in recent years, I believe that these significant natural and cultural treasures need to be preserved now more than ever.This monument includes some of the important lands adjacent to Canyonlands National Park. It provides strong protections against oil and gas drilling and mining threats near Canyonlands National Park, Natural Bridges National Monument and a portion of Glen Canyon National Recreation Area. It also offers culturally important and spectacularly beautiful lands for public recreation and enjoyment that would otherwise be vulnerable to development and off-road vehicle damage.Theodore Roosevelt said:"There are no words that can tell the hidden spirit of the wilderness, that can reveal its mystery, its melancholy, and its charm."Honor his legacy.

I love BLM land. National Parks and Monuments, not so much. BLM offers a greater opportunity for a wide variety of public uses. Please reduce the size of these Monument land grabs and return them to all people to use. Public lands should be available for well managed multi use.
I love our national monuments! They are important to me when I visit and to just know they are there for me and others in the future. Do not get rid of them.

I moved to Colorado in 1995 to take advantage of the recreational opportunities that exist here, and the increase in quality of life that comes from participating in those activities. I want to make sure that my kids, my grandkids, and generations after them enjoy these same resources and opportunities. Today, I am writing in support of Browns Canyon National Monument and to comment on the Review of National Monuments currently underway.In Colorado, Browns Canyon National Monument protects exceptional fishing and recreation resources. The popularity and productivity of the Arkansas River has earned 102 miles of the river Gold Medal status, a class bestowed to only a handful of waters in Colorado. Browns Canyon not only conserves an important stretch of this river, but it provides ample public access for recreation, including fishing, rafting and hiking. The size of Browns Canyon National Monument is the minimum to support these resources of significant value to local communities, hunters and anglers, and businesses.Browns Canyon was designated as a national monument with broad support and as a locally-driven conservation initiative. As national monuments, public lands such as those included in the Browns Canyon National Monument will help to sustain our outdoor traditions for future generations of sportsmen and women. National monuments are a part of our public land heritage that deserve to be celebrated, not jeopardized.I oppose any efforts to rescind or diminish Browns Canyon or any other national monument. Instead, I hope that the Department of the Interior will help to ensure the sound management of our nation's public lands by defending our national monuments and supporting the responsible use of the Antiquities Act.

I moved to Utah nine years ago to be able to go hiking and camping in its natural wonders. I'm willing to make sacrifices in my power and water consumption in order to preserve the beautiful land that surrounds us. Please preserve the current designation of the Bears Ears National Monument for the many generations to come.

I oppose any reduction to the Bears Ears National Monument, and want its status upheld. There are five tribal entities that value this land and others joined them in working hard to make public land management protection as a Monument possible. It is a recognition of the fine features of the area that should be enjoyed in perpetuity. I know this area personally and have hiked in the region, from Bluff. From significant rock art to wildlife habitat, one could list the reasons for the Monument but to me the strongest one is its impressive landscape, the Bears Ears are a commanding feature seen for miles around. This whole proposal was carefully studied by people familiar with the area. I supported the creation of this Monument and am strongly opposed to its loss or changes. Short sided greed and grandstanding by politicians should not be a guideline for public land management. We have responsibility to native peoples and to our own future generations. Keep Bears Ears status as a National Monument, and see that it gets an adequate budget to manage it.

I oppose the abolition or reduction of these National Monuments - Bears Ears, Cascade-Siskiyou, Grand Staircase-Escalante. I can not believe that this is up on the chopping block. We have fast food places piping up everywhere they have no problem securing a space of land among us, yet National Monuments' future is uncertain, What will become of them?Not all we have in the US is theme parks, shopping malls and restaurants, we need something more meaningful, The first peoples of this lands valued the land in its natural state, many years later we're still destroying. Not everyone can take expensive vacations like the president or celebrities do, in fact to see the beauty in other countries, we should be able to keep landmarks that are also affordable places of interest for future generations. Our nation wastes a lot more money on other things, use it to make an impact and a statement that we care about our natural resources and landmarks. SAVE OUR NATIONAL PARKS.

I oppose the change in status of the 22 National Monuments and the 5 Marine National Monuments. These are areas with unique physical and geologic features as well as animals and plants which can be found nowhere else. Many of them have national historic places. They should be preserved for their unique values they provide to all Americans and should be raped and pillaged for the value of a few companies.

I oppose the Department of the Interior's "Review of Certain National Monuments Established Since 1996."The establishment of the National Monuments under review has protected sites of important scenic, conservation, recreational, and historical value. This review process appears to be an attempt to strip the protections provided by National Monument status with a goal to transfer these lands to private interests for development of these lands: to mine them for minerals, possibly to construct luxury vacation accommodations accessible to only the wealthy, opening the lands for grazing that is not properly managed, or other damaging forms of land use and development.President Trump declared, "The Antiquities Act does not give the federal government unlimited power to lock up millions of acres of land and water, and it's time that we ended this abusive practice."In the United States, the government is the people and federal lands belong to the people -- all of the people. Lands are not "locked up" when they belong to everyone, and it is not an abusive practice to preserve and protect important American lands.I strongly oppose the idea that state governors and those living near National Monuments should have the ultimate say over how the land is managed. Lands that are culturally valuable, have immense scenic value, are historically meaningful, require permanent ecological protection and preservation, are important for recreational uses -- these lands must be preserved for the present and the future and, in many cases, protected and preserved for the non-human species that depend on those lands.I believe that the concept of "limited government" is an expression used to decrease protection of American lands and give those valuable public lands to private interests that seek to exploit those lands for private profit. Exploitation of protected lands can lead to damage and destruction of land value, and privatization takes public land and gives it to private interests, thereby locking it away from the public. Privatization can destroy recreational value. Exploitation and privatization can destroy historical, ecological, and scenic value.Our nation does not cry out for limited government in relation to its military, so why do we need limited government in other areas of concern? Cries of "limited government" are only heard when a private interest's goals to generate private wealth are frustrated. The concept of limited government is only expressed by those whose plans are thwarted when the people of the United States, through the powers of the federal government, preserve national resources using laws written for that very purpose.Some of the monuments under review are located in California. I very strongly oppose the review of all California National Monuments: Giant Sequoia, Carrizo Plain, San Gabriel Mountains, Berryessa Snow Mountain, Mojave Trails, and Sand to Snow.

I oppose the review of certain national monuments. The establishment of these monuments has protected important sites of tribal, conservation, recreation, scenic and historic value. This review is an attempt to strip this protections reflects a mentality of development at all costs. Please protect these beautiful spaces DO NOT strip them of their monument status.

I respectfully submit these comments as a member of the Society for American Archaeology in support of the __________________ National Monument.The Antiquities Act itself is the result of advocacy by the public and archaeologists concerned about the preservation of the cultural heritage contained in our federal lands. It is for the continued protection of cultural resources--specifically those located within the ____________ Monument--that I am writing.The ________________ Monument, which is subject to the review procedure outlined in the Executive Order (E.O.) signed by President Trump on April 26th, contains many known archaeological sites. There are likely even more as-yet unknown sites as portions of the land have never been surveyed to locate archaeological resources. In addition to playing active roles in the cultural lives of many people today, the historic and scientific value of these places and the objects they contain cannot be overstated. They are physical ties to the past, and hold irreplaceable information about the peoples who came before us, how they lived, and how they adapted--or not--to the ever-changing natural and social environments surrounding them. If these sites are looted or destroyed, those connections, and that data, are lost forever.Some are questioning the size of recent monument designations, given that the Antiquities Act states that monument boundaries should be limited to the smallest area compatible with effective management of the assets to be protected. As far as cultural resource protection is concerned, it is important to note that the science of archaeology has evolved greatly since the time the Act was signed. We've come to recognize that archaeological sites are best interpreted as part of the landscapes that surround them. It is only from this perspective that we can gain the clearest understanding of the lives of our forebears.I understand that preserving every acre of federal land from development is clearly neither possible nor even desirable. Setting aside lands containing the most sensitive cultural values, however, is vital to the continued growth of our knowledge of the past, without which the nation's future will be greatly diminished. It is possible to achieve both outcomes. Designation of land as a monument does not have to completely preclude economic development within its boundaries. Some activities compatible with resource preservation could take place, while still giving archaeological sites a higher level of protection than is afforded on lands outside monuments.I urge you to keep these realities in mind as the Department's review of ____________National Monument continues.

I respectfully submit these comments as a member of the Society for American Archaeology in support of the Bears Ears National Monument.The Antiquities Act itself is the result of advocacy by the public and archaeologists concerned about the preservation of the cultural heritage contained in our federal lands. It is for the continued protection of cultural resources--specifically those located within the Bears Ears Monument--that I am writing.The Bears Ears Monument, which is subject to the review procedure outlined in the Executive Order (E.O.) signed by President Trump on April 26th, contains many known archaeological sites. There are likely even more as-yet unknown sites as portions of the land have never been surveyed to locate archaeological resources. In addition to playing active roles in the cultural lives of many people today, the historic and scientific value of these places and the objects they contain cannot be overstated. They are physical ties to the past, and hold irreplaceable information about the peoples who came before us, how they lived, and how they adapted--or not--to the ever-changing natural and social environments surrounding them. If these sites are looted or destroyed, those connections, and that data, are lost forever.Some are questioning the size of recent monument designations, given that the Antiquities Act states that monument boundaries should be limited to the smallest area compatible with effective management of the assets to be protected. As far as cultural resource protection is concerned, it is important to note that the science of archaeology has evolved greatly since the time the Act was signed. We've come to recognize that archaeological sites are best interpreted as part of the landscapes that surround them. It is only from this perspective that we can gain the clearest understanding of the lives of our forebears.I understand that preserving every acre of federal land from development is clearly neither possible nor even desirable. Setting aside lands containing the most sensitive cultural values, however, is vital to the continued growth of our knowledge of the past, without which the nation's future will be greatly diminished. It is possible to achieve both outcomes. Designation of land as a monument does not have to completely preclude economic development within its boundaries. Some activities compatible with resource preservation could take place, while still giving archaeological sites a higher level of protection than is afforded on lands outside monuments.I urge you to keep these realities in mind as the Department's review of Bears Ears National Monument continues.

I strongly oppose any effort to eliminate or shrink our national monuments. An attack on any monument undermines the Antiquities Act whose legacy goes back to President Theodore Roosevelt. I value the protection of public lands and waters. The DOI needs to be a strong steward of our national monuments for current and future generations.

I strongly oppose changing the designation of our national monuments. The designations were made for important reasons in each individual case. For example, the Canyons of the Ancients in Colorado has incredible value as an ancient archeological site. I implore you not to change any national monument designations. Thank you.

I strongly oppose removing Bears Ears National Monument from its National Monument Designation. Bears Ears National Monument is part of our country's history and must be protected. It is incumbent upon us to ensure that this beautiful, cultural and historical site will not be destroyed and lost forever.Thank you.Nandia BlackKildeer, Illinois

I STRONGLY OPPOSE rescinding, or changing, the boundaries of SAND TO SNOW NATIONAL MONUMENT. The terrain designated as Sand to Snow National Monument clearly satisfies criteria necessary for protection of the area under the Antiquities Act, and any attempt to change the boundaries would conflict with the original intent of the Antiquities Act. Once this national treasure is opened up to developers and resource extractors we can never go back. There is tremendous value to ALL Americans in preserving this special place.

I strongly support all of our National Monuments, including Bears Ears. My wife and I hike and backpack and do canyoneering in these lands many times every year. Please keep their National Monument status intact.
I strongly support protecting land as national monuments, specifically Bears Ears. Our natural heritage should be protected.

I strongly support the continuation of Bears Ears National Monument within its current boundaries. I have taken many trips to this area and can vouch for its beauty and important cultural significance for the many Native Americans that call this area home. This monument connects fragmented sections of other national monuments, Forest Service, and BLM land; creating a truly monumental experience for those that visit this largely unspoiled area. It creates an unparalleled permanently protected habitat corridor for the wildlife that live here as well. Population is only increasing in the U.S. and land preservation needs to keep pace so we don't overpopulate the parks that we do have, impacting both the user experience and the plants and wildlife that live there. Please do what is right and keep this monument as designated.-Steve

I strongly support the continued protection of all National Monuments established since 1996. The protection of public lands is imperative for the common good and use of all taxpaying citizens. I strongly oppose any changes that would result in opening these lands to oil and gas exploration or any other resource removal.

I Strongly support the National Monument that protects Bears Ears--- it has been a long process- we need to have it matter with Tribal, Environmental and State officials negotiate and work together for long time for those agreements to be upheld or everyone heads back to court and that creates more uncertainty--- no national monument has been reversed- it provides open space for our children and Public lands is one of the great experiments of American Democracy- once destroyed you have risked taking it away for every!! please stand up for public lands in the West!! and for Bears Ears specifically!!!

I strongly urge you to continue to protect all national monuments now under review and reject any changes to these vital pieces of our nation's natural heritage.Monument designations have been instrumental in the conservation of important places and sensitive habitats for more than one hundred years. Endangered and threatened species such as desert tortoises, kit foxes, burrowing owls, pallid sturgeon, and rare native plants rely on these protected spaces. Shrinking or eliminating these existing protections would jeopardize these species and threaten their recovery.National monuments are economically beneficial to neighboring communities as many are home to outdoor recreation opportunities.More, removing monument designations issued by a prior administration has never occurred. Presidents of both parties have issued monument declarations and consistently respected those issued by their predecessors.Please reject any changes to our national monuments.

I strongly urge you to continue to protect all national monuments that are under review, and to reject any changes to these important pieces of our nation's natural heritage.Monument designations have been instrumental in the conservation of important places and sensitive habitats for more than one hundred years. Endangered and threatened species such as desert tortoises, kit foxes, burrowing owls, pallid sturgeon, and rare native plants rely on these protected spaces. Shrinking or eliminating these existing protections would jeopardize these species and threaten their recovery.National monuments are economically beneficial to neighboring communities as many are home to outdoor recreation opportunities.Additionally, removing monument designations issued by a prior administration has never occurred. Presidents of both parties have issued monument declarations and consistently respected those issued by their predecessors.Please reject any changes to our national monuments.

I strongly urge you to continue to protect all national monuments that are under review, and to reject any changes to these important pieces of our nation's natural heritage.Monument designations have been instrumental in the conservation of important places and sensitive habitats for more than one hundred years. Endangered and threatened species such as desert tortoises, kit foxes, burrowing owls, pallid sturgeon, and rare native plants rely on these protected spaces. Shrinking or eliminating these existing protections would jeopardize these species and threaten their recovery.National monuments are economically beneficial to neighboring communities as many are home to outdoor recreation opportunities.Additionally, removing monument designations issued by a prior administration has never occurred. Presidents of both parties have issued monument declarations and consistently respected those issued by their predecessors.Please reject any changes to our national monuments.
