I think the Bears Ears National Monument should be rescinded. To me this is mainly a large land grab by the federalgovernment of land that belongs to Utah, and it should be up to Utah to decide how they want to use that land. Thefederal government already controls too much of the land that should belong to the states, particularly in some of thewestern states.

I toured the USA with my wife on a cross country road trip two years ago, just before the birth of our beautiful daughter. One of the most enjoyable parts of our trip was visiting many of the country's National Monuments and National Parks, including some of the ones listed here.They provide a place for us to connect with nature. They also serve as valuable tourist attractions, and promote commerce by encouraging people like myself to travel and experience them. Local businesses benefit from these places existing and being maintained, by bringing business that simply would not exist in those areas.And all that economic benefit aside, these places are a treasure. A national treasure. They must be preserved for our children and grandchildren. We cannot abandon and exploit them for short-term gains, especially (though not exclusively) if those gains would primarily benefit large corporations, the rich, and the powerful.We must maintain the protections they currently enjoy. If anything, we should do more to preserve more of the natural wealth of this country. If we don't, how will we look our grandchildren and, should we be so blessed, their children in the eyes and explain to them that we squandered the earth's bounty so we could extract oil, gas, and minerals; that these things we've treasured and enjoyed were destroyed for small amounts of profit?This will not help America. It will not help our economy. It will not help the people who are suffering in this country. We need jobs and education, not short-sighted exploitation of our land for purposes of profit and greed. We cannot restore these things once they are destroyed. Please do not destroy them. The American people do not want this. To do anything less than protect these places would be a traitorous betrayal of our cultural values, our country, and its citizens.

I urge you not to rescind the national monument designations. I am adamantly opposed to any effort to eliminate or diminish protections for national monuments. These monuments increase economic activity for rural counties through tourism while at the same time protecting the land for future generations. I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.

I want to urge you to protect these national monuments from drilling and other man-made devastation. I have had the privilege of visiting some national and state parks and wish to see many more during my lifetime. They are home to much wildlife and a boon to local economies due to wilderness tourism.I particularly would like to see the Canyons of the Ancients in Colorado,Please protect these beautiful places from human greed.Thank you!Tyger

I was a volunteer BLM site steward for Bears Ears, Comb Ridge, and Cedar Mesa for over 10 years. My job was to document visitation and damage and to report any new as yet undocumented sites. I personally witnessed a total of 3 minor Instances of damage due to human activities. This over a span of more than 10 years. The damage and protection arguments are completely fabricated lies. Please return this area to its original status. A new monument status would only accelerate the areas demise, not protect it.

I was born and raised in Montana, but have lived in many states including Tennessee, South Dakota and Alaska.I am writing to urge you to go against any measure that involves the transfer or sale of our public lands.Our public lands not only define us as a people, but as a nation. If we sell that to the highest bidder, we are selling our soul and the very foundation of American principles and ideals. We have been given this amazing gift and we must resist extracting the greatest dollar while turning a blind eye to the human value. These lands are for we the people.From picking huckleberries as a child in Glacier National Park to camping in the Badlands of South Dakota. From harvesting my first whitetail deer on a parcel of BLM land on the Powder River to hiking in the dead of winter to a public-use cabin on the Kenai Wildlife Refuge. Catching my first largemouth bass at Lee Metcalf Wildlife Refuge and hiking under colorful autumnal foliage at Land Between the Lakes. These lands are our richest patrimony.We hunt. We fish. We hike. We camp. We find solace. We find humility. We find wonder. We find our spirit. If these lands cease to exist, we cease to be a free country.From sharp, glacier-carved peaks in Glacier to the Statue of Liberty. This is our heritage.I strongly urge you to take a long, hard look into yourself when considering any action on our public lands. Do not agree to sell what makes us Americans and what makes our democracy.Sincerely,Devin Wagner

I would like to comment in support of Papahanaumokuakea National Marine Monument. This 583,000 square miles reserve is home to 7,000 marine species (a quarter of which are found only in the Hawaiian Archipelago), the endangered Hawaiian monk seal and green sea turtle, and 14 million breeding seabirds representing 22 species.Studies show that identifying and protecting marine reserve areas work and increase resiliency and abundance of sea life.For the benefit of fisheries, tourism and ecosystem health, we must maintain the Papahanaumokuakea National Marine Monument.

I would like to encourage Sec Zinke to remove Bears Ears' designation as a National Monument. I think it is an example of federal government overreach and should be a decision made at the local and state level.

I would like to strongly recommend the continued protection of the areas currently covered by Bears Ears and Grand Staisecase/Escalante National Monuments. I have spent many years enjoying the wilderness and cultural sites in Bears Ears National Monument. This area is a national treasure, with irreplaceable pre-Colombian cultural history that deserves federal protection.

I would like to urge you to leave the Bear's Ear Monument in the status designated by President Obama. This area needs to be protected as a federal National Monument. This area is a uniques and incredible landscape. It is also a cultural treasure that needs to be preserved for future generations. Please protect this area, thank you Diane Shoutis, Wyoming

I write in opposition to the review of National Monument designation and/or expansion requested under Executive Order 13792 of April 26, 2017 (82 FR 20429, May 1, 2017). This effort represents the worst kind of bureaucratic maneuvering to strip the public of their rights to access what are inherently their lands in the interest of satisfying monied special interests who reserve them for their own uses. As a resident of Southern California I can speak from personal experience about the San Gabriel Mountains National Monument, and from this experience I can say that the idea that there was "...[inadeequate] public outreach and coordination with relevant stakeholders..." is preposterous, and I can only assume that this is also the case with the other National Monuments on the list.
I write in support of retaining the Northeastern Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument in its current designation, or expanding upon it.

I'm writing in regard to executive order 13792. National Monuments are an vital part of our national heritage and must be protected. As well, they're and important source of income for those working in the tourism industry.Here in Maine, we are fortunate to have Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. Visiting there is a wonderful way to recharge and reconnect with an unspoiled natural environment.

I'm writing in support of all monument designation or expansion under the Antiquities Act, especially Bears Ears in Southeastern Utah. Therefore, I am not supportive of any review of monuments that may result in the reduction of size or protections for the region.I've been climbing and recreating in the Bears Ears area for over 10 years and every time I visit, it seems the region grows more beautiful. The area truly is a national treasure and deserves our continued protection. I've often said that America's public lands really are what make this country unique and great. Responsibly protecting our public lands from privatization is the key to keeping America beautiful.Please continue to keep Bear Ears protected and beautiful.

I'm writing specifically about the Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. I urge you for the sake of future generations of Americans, to preserve this and all of our natural resources. I grew up singing America the Beautiful in elementary school, and it is with awe and pride that I have been able to view so many of our parks and national monuments. I hope my grandchildren will have the same sense of our beautiful nation.

I'm writing to let you know that I support the designation of Bears Ears National Monument and ask that it's boundaries remain unchanged.I am second year archaeology student at the George Washington University in Washington, D.C. It matters to me deeply that places like Bears Ears, places that are rich in cultural history, be preserved.Over the last several decades the trend in archaeological research has shown that this land which we now call The United States of America was inhabited by advanced people long before previously thought. With every excavation we find that the history of our country actually began longer ago than we thought. We are also finding that the people who lived here had complex systems and strategies for survival.Not only is this objectively fascinating it has real implications for every American. A country needs to take pride in its history and needs take necessary measures to protect it. Knowing and respecting history fosters patriotism, kinship among citizens, and a confidence in oneself.The designation of Bears Ears as a National Monument protects over 100,000 archaeological sites in an area where evidence of pre-Clovis people has been found. Maintaining this designations will protect our nations history.I want to conclude by thanking you for your work as I imagine it is often thankless. This is a difficult task you have been given and I hope that you will listen to the voices of the American people. Please recommend that the President leave the current Bears Ears National Monument boundaries in place.

In defense of Bears Ears National Monument:- Since the arrival of Europeans, Indian tribal governments have lost up to 98% of their aboriginal land base.- The Bears Ears National Monument is the result of an extensive, thoughtful, historic, collaborative process between the American public, federal agencies, and five Native American tribes (Hopi, Navajo Nation, Pueblo of Zuni, Ute Indian Tribe, and the Ute Mountain Ute).(i) THE REQUIREMENTS AND ORIGINAL OBJECTIVES OF THE ACT, INCLUDING THE ACT'S REQUIREMENT THAT RESERVATIONS OF LAND NOT EXCEED "THE SMALLEST AREA COMPATIBLE WITH THE PROPER CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF THE OBJECTS TO BE PROTECTED":- The current area of Bears Ears NM is 500,000 acres smaller than what was recommended by the historic Inter-Tribal Coalition. If it is reconsidered, than the area of the National Monument should be increased.- Each day, an estimated 6,000 acres of open space are converted to other uses. Expanding urban and suburban areas often result in a loss of forests, grasslands, and other natural areas-Bears Ears has abundant rock art, dwellings, ceremonial sites, granaries, and many cultural resources reflecting historical and cultural significance to a variety of Native American peoples.- The area is recognized worldwide as "one of the most densest and most significant cultural landscapes in the United States", and includes tens of thousands of archaeological artifacts, as well as ruins of cliff dwellings built by people who lived there from roughly 350 to 1300.

In the review of status for "Certain National Monuments Established Since 1996":1. State upfront that these National Monuments do not represent a "landgrab" of federal lands. The land within the newly created National Monuments was federal land to begin with. There was no "taking" of private or State property.2. Hold firm. Never ever go backwards. Once land has achieved protected status keep it that way. Only ill comes of downgrading these National Monuments to multi-use lands, including resource extraction.3. Require that Trump, author of the executive order 13792, visit each of the National Monuments under review with his son and grandchildren . Require Trump to explain to them that he wants to diminish their national heritage. Let his offspring talk with a Ranger at each site. Let his offspring walk a trail with a Naturalist and Cultural Historian. Let his offspring listen to people who respect these lands as Tribal Lands. Invite Trump to listen too. Trump stands in dire need of education.4. Raise DOI voices to tell Trump loud and clear that if he persists with EO 13792 future generations will look upon such betrayal of our National Heritage and Values as we now look upon EO 9066. And if Trump doesn't know what EO 9066 is, give him a history lesson.My opinion is this: Trump ignorant of science and of history, of the need to preserve habitats uninterrupted by extractive industries, of the need to show respect to Tribes, and of the need people have to feel unsullied wonder.

IT IS ESSENTIAL THAT THE NATIONAL MONUMENTS AND PARKS ARE PROTECTED IN THE UNITED STATES I am especially concerned about Bears Ears.Please protect ALL of our parks and monuments. They DEFINE us as a country.

It is imperative that we preserve our national monuments!. Nature is healing to the body and spirit. When we appreciate the earth and it's beauty, kindness to all (which is quite lacking nowadays) living creatures abounds. There is so much selfishness which is celebrated in this country. We need our national monuments to have a bit of grounding.Thank you,Debbie Adatto Ishida

It is impossible for me to fathom a world without escape into the natural beauty of a monument. Though humans are an innovative, creative, and hard-working species, we are also destructive. National monuments provide a way for us to connect with the natural world in ways that span those details that divide us. I urge you to, when reviewing these national monuments, to think not just about what ecosystem services (revenue, etc) they provide to humans, but how protecting these lands has ensured that this country can still be naturally beautiful, and provide a place for people to connect with the natural world. I would urge you with all my strength not to remove monument status from any of these amazing natural reserves.

It is so very important to keep natural spaces alive and open, not only for the value of nature, but because of the vast benefits they offer, from oxygen on trees, to housing many species of life, to even just having a tourism value if money is all that's being considered. Please remember to look at environmental science before rescinding the stays of these landmarks, and see that the benefits of having them far outweighs the short term benefits of destroying them.

It is unconscionable to me that our government would undertake to remove protections established by former Presidents, acting in their capacity as our elected leaders, from our heritage, a heritage of pristine lands accessible to all. We should not risk our National Monuments, National Parks, and other national, natural, treasures at a time when pressures on our shared environment are contributing to an alarming loss of open land, natural spaces, and species diversity.As a practical matter, it should be obvious to the President and the Department of the Interior, as it is to me, that any attempt to change the status of our National Monuments will end up in court. Some have already questioned whether the authorization to designate Federal land as a National Monument includes an authorization to end that designation. I'm inclined to think not - and with that in mind, have contributed to and will contribute to those organizations that are best prepared to fight any such move.Mr. President, after spending so many years breathing your own gases, you might want to visit some of the National Monuments under review. The fresh air would do you good.

It seems disingenuous that this Administration would consider eliminating or reducing National monuments. These areas (many rural and remote) attract millions of tourists that spend in aggregate billions of dollars. Why destroy tourist dependent jobs at a time when the focus of our government is on creating jobs.

It's sickening to imagine the shared landscapes belonging to the American public being sold out to state governments in thrall to special interests in the extractive industries. It's also abundantly plain that these precious resources would be sold to the highest bidder if the states were to assume control.Therefore I strongly urge you to continue to protect all national monuments that are under review, and to reject any changes to these important pieces of our nation's natural heritage.Monument designations have been instrumental in the conservation of important places and sensitive habitats for more than one hundred years. Endangered and threatened species such as desert tortoises, kit foxes, burrowing owls, pallid sturgeon, and rare native plants rely on these protected spaces. Shrinking or eliminating these existing protections would jeopardize these species and threaten their recovery.National monuments are economically beneficial to neighboring communities as many are home to outdoor recreation opportunities.Additionally, removing monument designations issued by a prior administration has never occurred. Presidents of both parties have issued monument declarations and consistently respected those issued by their predecessors.Please reject any changes to our national monuments.
It's simple. We don't need that oil this bad, and those companies don't need the money that bad. You are talking about priceless national treasures. Your job is to protect, not molest.

It's unbelievably that you cannot figure out how to protect our cultural and open space resources in this country and especially in Utah, where I reside. We **must** protect our natural resources like Grand Staircase-Escalante and Bear's Ears! These monuments should be protected for their cultural heritage (in collaboration with the sovereign tribes) and their natural beauty.We need more monuments and less fracking and coal mining and other extractive industry development in Utah and the west/south west.Protect Bear's Ears!Protect Grand Staircase-Escalante!

Katadin Woods and Waters National Monument is a tremendous gift to Maine of private lands. The original "stakeholders" were the private owners. Their gift gives all of us who live in Maine a stake in preserving this land - not for natural resources exploitation, but for public enjoyment and recreation of all sorts. Reversing this designation would be a tragedy, and the re-privatization of the land would deprive all of us of the security which comes from knowing that it is protected for the present AND for the future generations.Please protect and preserve the designation of this National Monument!

Katahdin Woods National Monument is a gem. How can you even consider abolishing or diminishing it? This National Monument cost the U.S. Taxpayer nothing, NOTHING, and includes an endowment for its management. What do you stand to gain other than political posturing?I have been hiking and canoeing this area for 30 years and remember it back when it was an industrial pulp forest. The paper companies in their generosity (sarcasm) even left a 50' buffer between the banks for the rivers and the adjacent clear cuts. Even so, the cultural and natural history of the area was and remains outstanding, though one wouldn't want to wander far from the water.There is a place where Wassataquoick Stream enters the East Branch of the Penobscot, rushing crystal clear over the raw white crushed granite bed into the brown tannic waters of the Penobscot, the heights of Katahdin looming over the lush floodplain forests, native brook trout in the river, fiddleheads in the woods, moose, black bear . . . it nourishes my soul.I now live thousands of miles away but look forward to the day I can return to the Katahdin Woods. I rejoiced upon the news that it had become a National Monument. I will again canoe those waters, an eco-tourist, spending time and money in the surrounding villages, encouraging others to do the same.If you return this area to an industrial forest few like me will visit, only the chain saws will be be heard. Logging these forests is a once in a generation short term source of income that debases the area for everyone else.Eco-tourism is forever, I would like to ski the path up the East Branch in the winter, ride my fat bike there in the fall, canoe in the spring, you can assure that I, and millions of others through the ages, will be forever able to do so.Through the generosity of a private citizen this area has been placed under YOUR PROTECTION, if you rescind this protection rest assured your soul will rot in hell.
Keep Bears Ears at its current size! Let all Americans benefit from access to this preserved natural treasure.

Keep it public! Please protect these lands as public lands and prevent their extraction and use for commercial purposes. We are lucky enough to live in a country with so much bounty already and any degradation of these lands for private or commercial purposes would be unnecessary and harmful.

Keep our national monuments! I'm a resident of New Mexico and it is extremely important to me that we preserve such sites as the Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks and Rio Grande del Norte. I also support the preservation of Bears Ears National Monument in Utah. We care deeply about our national monuments and want them to be available for future generations! Please continue to protect these precious and beautiful national monuments.
Keep this monument, or any other monument for that matter, a national monument for all generations

Keep you slimy hands OFF our protected lands and monuments! And all the hands of this entire corrupt administration so detrimental to the environment, the future of the American people, this country, and our planet! It is despicable you should even consider taking away protection status, drill in national parks,and stomp all over the great strides taken by Pres. Teddy Roosevelt to ensure our natural heritage over a century ago ! The entire Trump cabinet makes the thinking, caring American citizens...still the majority!... sick to their stomachs. PLEASE let the Sec. of the Interior prove to make himself an exception to that rule!
Keep your money grabbing paws off our parks! Our nation is great because of our natural wonders. We can't lose anymore to unwise exportation.

Leave National Monuments alone. In the age of advancing technology, mankind is becoming disconnected from the landscape and nature as a whole. National Monuments are one of the imperative resources that people need in order to rekindle that relationship with the land. People need a place where they can escape the cars and concrete. It's a sad sight to see land being privatized and developed. Lets leave these federal lands, in their entirety, alone. Access for hunting, fishing, and outdoor recreation should be easily accessible for all, not just for the social elites.

Leave our National Monuments in tact. I can't believe you would even consider undesignating them. The are a critical part or our country's character and identity. I support protection of existing National Monuments. You are a very destructive administration and I can't believe you would even consider threatening their designation. Your activity is a national and international embarrassment. Spend your time on some thing positive and constructive instead.
Leave our Public Lands free!!!
Leave the monuments alone! Why are you even wasting time on this - you should be focused on protecting more land! It's a disgrace.

Leave the National Monuments as they are. Don't change a thing. They are meant for everyone to enjoy the beauty of nature. There are so many creatures and plants that make these special places home. Very delicate ecosystems are in the place. Don't rape and pillage our beautiful lands for you to make a profit. When we are gone it is our children and our children's children that have to live in the future with the choices we make now. Don't make future generations miss out on these amazing places. One of the things that makes America great is all of our National Monuments and parks. Don't take that away from the world.do the right thing and protect these places from ever becoming a mine or oil field. We need to stop using Fossil Fuels and think of what will be the consequences of the future if we don't change and stop our destruction of mother earth.

Let us be truthful here. National Monuments and national Parks are places of refuge. We want to recreate & camp in these places and we do not want any sounds such as drilling rigs, engines, helicopters etc ruining that experience. I spend a lot of money each year taking family & friends to places such as Bears Ears, the San Gabriel Mountains etc. I can drive into the San Gabriels so all the costs are gear, & food. That money is spent locally. Many others do the exact same thing.Bears Ears is a little different as it requires travel + all the gear & food and a place to stay while enjoying the outdoors. That costs quite a bit more and that money is spent all over the place getting ready for the trip.If monuments are lost, they will be lost FOREVER. It only takes one moment of weakness to lose a monument & the entities that want to build there will try every day forever. We MUST be vigilant and keep development out of wild places and National Monuments & Parks.Thank you

May 22, 2017Honorable Ryan Zinke, Secretary of InteriorMonument ReviewMS-1530U.S. Department of Interior1849 C Street NWWashington, DC 20240Dear Secretary Zinke,I am writing to support the Bears Ears National Monument and urge you and President Trump to support this Monument also, in its entirety. In 2016 then President Obama listened to the coalition of five tribes that had come together to protect their sacred lands, and although smaller than the optimum, designated 1.3 million acres. Bears Ears names a spectacular area that also includes the remarkable Comb Ridge, Indian Creek, and White Canyon and exquisite habitat, all of which are important to the tribes because of approximately 100,000 ancient archaeological sites along with present cultural significance.World-class recreational opportunities exist for those of us who visit Utah to see and travel in this landscape of weathered sandstone, forested heights, deep canyons, and ancient cliff dwellings. Tourism is important to Utah's economy, and Bears Ears along with other Monuments, Parks, and Wilderness are the key to visitation. Since I live in the area and have traveled there as much as I am able, I am proud and relieved that greater Bears Ears has finally been afforded protection. Political policy in Utah has prevented this in the past and in no way should be allowed now to take us back to that time when Bears Ears could be looted, developed, bought and sold, and damaged from mineral exploration. These are activities that destroy "the peoples land" and benefit only a few of the wealthy and powerful, let alone the general public looking for jobs.The United States has not always treated our native people well, and now is a good time to acknowledge the importance of their presence, their history and culture, and their rich contributions to our society. They have formed a coalition, which has been joined by many Utah citizens and many of us in other states of various backgrounds and experience because after all, Utah's beautiful Monuments and Parks belong to all of us.You've seen this landscape, and as an outdoor person, I hope you were able to stay long enough to feel its magic and learn of its importance.Thank you for this opportunity to present my comments.Sincerely,Susan Morgan, PhDP.O. Box 442Arroyo Seco, NM 87514

May 24, 2017Dear Secretary Zinke,I am a Utah resident, and I urge you to recommend to President Trump that Bears Ears National Monument be upheld and the boundaries remain intact as designated in Proclamation 9558 of December 28, 2016 (Establishment of the Bears Ears National Monument).Bears Ears protects historic pioneer sites and ancestral homelands of Native Americans. It includes thousands of archaeological sites as well as paleontological, geological, and ecological treasures. It has been said to have the highest density of cultural sites in the US. Please do not ignore the previous work of dedicated stakeholders who came together to develop a compromise on the Monument's initial boundaries. The current size is the smallest area compatible with proper care and management. Shrinking the boundaries would jeopardize the valuable natural and cultural resources of the area.As a Utahn with two advanced degrees in the natural sciences, and a passion for hiking and camping, I urge you to consider the importance of this Monument for all Utahns and generations to come. Whenever I visit national parks or monuments, I am struck by the number of tourists there, and I am particularly struck by the number of international visitors. Our natural parks and monuments are a jewel that inspire awe around the world. I urge you to recommend that Bears Ears remain as a monument with its current boundaries intact. You have the power to show the world how much you value this country's unique natural and cultural heritage. If the Monument is reversed, the resource will suffer. Please don't deprive my children of the opportunity to experience this beautiful, culturally significant landscape in its current, protected state.I implore you to keep Bears Ears as a National Monument with its current boundaries intact.

Monument Review, MS-1530U.S. Department of the Interior1849 C Street N W, Washington DC 20240Dear Sir,I have visited various national monuments in the US and they are absolutely breathtaking.It is so sad that this current president does not value the importance of national monuments / environment.Please think about the next generation.Please protect our National Monuments. Continue to fight for the future

Monument Review, MS-1530U.S. Department of the Interior1849 C Street N W, Washington DC 20240Re: National Monuments and the Antiquities ActDear Interior Secretary Zinke:I am a retired lawyer living in northern New Mexico. I have visited numerous National Monuments over the last 60 or so years.Any attempt to undo National Monument protection is deplorable and is a betrayal of our children's and grandchildren's future. I urge you to not to participate in the destruction of the legacy we should pass on to future generations.Of the many arguments to be made in support of the Monuments, I will just touch on two.First, Monuments are not land grabs as often cited by politicians. The lands were public before designation and remain so. The land grabs are the fantasies of those such as Representatives Chaffetz and Bishop that want to sell off OUR public lands for short term gain. The designations were carried out after extensive research and public consultation. Those that contend otherwise are liars.Second, Monuments are economic boons to the nearby communities and to the nation as a whole. Nationwide, outdoor recreation generates 887 billion dollars of consumer spending annually and creates 7.6 million jobs. In your home state of Montana, outdoor recreation generates 5.8 billion dollars of consumer spending, and provides over 64,000 jobs in a state with a population of just over a million. Don't kill the goose that laid the golden egg.In closing, I implore you to part company with your Republican brethren on this issue and actually put your country first, not your party.Sincerely,Michael MacklinPO Box 1944Las Vegas, NM 87701macklin.m@gmail.com505 426 0685Cc:Senator Tom UdallSenator Martin HeinrichRepresentative Ben Ray Lujan

Mr Secretary, maybe you and the President haven't noticed, but undeveloped land and marine environments everywhere on the planet are in ever-decreasing "supply", requiring the Dept of Interior to actively engage in preserving what's left for the benefit of citizens, visitors, local economies, and the plants and animals still extant. Given that the demand for coal is in steep decline due to changing technology and environmental degradation, there is no increasing demand for uranium ore, and petroleum reserves in the US are vast and increasing, the only apparent need for this "review" is to further the greed of you and your president and the small number of "constituents" you represent. You want to exploit and ruin these public lands to benefit yourselves and the rest of the 1% for the short-term enrichment of yourselves and your fellow oligarchs. However, millions of us enjoy outdoor recreation such as canoeing/kayaking, back country hiking, wildlife preservation, viewing, hunting and photography, camping, unspoiled wilderness and so on. We cannot pursue these activities in polluted air and water and despoiled, lifeless landscapes. This is not a political issue, although you and Trump and the rest of your teabag ilk want to frame it in this manner, with the express purpose of plundering what little remains of the world as it was before the Industrial Revolution, and you don't give a good damn for the Native Americans who live on these lands or for the many millions of us who enjoy getting out of our concrete jungles to experience real life. Shame on you; are you completely amoral as well as greedy and informed only by your own closed, unscientific minds. Your "review" is a sham and a political device to further enrich a very small group of already obscenely wealthy people while mentally, spiritually and economically impoverishing the rest of us. Where do you think the clean air and water you and Trump like to consume come from? I know you're opposed to information and science, but just as an exercise, take a look at how many visitors travel to the places you wish to despoil, and the contribution to the local and national economies these visitors make. Finally, we are instructed in the Bible and the Quran to protect and provide stewardship of the earth, not to ruin it and leave it lifeless. As an example of the kind of damage you want to do, take a look at Everglades National Park and the impact your friends at "Big Sugar" have had on the ecology of the Park, despite it's millions of visitors and your mandate to protect, not further injure, public land. What are you thinking, if anything at all?

My name is Jarred Jackman and I am a citizen of the USA and a resident of Washington state. I have seen the list of the public lands being reviewed. I have been to many of these areas and still more are on my list of places to visit. In a time when our country is being more and more populated and the land is being more and more obliterated, these public lands represent the last vestige of hope that we will indeed have open spaces that belong to everyone and no one. We will be able to pass these lands to our children, their children, and so on. If these public lands are taken from the public and given to either local governments or sold to private entities, short term gains may be enjoyed by a select few. But long term loss will be felt by all.I'm advocating that these lands be kept public and protected under state and federal laws and regulations. I'm advocating that we not only use this review to learn more about the lands listed, but that we consider adding to the list. Please please please do not put your economic or political self-interests ahead of what is best for our nation as a whole. I can't count how many Europeans I've met who visit our country and are completely amazed at the large tracts of land that we have protected. We MUST preserve these protected spaces and as I already mentioned, add to them.Keep public lands public and do not give the rights to those lands away to local governments. Please, for the sake of the future, keep our public lands.

National monuments across the country are currently under review by the Trump administration. Based on the results of this review - including comments by members of the public - valuable fish and wildlife habitat and prime hunting and fishing opportunities could be changed permanently.Here in Montana, sportsmen worked hard to advance habitat protections for the Missouri Breaks National Monument - a 377,000-acre chunk of public lands that provides both excellent hunting opportunities - for deer, elk, bighorn sheep and black bears - and fishing access warm-water species such as northern pike, walleye, catfish and small-mouth bass.As a kayaker, hiker, hunter and fishermen I want all of our national monuments to stay protected and not have there boundaries altered.Join me and Backcountry Hunters & Anglers in urging the Trump administration to maintain hunting and fishing opportunities, protect valuable fish and wildlife habitat and keep the size and scope of our monuments intact.

National monuments across the country are currently under review by the Trump administration. Based on the results of this review - including comments by members of the public - valuable fish and wildlife habitat and prime hunting and fishing opportunities could be changed permanently.Here in California, sportsmen worked hard to advance habitat protections for Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument - a 330,000-acre chunk of public lands that provides both excellent hunting opportunities - for deer, elk, wild turkeys, wild pigs and black bears - and fishing access for bass, trout and countless warm-water species.Wild recreation, hunting and fishing is very important to me and is an intragal part of my family's lifestyle. Any loss of of public access is an attack on my personal freedom and affects my chosen way of life. This is not only a affront to me, but also future generations, who should be given the same opportunities that I have enjoyed.Join me and Backcountry Hunters & Anglers in urging the Trump administration to maintain hunting and fishing opportunities, protect valuable fish and wildlife habitat and keep the size and scope of our monuments intact.

National monuments across the country are currently under review by the Trump administration. Based on the results of this review - including comments by members of the public - valuable fish and wildlife habitat and prime hunting and fishing opportunities could be changed permanently.Here in California, sportsmen worked hard to advance habitat protections for Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument - a 330,000-acre chunk of public lands that provides both excellent hunting opportunities - for deer, elk, wild turkeys, wild pigs and black bears - and fishing access for bass, trout and countless warm-water species.Join me and Backcountry Hunters & Anglers in urging the Trump administration to maintain hunting and fishing opportunities, protect valuable fish and wildlife habitat and keep the size and scope of our monuments intact.

National monuments across the country are currently under review by the Trump administration. Based on the results of this review - including comments by members of the public - valuable fish and wildlife habitat and prime hunting and fishing opportunities could be changed permanently.Here in California, sportsmen worked hard to advance habitat protections for Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument - a 330,000-acre chunk of public lands that provides both excellent hunting opportunities - for deer, elk, wild turkeys, wild pigs and black bears - and fishing access for bass, trout and countless warm-water species.Leave my public hunting land alone. This is unacceptable.Join me and Backcountry Hunters & Anglers in urging the Trump administration to maintain hunting and fishing opportunities, protect valuable fish and wildlife habitat and keep the size and scope of our monuments intact.

National monuments and other public lands represent an import bequest from our current generation to future generations -- of Americans, and citizens beyond who travel annually to see the grandeur of the American landscape. Chief among the new monuments is Bears Ears in Utah, a site of immense importance geologically and anthropologically. By preserving this unique site, we leave it for all Americans to enjoy and learn about our past. Development of these or other sites will return only a marginal gain, quickly forgotten, while the natural beauty sacrificed for these trifling gains will be lost forever.
NATIONAL MONUMENTS ARE IMPORTANT

National Monuments are national treasures that must be preserved. Among the monuments listed for review are true geological, archaeological, historical, and biological gems. Once they are declassified as National Monuments there is no question they would be exploited and destroyed.Our natural and national treasures MUST come before corporate profits.

National Monuments are national treasures, a birthright of every American. To take them away would be to give away our heritage to the highest bidder. I strongly stand against taking away any National Monuments.

National monuments are not yours (as legislators who receives funding from industry) nor the presidents (who also gains financially from industry) to sell off. They belong to this country and are treasures.Do not open public lands for energy, industry, or development. It benefits only a few, who already have the lions share of wealth in this country. Shame on you, as a law maker if you even consider it.

National monuments are treasures for everyone. The monuments currently 'under review' had years of study and public input before they were designated. Bears' Ears, in particular, got the approval of both the Navajo and t he Hopi, who reportedly rarely agree on anything.Monuments also help local economies---crucial to areas that still haven't recovered from the economic downturn.I don't know why Secretary Zinke is calling this "the first ever formal public comment period for Antiquities Act Monuments".It's not an accurate claim.Preserve Bears' Ears as a National Monument!

National Monuments belong to the nation and should not be taken back and given to private companies for development.Do NOT open these up for review, they are public lands and need to stay public, pristine and off limits to for profit development.

National Monuments like Bears Ears should be kept as monuments and their size shouldn't be changed. Bears Ears holds many artifacts sacred to many different tribes living near the area. Not to mention it contains many opportunities for recreational activities because of the natural landscapes and beautiful scene.

National monuments were designated and are the proper vehicle for preserving unique characteristics of land and sea for present and future generations. Although such designations prevent development of resources within the monument areas the benefit of having as close to unspoiled environments far exceeds the value of extracting those resources. Monuments benefit all generations of USA citizens, now and forever. To remove the protection of their designations benefits only a few people today and those to come will only wonder what was.Keep all existing National Monuments.

National treasures are to be shared over generations. Do not reduce or alter the size or scope of our National Monuments! They are not to be auctioned off to the highest bidder and irreparably damaged. We need more not less.

National wild spaces are a crucial part of what makes our nation spectacular. I urge you to preserve Bears Ears National Monument and Grand Staircase-Escalante and all our national monuments. Don't take the joys of wilderness exploration away from our children. Don't further the damage done to native peoples by dismissing their sacred lands.
No. Just no. Protect our lands. Once they are gone, we can never get them back.

Of all the legacies that we as a people leave for future generations, the preservation of our natural landscapes is one of the greatest and most important. Please think beyond short term profits for a few people and remember that the decisions we make now affect these landscapes forever. These monuments were created to protect some of our most cherished and fragile landscapes. Please do not remove the protections these monuments deserve.

Opening the national parks to review is a horrid idea, that would allow drilling, mining, and other destructive activities on some of America's most beautiful wild lands and waters. These monuments also protect wildlife and support the economies of nearby towns by bringing in tourists. I am very against this review.

Organ Mountain Desert Peaks Monument is a park I enjoy visiting since I live 20 minutes away. Over the years I have worried about development destroying this historic area and was overjoyed when it was named a National Monument. Please make sure this monument remains as it is so future generations can also enjoy this location. I have many fond memories of walking the trails with my daughter and her friends, seeing wildlife I would not see in the city, and enjoying the views.The increase in tourism dollars the local community has seen should not be overlooked in this either. This allows the city of Las Cruces to continue to grow, employing more locals in jobs.Thank you for considering all of our comments as you make this decision. I hope that political and businesses hoping to exploit our national treasures are not given more weight with their plans than the American people who enjoy these National Monuments on a daily basis.

Our Federal Govt. has been grabbing too much land for far too long. I have been going to the San Gabriel Mountains since I was a kid and never had to pay to enjoy the day, or night, with family or friends until the Feds stepped in. The environment was maintained by those of us that enjoyed the freedoms of the land. These lands need to be given back TO THE PEOPLE for everyone to enjoy. This was nothing but a land grab and the Federal Govt. needs to back off from this and other lands they continue to steal from We the People.

Our home, planet earth, provides everything that every living entity needs to survive and thrive... in abundance.That's how it was designed. We, as humans, are not the inventors of this harmonious balance, our Creator is.Therefore, we do not 'own' earth. Nobody does. Earth belongs to every form of life that calls this great planet 'home'.Every living thing has a purpose. Every form of bird, animal, human, fish, bug, germ, plant, mineral, water, cell, etc... we are all meaningful components in the great balance of life, all sacred, all necessary.Human beings were gifted with the power of choice. With choice comes the immense responsibility to care for, protect, and preserve all forms of life (or not), including all elements which constitute our environment.This responsibility runs much deeper than caring for us, here today. It carries on to those who will be following us, those yet to come, long after we're gone. Abusing, exploiting, contaminating, destroying, wasting, disrespecting, or misusing any inch of our home, is blatant disregard for all forms of life. The human race has already done enough damage. It's time to allow Earth to heal herself so she may continue to take care of her children.Reversing the protection of lands designated as North American National Monuments is an irresponsible, disgraceful mistake. Please. Leave them alone. Our grandchildren and all future generations will thank us.

Our national lands are some of our greatest treasures, for the enjoyment of all people of all political beliefs, and once sullied, will never be as they once were. We should protect them and be proud of them.

Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am extremely disappointed that President Trump has signed an executive order that attempts to undermine our national monuments. Attempts to roll back protections for national monuments would be both illegal and terribly misguided and I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, which is first on the list for this review, is a textbook example of the priceless historic, cultural and natural wonders that are protected as National Monuments. Protecting 100,000 archaeological and cultural sites as well as stunning mesas, canyons and arches and the incredible outdoor recreation, hunting, fishing and general solitude and peace they contain, these treasures are irreplaceable. The designation and boundaries of the monument honors the voices of five sovereign tribal nations who joined together to seek protection of their shared ancestral lands and traditions, Bears Ears National Monument should remain protected permanently.Additionally, an attempt to attack one monument by rolling back protections would be an attack on them all. Sending a signal that protections for our shared history and culture are not permanent would set a terrible precedent. This would discourage business investment and community growth around all national monuments while also sending the signal that our history and natural wonders are negotiable. National monuments have already been shown to be tremendous drivers of the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy and businesses in gateway communities rely on the permanency of these protections when making decisions about investing in these communities. Whether at Bears Ears or other monuments across the country, our national monuments should remain protected for future generations to enjoy - they are a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for National Monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.

Our national monuments and public lands and waters help define who we are as a nation by telling the story of our historical, cultural, and natural heritage. I am extremely disappointed that President Trump has signed an executive order that attempts to undermine our national monuments. Attempts to roll back protections for national monuments would be both illegal and terribly misguided and I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.National monuments help protect God's creation and tell the stories of God's people. National monuments help faithfully tell the stories of all of us. From the Native American story at Bears Ears to the framework story at Cesar Chavez to the African American story at Pullman. Our national monuments tell our stories and are places where we pray and play.Bears Ears National Monument in Utah, which is first on the list for this review, is a textbook example of the priceless historic, cultural and natural wonders that are protected as National Monuments. Protecting 100,000 archaeological and cultural sites the monument honors the voices of five tribes who joined together to seek protection of their shared ancestral lands and traditions, Bears Ears National Monument should remain protected permanently.An attempt to attack one monument by rolling back protections would be an attack on them all. Our shared history, culture, and natural treasures should be protected not dismantled. Monuments across the country should remain protected for future generations to enjoy - they are a gift that belongs to all Americans.I am firmly opposed to any effort to revoke or diminish protections for National Monuments and I urge you to support our public lands and waters and recommend that our current national monuments remain protected.

Attempts to rollback protections for national monuments would be both illegal and terribly misguided. I strongly urge you to oppose any efforts to eliminate or shrink our national monuments.

Our national monuments are important not only for the sake of nostalgia, national pride and beauty-although all of those are valuable in their own right-but also for the sake of anthropology, American history, environmental science and biodiversity. These sites are often of great scientific interest, housing rare species and natural phenomena, battlefields, and some of the oldest human settlements in the Americas.The locations on this list didn't become federally protected as a lark. Most of them were added to this list thanks to a great public outcry, because experience had proven that nothing less was sufficient to protect them. As someone who traveled our wild, beautiful and diverse country to visit landmarks like these, revoking the protection of these lands would be a mistake and a shame. Don't take away protections on more wild lands, protect whats left of americas beauty.

Our national monuments are our pride. Go to the Grand Canyon, the Staircase, go out to these beautiful places of nature and wonder. They instill faith and pride in our country. These monuments are priceless. The greed and corruption of this current administration will go down in infamy as one of the most destructive forces of our time. I am asking you to protect our nation, our people, our air, water, and land from short-sighted greed. These monuments need to be protected. They are valuable not only to the local economies they support but to the very soul of this country.

Our National Monuments contribute significantly to local economies.National Monuments attract tourists and businesses around these very special natural and cultural sites.Please do not rescind National Monument status from any of the designated sites.Handing over public land for private profit by mining companies and others will not bring lasting prosperity to rural areas -but it will ruin areas that are irreplaceable.

Our National Monuments including Grand Staircase Escalante and all of the others are a source of National pride. They are irreplaceable and gorgeous and were protected for good reasons. Visiting these lands is the most wondrous, spiritual, renewal for those of us who respect and love our natural world These places are unique unto themselves. Please, please, please protect these lands and keep them as they were created and meant to be. Altering them in any way would be shameful and a disgrace. "This land was made for you and me."

Our National Monuments should not be reviewed now, or ever. This is absolutely unacceptable. National Monuments are a large part of what make our country, the America that it is. I plead to leave these incredible places be. Thank you.

Our National Park System is one of the many reasons America is already great. We have these beautiful pieces of land that we should protect for our future generations, not open them up to private interests.I am so lucky. I've been able to experience many of these parks and was fortunate enough to volunteer for NPS and live in a national park. I was right out of college, not really sure what I wanted to do with my life, and then I got that internship and it changed everything to the point where I refer to segments in my life as "pre-NPS" and "post-NPS." I want everyone to have the opportunity to experience these places and explore the world around them.National Parks and National Monuments give back to the community around them, creating secure jobs and spurring business development and opportunities. These are precious pieces of land that are worth so much more than our current government thinks they are. We have to protect this land.

Our National Parks and Monuments should never be "for sale". The beauty and serenity of nature should be available for generation after generation to enjoy. My family has enjoyed camping and exploring these natural areas for years, and do not want to see them spoiled by pollution, oil wells, or gaudy gold towers.
Our national parks are essential and should not only continue to be protected, they need to be funded!

Our National Parks, Monuments, Nature Area's etc MUST be left intact and preserved. These area's are in some cases the last refuge for wildlife and an ecosystem that may not survive for our children to experience.We have enough area's in the world for mining and logging. Destroying yet another habitat will not change anything for these industries however it will make a difference for the thousands of living things that will be killed or displaced.

Our public lands are our national treasure that we must preserve and protect from commercial exploitation so future generations may enjoy the benefits of the history and recreational opportunities such land provides. Mining, lumber, and fossil fuel interests do not look at the long-term. Their considerations are only for the short-term profits available. They would rob from our children, grand-children, and those succeeding generations: one can't put back what is destroyed. I grew up in coal country where mountain tops have been blown away for easier access to the mineral. I have seen the restoration efforts after the seams play out and they're unsatisfactory. Again, that which was ripped from the earth cannot be put back.

Please continue to protect our national monuments and parks. They are not the last frontier for extracting resources, but rather an important part of our history and culture. I have fond memories of traveling with my family as a child to visit these locations, to learn about our country and learn to appreciate nature in new ways.
Please do all you can to rescind the Bears Ears Natl Monument as outlined by Barrack Obama.And almost everything else Obama did and stands for, especially ObamaCare.

Please do not allow any mining, logging, drilling or activities that will destroy the national monuments of this country. These areas must be preserved to protect the historical and natural significance and the animal life located there.Thank you
Please do not allow our national monuments to be destroyed by this president. Thank you!!

Please do not amend or change in any way the established monuments in the State of Utah. These monuments are wanted and needed by the people of the state. The governor and our legislative group do NOT represent the will of the people and should not be the basis for your decision.

Please do not change the designations of National Monuments, it was no small feet to create them, and it should be no small feet to destroy them. They are a legacy to future generations, and a way for people across our nation to experience the natural wonders that our country has. Bears Ears is beautiful and should be protected. Millions of people fought for this, and millions more will benefit. As land becomes more scarce, water becomes harder to come by, and as our country changes, the land should remain.

Please do not change the status of Bears Ears National Monument or any of the other National Monuments under review. They are a reflection of the glorious, independent, adventurous spirit of America. These lands need to remain protected and preserved for our generation and generations to come. Thank you.
Please do not change the status of these areas. It is the future we pass onto the next generations.

Please do NOT decertify Bear Ears National Monument. The archeological significance of the area alone should place it beyond the reach of developers. If that's not enough, please consider the documents submitted by at least 3 native tribes asking that the monument status remain.

Please do not diminish the reach of Bears Ears or any other national monuments. We need these few precious spaces for our children and children's children to enjoy. We are already in the middle of a severe ecological crisis in the Anthropecene era. It's vitally important that we preserve those natural areas that still survive.
Please do not get rid of the regulations protecting these beautiful places.
Please do not open this monument to drilling for oil and other fossil fuels. Its biodiversity must be protected for current and future generations. Let's lead the way with green technology instead.

Please do not reduce or dispose of our national protected monuments or lands. They are truly special areas that bring beauty, tranquility, and a sense of connection for all visitors. I am currently proud to live in a country who values its land and resources, for without that, we have nothing.

Please do not remove protections for our National Monuments. Each year, my family travels to the Vermilion Cliffs monument, Grand Canyon, Grand Staircase-Escalante, and Bears Ears regions to commune with nature and marvel at the many wonders hidden among these protected places. These places must be protected to ensure native nations have access to their sacred sites and historic territories. They also must be protected to ensure current and future generations can enjoy these special places.I also want to encourage you to maintain protections for the Sonoran Desert. As a resident in Tucson, AZ, the Sonoran Desert is literally our backyard. We cherish this desert and urge you to take every action to protect it. The desert is full of flora and fauna unique to this part of the world.

Please do not revoke National Monument status for these special places. My argument is three fold:1. Not everything has to be for profit. Once revoked these places will be subject to privatization. They will no longer be held in the public trust for the benefit of the greater good. With so much stinking profiteering in government can we have one damn thing that is not for profit? Can it just be enough that protecting these places is the right thing to do for our grandkids and children?2. These places are national monuments because they hold biological and geological significance. I know our President is not educated and he has the basic understanding on most issues of an angry toddler, science is scary to a man who is willfully ignorant. He doesn't understand anything that doesn't garner him personal profit. It's the voters and the DOI's job to protect these scientifically valuable places for research and enjoyment by all.3. There should be no bill, amendment or order set forth in front of this president until it is verified by an independent council he is acting on behalf of the American people and not a foreign entity. DOI would be allowing the fate of these special monuments to be in the hands of a president who has committed obstruction of justice at the best and treason at the worst.

Please do not roll back our newer national monuments. I live in Wyoming and am a greatparticipant in the out-of-doors. I have been to many of these monuments and I find themto be our heritage and a treasure to us all.I just visited Utah, and heard local support from hotel owners and business peopleregarding Bears Ears National Monument. Please maintain the integrity of thatmonument - do not reduce its size to allow exploitation.Our natural resources are our American heritage. Please maintain them during thesechaotic and troubling times. Do not add another layer of disharmony.Thank-you - I appreciate the ability to comment on our national heritage

Please do not take away our public lands! They are crucial to who we are as a nation... and what our nation is as we protect it for future generations. Please keep Bear Ears National Monument intact. We have traveled throughout the Monument, to Butler Wash, Grand Wash, Cedar Mesa, and Comb Ridge. We have backpacked, dayhiked, car camped and traveled through Bears Ears Country. We respect the Native American legacy of the Monument which is a sacred, holy land. The archaeology sites are breath taking. We've roamed the BLM lands with our little dog Joe and all of us felt so carefree. My wife wandered through Bears Ears Country 50 years ago when she was a little girl and she counts on the land being preserved so our granddaughter and our granddaughter's granddaughter can experience the area. It is the quintessential American experience. No TV screen or cell phone image can take the place of seeing, smelling and feeling the rocks, the air, of Bears Ears. It would be criminal to decommission Bears Ears simply for the convenience of a relative handful of profit motivated developers. "This Land is My Land, This Land is Your Land." Please keep Bears Ears federally protected land! The state of Utah has a long history of neglecting and abusing their lands. The Salt Lake Valley is a good example of the consequences of their unchecked greed. We live in a dome of intense pollution. We need the Federal Government to help protect the state and preserve this land for future generations, instead of the state government that would use it for a quick profit and leave it destroyed.Please do what we want so much! Please keep our national monuments safe from commercial development.These are important tribal lands that have been continually taken away from Native American groups. For more than a hundred years, Presidents of both parties have used the Antiquities Act--a tool signed into law by Theodore Roosevelt--to enact far-sighted protections for our common American inheritance. To roll back these protections would be an unprecedented attack.National Monuments are designated after years of public engagement and stakeholder outreach. The idea that a fifteen-day comment period would be a meaningful supplement--or means to supplant--the years of engagement that have led to the designation of National Monuments like Bears Ears does not make sense.I support the designation of Bears Ears National Monument and the others currently under review.
