Quoting Theodore Rossevelt: "I believe that the natural resources must be used for the benefit of all our people, and not monopolized for the benefit of the few, and here again is another case in which I am accused of taking a revolutionary attitude. People forget now that one hundred years ago there were public men of good character who advocated the nation selling its public lands in great quantities, so that the nation could get the most money out of it, and giving it to the men who could cultivate it for their own uses. We took the proper democratic ground that the land should be granted in small sections to the men who were actually to till it and live on it. Now, with the water power, with the forests, with the mines, we are brought face to face with the fact that there are many people who will go with us in conserving the resources only if they are to be allowed to exploit them for their benefit. That is one of the fundamental reasons why the special interests should be driven out of politics. Of all the questions which can come before this nation, short of the actual preservation of its existence in a great war, there is none which compares in importance with the great central task of leaving this land even a better land for our descendants than it is for us, and training them into a better race to inhabit the land and pass it on. Conservation is a great moral issue, for it involves the patriotic duty of insuring the safety and continuance of the nation. Let me add that the health and vitality of our people are at least as well worth conserving as their forests, waters, lands, and minerals, and in this great work the national government must bear a most important part."The unique and innovative history of the Antiquities Act has time and time again provided the American people with cultural, spiritual, and economic rewards that far outweigh gains from short-term extractive uses. These Monuments enjoy broad public support both locally and nationally, and even the ones that didn't initially now favor Monument status by an overwhelming margin.The vast majority of legal scholars seem to agree that Presidents cannot rescind or undo designations by previous Presidents without an act of Congress.Please do not follow any short-sighted plan that would impact these monuments.
Rescind the Bears Ears Monument and start over with a better plan for the people and the land. It should be useable for all uses.Johnny Parsons
Save bears ears. This land belongs to the people of today and the children of tomorrow. It is a legacy that all American's deserve.

Sec. Zinke,Please rescind the Bears Ears Monument. We support common sense protections to ensure ongoing enjoyment and utilization of these magnificent lands, and the wildlife herds and hunting on these 1. 3 million acres. Certainly, this is an area that has been wonderfully managed for wildlife, hunting, and other uses by the state of Utah. Those impacted the most by a national monument designation are a critical concern. State driven processes with all stakeholders collaborating are the right way to make land use determinations, not top down monument designations of massive landscapes with little local or state support.We also recognize that national parks in the state of Utah were areas first designated as monuments. What this means, is that the Bears Ears Monument designation puts this area on the pathway to permanent hunting closures. While pithy slogans and protectionist rhetoric sound well intentioned, make no mistake, most of those who are pining for "protection" through a national monument designation do not support our right to hunt and fish in these areas. They want these areas closed to hunting. A national monument designation takes them one step closer to their dangerous objective. Losing these world class-hunting areas would be sad outcome. It would erode the rights of sportsmen, decades of herd restoration, and the millions invested by Utah Sportsmen. As we have seen repeatedly, when hunting is banned, herds suffer and even disappear. It is not good for hunters and it is not good for wildlife. There is a better way to manage and ensure abundance of these herds and habitats for future generations.The voice of sportsmen was ignored as part of the monument designation process. This is particularly disappointed considering that for decades, Utah sportsmen have been the stewards of a massive effort to restore wildlife to these areas. We have restored natural mosaics to control wildfire, enhanced habitat for wild game and grazing, developed water resources, and reintroduced elk, mule deer, wild turkeys, and bighorn sheep. Even after all of these efforts, local sportsmen along with local and state wildlife managers were not consulted about the impacts of this Monument Designation. Unfortunately, one of the primary impacts would be on the very programs and management investment that are needed the most to protect the herds of elk, mule, big horn sheep, wild turkeys, and other wildlife we have worked so hard to restore.The results of these proactive and expensive conservation efforts have been amazing. The San Juan Elk unit is one of the top Elk Herds in the World with many 400-inch bulls and even world record elk harvested. The deer herds in this area are thriving. Two of Utah's premier Desert Bighorn Sheep hunting units also lie within the monument designation boundary. Proof of the success of these efforts is the over 50,000 applicants for hunting permits to these units every year. Not only does this show the popularity of these units, but also demonstrate how important sportsmen funding is to continue on-the-ground management and conservation in these areas.These herds only exist because of sportsmen funding, thousands of volunteer hours, predator control, and millions of dollars in on the ground habitat enhancement and water development efforts. Our experience with Grand Staircase has been disappointing. Habitat enhancement projects through pinyon/juniper management is significantly more difficult and a lot more expensive, if they are even allowed. Predator control has become very restricted and limited. As a result, the Escalante Desert Bighorn herd, once one of the top Desert Bighorn herds in the world, has dramatically declined. The area has become more susceptible to catastrophic wildfire. In essence, the preservationist mentality has been a failure for wildlife and the habitat work most needed to ensure abundant herds of wildlife.As a sportsman and Big Game Forever supporter, I strongly encourage you to rescind Bears Ears monument. It is the best way to ensure the continuation of the efforts, collaboration, and programs that are doing the most to protect, restore, and enhance the hunting, access, in this corner of the state of Utah. Our efforts have worked to make this area truly one of a kind for hunters, wildlife lovers, and all who appreciate the wild things and wild places that Utah hunters have worked so hard to restore.Please rescind the Bears Ears monument designation. We love hunting on these incredible public lands, and want them protected. However, monuments are very restrictive on land and wildlife management. Whatever the future plans are for these areas, Utah Hunters have earned a seat at the table. We encourage you to pursue solutions that will protect state management of wildlife, hunting, and the collaborative, common-sense management investment of Utah's hunters, families and hard working rural communities that has worked for generations.Sincerely,

Secretary of the Interior ZinkeDepartment of the InteriorWashington, DCMay 13, 2017RE:Canyons of the Ancients National MonumentSecretary Zinke,I am writing concerning President Donald Trump's Executive Order #13792 of April 26, 2017 which presents the possibility that National Monuments and Parks could be reduced in size and/or put into the hands of individual states to manage. A part of the order requires public input to the Department of the Interior on the issue. This is my input on Canyons of the Ancients National Monument.National Monuments are a jewel in the crown of our pubic lands. Over the years I have visited, hiked, and camped in most of the ones being considered for public commentary. I have found them to be beautiful and inspiring places, both for their natural history and often for their human history. The importance of many of them to the rights and history of indigenous peoples is undeniable. In the case of this Monument, the desires of Indigenous Peoples in the area should not be ignored. Too many treaties have been broken so far. Many archeological resources have been lost in this area have been lost, due to the building of a dam on the Dolores River. No further loss should be allowed. In my opinion, as a Biologist, I believe the total acreage incorporated into this Monument is necessary to accomplish protection and inclusion of all necessary aspects pertaining to resources for which the Monument was established. National Monuments remain places where the visitor can enjoy the setting without the intrusion of commercial interests. These Monuments belong to all the people of the United States and I am pleased to have my Federal Taxes help to pay for them. For this reason I believe they should be kept under protection by the Federal Government and not left to the caprice and potential special interests presented by State Governments.Please enter this letter into your public commentary.Best Regards,Ann Kircher578 Moultrie StreetSan Francisco, California 94110415 305 2251annkircher@gmail.com

Secretary Ryan Zinke,As a citizen, a voter, and an outdoorsman, I value Bears Ears National Monument and the other public lands which are set aside for the use of all US citizens. These lands should remain protected. Opening these areas to private enterprise would be a theft from the American people.

Secretary Ryan Zinke,Bears Ears National Monument should have been protected 50 years ago and deserves to be protected for all future generations. Please don't rescind or change its designation.The marine sanctuaries are the sole reservoirs for replenishing the over fished and vanishing oceanic bounty we depend upon!Our National Monuments are ours. They are lands of exceptional beauty, biodiversity, cultural significance. They allow access to all Americans into rare jewels of our public lands. If anything, we should increase both the number and size of our National Monuments.We are so lucky to inhabit this beautiful earth! and what a gift it is to all Americans. Please preserve this gift for future generations.I can't even believe this is happening. This is a travesty of freedom! Hands off the National Monuments we already have!

Secretary Ryan Zinke,The rocks that make up Bears Ears contain stories that have not yet had the chance to be completely read. Keeping these lands protected save these stories from being lost forever. Please keep Bears Ears National Monument safe.

Secretary Ryan Zinke: It is critically important the lands in our national monuments remain protected in government possession as they are. Each and everyone is unique in itself and once it is disturbed or destroyed it will be gone for all time. As our populations increase, the human need for these undeveloped areas increases. Future populations deserve the chance to see and experience them as we can today. PLEASE protect them.

Secretary ZinkePlease support the continued protection of Bears Ears as a National Monument. The Monument Declaration by President Obama closely followed the area considered in Representative Bishop's PLI and did not contain the kind of heavy handed restrictions portrayed by some of the local politicians. What it did do was create a Monument Advisory Committee of fair and balanced stakeholders to provide advice on a management plan for the Monument, and specifically designated a Bears Ears Commission consisting of representatives of the five Indian Tribes that proposed the Monument to provide guidance and recommendations on the development and implementation of management plans and on management of the monument. Is is altogether fitting that these Tribes that have a real concern for the land and the history of their ancestors participate in the lands protection.It has been indicated that you have respect for the views and sovereignty of these native peoples and I hope that you will support the creation of the Bears Ears Commission and give considerable weight to its' views on protection of the Monument.Thank you for you consideration of this request.

Secretary Zinke - My wife and I are ardent supporters and users of the public lands, including Bears Ears & Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments. We not only want these monuments to remain intact & in public ownership, but also expect their current boundaries to be honored & maintained. These public lands are owned by ALL U.S. citizens, not just white Utahns who live in or near Blanding and Monticello, UT, nor are they the exclusive property of our vision-less Utah State & county (San Juan & Kane) politicians.It is not true that the Antiquities Act was inappropriately used to establish Bears Ears National Monument, or that it was a "Midnight" designation. The public lands comprising the monument are rife with archaeologic and scientific values, & were acknowledged in the failed Public Lands Initiative (PLI). President Obama was petitioned by his Native American constituents (a group of U.S. citizens that felt ignored during the PLI process) to use the Antiquities Act to designate the area as a national monument. Former Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell visited the area and held four days of public meetings to understand what was a stake. The President delayed monument designation for Bears Ears while his Interior Department worked with Congress to craft a mutually acceptable PLI. Unfortunately the PLI contained numerous "poison pills" that made it difficult to advance the bill through Congress before the end of President Obama's term; the following proposed actions are some examples: 1) forbidding designation of any future National Monuments under the Antiquities Act by a sitting president in 7 Utah counties identified in the PLI; 2) circumventing the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals decision regarding disposition of RS 2477 roads by unilaterally granting title of these roads to the state without having to meet criteria dictated by the court; 3) hamstringing federal land-managing agencies ability to manage the public lands by requiring approval of their land-use management plans by county advisory groups prior to implementation; 4) transferring federal responsibility for oil & gas leasing & regulation to the State of Utah.Consequently, the monument was designated as a geological, archaeological, & cultural legacy for all U.S. citizens, & specifically provided the Native Americans with a co-management role. Please don't undo this long-overdue, decent olive branch that has been extended to our Native American citizens. We believe that national monument designations benefit all. Even our State and local politicians grudgingly acknowledge benefits the State of Utah has received from its "Mighty Five" national parks, most of which began as national monuments. Furthermore, business communities of Boulder & Escalante, UT have expressed what a boon Grand Staircase Escalante National Monument has been to their respective livelihoods.In summary, my wife & I want public lands including Bears Ears National Monument to remain intact & in public ownership for the benefit of our daughters & grandchildren living in Washington State, & our cousins living in Michigan, Chicago, & Florida. They along with all U.S. citizens (especially Native Americans) are co-owners of all public lands, including Bears Ears & Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments.Finally, Secretary Zinke, which legacy would you rather have - one which promotes short-term gain for a few realty & energy promoters, or one that saves a special place for our children & grandchildren & lasts for the ages?

Secretary Zinke,I am concerned about the review of federal lands for potential use by companies and ranchers for purposes of profit.The national park lands have been set aside for the American people. How amazing it is to go and see people from all over our country, seeing perhaps for the very first time these wonders in America. How delightful to see school children learn about our country, the parks animal inhabitants, how they survive, the survival of the fittest. Those lessons can be taught in the classroom, but to see these miraculous animals first hand, up close, can never be done by textbook.I love the freedom from the city, when I go to our national parks and federal lands. Bringing oneself back to nature is nourishing for the body and soul. It allows people to get out and move, to explore, to learn what they never knew they could do. A hike, a canoe trip, rafting. These are things that will live in ones memories forever. Two of my most favorite trips were in Alaska. Skiing in Denali National Park, and kayaking in Prince William Sound. Another top favorite is Utah. What vast wonders are there for people to experience.As I write this, my husband and I are speaking of visiting all the national parks in our country. A bounty of beauty for the people of the USA. These parks and lands belong to the people, are for the people, and are a sacred heritage for all.Thank you. I hope your love for our land shines through for all Americans by keeping our parks and lands free from greed and available to all Americans for their exploration of our great country.Sincerely,Amy PayneSeattle, WA

Secretary Zinke,I am writing to urge you not to remove National Monument designation for Bears Ears National Monument, or for any portion of it.Bears Ears National Monument constitutes an unprecedented agreement between the federal government and five native nations, and protects multiple sites and artifacts of unparalleled cultural significance, including giant petroglyphs, abandoned dwellings, human remains, and ancestral range. It also provides incredible recreational opportunities for outdoor enthusiasts. Despite its large size, the Monument only barely encompasses its most significant sites. The Monument will be irreparably harmed if any portion of it is de-designated.Given the careful and lengthy process that it took for five native nations and the U.S. to reach an agreement on Bears Ears, the notion that there was insufficient opportunity for stakeholder input on protecting this land is ludicrous.In addition, I find Executive Order 13792 cynical and dangerous. The United States has historically been a major tourist attraction on account of our incredible protected natural landmarks. By rolling back protections on designated Monuments, we would be essentially rendering their federal protection meaningless--reversible by the whim of a given presidency. And thus we would begin to lose our special open spaces, our national identity--and our tourism industry.I urge you in the strongest terms to keep Monument designation for Bears Ears National Monument, and for all currently designated National Monuments.Sincerely,Ore CarmiBerkeley, CA

Secretary Zinke,I urge you NOT to change or modify the National Monuments Established since 1996. The creation of these sites was done with the support of a great many of the American people, throughout the United States of America. Some of these Monuments not only have special resources to be protected for our country's current and future generations, they also have cultural and spiritual significance for our citizens.These are national treasures, and I would urge you to protect them, even with the rise in pressure from commercial ventures or those with private interests, to open them for development.

Secretary Zinke,In reference to Executive Order 13792 of April 26, 2017 (82 FR 20429, May 1, 2017), I heavily encourage you and the Department of the Interior to PROTECT all monuments established via the Antiquities Act since 1996.Please count my support of the following national monuments:Grand Canyon-ParashantIronwood ForestSonoran Desert and Vermillion CliffsBerryessa Snow MountainCarrizo PlainGiant SequoiaMojave TrailsSand to Snow and San Gabriel MountainsCanyons of the AncientsCraters of the MoonKatahadin Woods and WatersUpper Missouri River BreaksBasin and Range and Gold ButteOrgan Mountains - Desert PeaksRio Grande del NorteCascade SiskiyouBears EarsGrand Staircase-EscalanteHanford ReachMarianas TrenchNortheast Canyons and SeamountsPacific Remote IslandsPapahanaumokuakeaRose AtollI especially want to support Grand Staircase-Escalante and Bears Ears, as I have lived in San Juan County, UT (I was the 2001 Monticello UT Citizen of the Year) and believe that area needs greater protection.The 157 current parks and monuments established by 16 different Presidents with the Antiquities Act belong to ALL Americans. This includes places like Grand Canyon National Park, Olympic National Park, Zion National Park and Dry Tortugas National Park. Without the foresight of patriotic Americans wanting to protect these places and bringing the unique cultural, natural and historical heritage to the attention of these presidents, these parks and monuments would not exist. These lands are our lands, this history is our history, the cultures are our culture. The monuments under review have the potential to be as important to as our great National Parks. The Antiquities Act is still relevant and we need to abide by it to preserve our great land.Please respect the importance of the protecting these lands and the Antiquities Act. Many American citizens and then the former Presidents worked to protect these lands as monuments for future generations. The vast majority of legal scholars agree that Presidents cannot rescind or undo designations by previous Presidents without an act of Congress. I think it's your job as Secretary of the Interior to protect America's public lands from the constant pressure of natural resource extraction. America has plenty of other places to mine, drill, log, etc, and we need to protect some sacred places, like the monuments established before and after 1996. The Antiquities Act is unique and innovative and has provided the American people time and time again with cultural, spiritual, and economic rewards that far outweigh gains from short-term extractive uses. Monuments, parks, and public lands contribute mightily to local and national economies, if the local economies let them. The outdoor recreation industry is a $646 billion industry, and in my little area of Colorado alone, public lands help support hundreds of jobs as well as hundreds of thousands of dollars in tourism and business.I would like to remind you of these lines from Teddy Roosevelts's 'New Nationalism' speech, delivered in 1910 but still relevant today:Moreover, I believe that the natural resources must be used for the benefit of all our people, and not monopolized for the benefit of the few, and here again is another case in which I am accused of taking a revolutionary attitude. People forget now that one hundred years ago there were public men of good character who advocated the nation selling its public lands in great quantities, so that the nation could get the most money out of it, and giving it to the men who could cultivate it for their own uses. We took the proper democratic ground that the land should be granted in small sections to the men who were actually to till it and live on it. Now, with the water power, with the forests, with the mines, we are brought face to face with the fact that there are many people who will go with us in conserving the resources only if they are to be allowed to exploit them for their benefit. That is one of the fundamental reasons why the special interests should be driven out of politics. Of all the questions which can come before this nation, short of the actual preservation of its existence in a great war, there is none which compares in importance with the great central task of leaving this land even a better land for our descendants than it is for us, and training them into a better race to inhabit the land and pass it on. Conservation is a great moral issue, for it involves the patriotic duty of insuring the safety and continuance of the nation. Let me add that the health and vitality of our people are at least as well worth conserving as their forests, waters, lands, and minerals, and in this great work the national government must bear a most important part.Thank you for your consideration. Please work to protect our national monuments, especially those under review, for us and for future generations.

Secretary Zinke,Please recommend strongly to President Trump that he respect the 100-year Presidential tradition of respecting the National Monument designations of previous Presidents. No place is more important to protect than Bears Ears National Monument -- a landmark collaboration with numerous Native American Tribes (with only one minor sub-tribe dissenting).I have visited many of the existing monuments across the West, both before and after designation. I assure you they are much better managed after!These treasured landscapes belong to all Americans, especially Native Americans. Giving in to local politicians makes no sense, not in Utah, not in Oregon where I live, not in Montana,....Thank you for your consideration.John SchubertRetired 30- year Trails Specialist & Wilderness Ranger

Secretary Zinke, Please do NOT rescind the designation of Bears Ears as a National Monument. I live in Utah and have a deep appreciation for our public lands. I have enjoyed visiting Southern Utah with my family and teaching my children about the richness and diversity of these lands. I believe they need to be protected and preserved for everyone to visit, to enjoy, to learn about and learn from in the years to come.Again, I ask you not to recommend that the designation of Bears Ears as a National Monument be rescinded or reduced.Thank you,

Secretary Zinke, since moving to Washington state 16 years ago I have gained a greater appreciation of our wild spaces, our national parks and our monuments. My family are avid campers and look forward to many adventures in these wonderful places that belong to all Americans. Please do not make any changes to the status of our national monuments so that future generations have the same opportunities to enjoy them that we have had. Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Secretary Zinke, This comment is in support of all 27 of the monuments under review. I strongly urge you to retain the protected status of each of these unique and irreplaceable places. Each constitutes a part of the heritage of all Americans, and must be held in perpetuity for the benefit of future generations. To strip any of them of the National Monument designation would be a travesty and an outrage against the environment.
See attached

some of my most memorable vacations as a child and as an adult have been to our National Monuments.Americans are creative and can meet energy needs without destroying the purity of our wild space. The assumption that our national monuments aren't profitable is "fake news." Outdoor recreation supports 7.6 million jobs and generates $887 billion in consumer spending annually. Don't spoil our wild spaces with energy development. I remember the first time I went to southern California in 1970 and saw the oil rigs off the beautiful beaches. I thought "what a shame they ruined this beautiful view." Don't do this to our national monuments.

Spending time outside among these beautiful monuments is enriching to the lives of everyone who takes part. In a time when nature and our health are threatened by the greed of corporations we need the government to stand up for our right to enjoy these areas for years to come. By not being short-sighted, our government has the opportunity to protect these monuments for years to come and protect them from assault. Please do what is best for the people of this country and for these monuments and continue to protect them.
Stop taking private or state land for any purpose.
THANKS

Thanks for allowing public comment on national monument designations. Having traveled substantially in the bears ears and in greater south east utah for the better part of the last 25 years I'd like to see it protected from private or corporate ownership. Keep bears ears wild and remote. It should be kept as close to possible as it is now. Current roads and 4x4 trails need to be kept open to multi use. Canyons have much of the ruins a petroglyphs and need to be protected but not by national park designation. National parks have to many restrictions (needed because they attract many people) in the bears ears and other national monuments hunting and firewood gathering should still be allowed, mtn biking should be allowed. 4x4 and overland traveling by jeep should still be allowed to canyon trail heads so that remote hikes can take place. I think federal designatinon should still occur but not as a restrictive national park. I believe grand gulch and other canyons should be preserved but the greater bears ears is too large and encompasses areas where there is no antiquities. Futhermore the BLM and forest service have done a good job in preserving this area up to the present point. The County of San Juan should be commended for their balance of protecting and keeping roads open and inventoried throughout the area. SE utah has a lot of beauty that i'd like my kids to be able to see in it's natural beauty and be able to recreate the way many of us in the past have been able to do.

The American people do not want our National Monuments developed, torn asunder nor downgraded. Historic areas like Bears Ears should be around for all of US to admire and learn from. For instance, Bears Ears boasts ancient cliff dwellings, rare wildlife, stunning canyon lands and the highest concentration of ancient cultural sites in the country. None of these things can be replaced and they should remain pristine and untouched, not be handed over to those who would destroy them.

The Antiquities Act of 1906 authorizes the president to protect "objects of historic or scientific interest" on federal lands as "national monuments" has created a conservation legacy like no other nation. It has become woven into the fabric of American exceptionalism.Now, America is face with the possible destruction of this exceptionalism because of a misguided review that is prompted by the never ending greed of the extractive businesses of gas, oil, and mining. While I understand the need for these explorations and I am a user of the products from them, there are some areas of our nation that should be FOREVER PROTECTED from this exploration. We, as a nation, must understand that we cannot forever being destroying our natural world.These are special places that are part of the American psyche. Even if we haven't seen them all, knowing that they are there and are saved from destruction, it makes us proud that our presidents have the foresight to saved beautiful and sacred places. All of the National Monuments have physical features that are unusual and or beautiful. Additionally, there are cultural areas of our Native Americans that should be saved. All of these listed National Monuments make America exceptional.ArizonaGrand Canyon-ParashantIronwood ForestSonoran DesertVermillion CliffsCaliforniaBerryessa Snow MountainCarrizo PlainGiant SequoiaMojave TrailsSand to SnowSan Gabriel MountainsColoradoCanyons of the AncientsIdahoCraters of the MoonMaineKatahadin Woods and WatersMontanaUpper Missouri River BreaksNevadaBasin and RangeGold ButteNew MexicoOrgan Mountains - Desert PeaksRio Grande del NorteOregonCascade SiskiyouUtahBears EarsGrand Staircase-EscalanteWashingtonHanford ReachMarine National MonumentsMarianas TrenchNortheast Canyons and SeamountsPacific Remote IslandsPapahanaumokuakeaRose AtollPLEASE don't destroy these places for the sake of greed. America and its people will be the worse for it!Sincerely,Chris MooreDenver, Colorado

The Antiquities Act of 1906 was signed into law by Theodore Roosevelt and has been used by 16 presidents over the last 110 yearseight Democrats and eight Republicansto protect some of the nation's best public lands. In recent years, sportsmen and women have advocated for the responsible use of the Antiquities Act to protect some of America's finest hunting and fishing areas, including Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks in New Mexico, Katahdin Woods and Waters in Maine, and Berryessa Snow Mountain in California. An Executive Order signed by President Trump is requiring a review of 27 different national monuments covering 11.3 million acres. Executive branch actions to reverse, shrink, or otherwise undermine a single monument could jeopardize all monuments. Your action is also needed today to protect this legacy.Thank you for your time.

The Bear's Ears National Monument site protection by the federal government should not be rescinded or changed. Although in the past, local conservation practices may have been sufficient, recent events make it clear that the very fragile environment and antiquities need more protection. It is untrue that exploration for natural resources including oil, gas, and minerals is currently necessary. It is absurd to argue that ranchers have an inalienable right to graze animals. Just because money can be made from doing something doesn't mean it should be. Just because people want to do something that their ancestors did on federal lands, doesn't mean that we should continue to allow it. Indeed, following that argument, these are the ancestral lands of local Native Americans.I am a Westerner, living in Idaho. I understand current arguments about public land use.Bear's Ears currently belongs to all of us, not just the locals, not just the ranchers, not just the natural resource extractors. ALL OF US.
The Bears Ears monument is an incredible resource - culturally and scientifically - and should be protected.

The Bears Ears National Monument gives stronger protection to an area of immense historical, cultural and natural significance. Please keep the designation and fund the BLM to manage it into the future. I have spent a lot of time in this area as I live close by and the use has increased over the last 20 years as people have discovered its beauty. The highest level of protection will preserve this area for future generations. National Monument status brings economic benefit via tourism and can be very positive for neighboring communities.

The current Bears Ears boundary is the same boundary proposed by the Utah delegation in their failed attempt to pass protection for the area. They knew the importance of the area then.Now, they see the potential to exploit the area because of the new political atmosphere created in 2016. This monument needs to endure and the boundaries proposed by the Utah delegation and the Obama designation need to stand. History is watching and will not be kind if this Bears Ears designation is reversed

The Department of the Interior should not de-list 27 National Monuments and open up these areas for land sales to private companies for oil and gas exploration, logging, mining or other uses. These are protected areas that provide important habitat and space for wildlife and these areas also provide special outdoor recreation for people. If these areas are de-listed and sections of land are sold off, these areas will never be the same--they will be forever damaged and we won't be able to get them back. As a life-long resident of Western Colorado the issue of protecting our public lands is very important to me as well as to so many others in communities across the West.

The first national monument was dedicated to the people of the United States in 1906 in order to preserve and protect the unique and historic features of this country. Since then, national monuments have retained protection from encroachment and destruction from special interest groups who do not see the beauty and value of these lands and features. The fact that an element of the government is considering removal of these protections is a sure sign of special interests seeking to pounce on the greater good; on what has been gifted to the people. To remove these protections means destruction of what our forefathers have fought to protect for all generations to come. National Parks and natural wilderness areas are those areas in our country which provide a respite from the noise and concrete of cities and the stresses of life. From Louis Marshall "Let us preserve some of the simple things. Let us know that there is somewhere in our State a region which is not commercialized and citified, and to which those may repair who yearn for a restoration of their shattered nerves amid the vat silences of the eternal mountains and the primeval forests."
the govt. doesnt have the right to block off public land ! The only land that the Federal govt owns is the ten ( 10) sauare miles that is called Washington D.C.

The Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument was a private donation in the Maine woods to the federal government to ensure the natural land would be protected for all citizens. It has raised awareness and provided recreational use and business to the area. It would be unfortunate to return the land to the private owner who could choose to prohibit recreational use on the land based on a decision of those that do not value the land's worth.

The Monument should be reduced in size to the smallest acreage necessary to protect the true "objects" of the Monument.The Proclamation should be amended to recognize outdoor recreation, including motorized trail riding and historic permitted OHV events, as allowed uses or purposes of the Monument.Specific, established recreation corridors should be specifically identified for continuing use, including motorized recreation. If you know specific routes or have personal experiences to relate you should do so.Direction should be provided instructing that for any routes closed to motorized travel, the Secretary will determine whether an interim restriction with subsequent restoration of access is appropriate, and if not, the proper relocation or establishment of comparable additional motorized access that can be implemented to offset the closure

The parks and monuments under review should be made or remain in their present status.They belong to the American People. People! Not corporations.They are for enjoyment and recreation. Not oil and gas exploration.They are for our children and grandchildren.Don't think about making dollars now and save them for the future.They should be open to the public forever for enjoyment and recreation. Not for oil and gas exploration.Thank you

The proposed review is a complete waste of taxpayer money. The Monuments that we have created represent the best that our land has to offer and it should remain untouched and unexploited. We need to preserve these lands for space that people can escape to, that people can find peace in. We have already destroyed enough of the lands in our great country

The recent act of Donald Trump's administration to put the status of national monuments up for review is extremely misguided. These monuments were created to ensure that they remain safe from environmental exploitation and can always be accessed by the public. As an Arizonian, I am particularly concerned about monuments like Grand Canyon-Parashant, Ironwood Forest, Sonoran Desert, Vermillion Cliffs National Monuments, and Bears Ears. Monument status ensures that these places remain environmentally protected, which in turn drives tourism to these areas. These monuments are often serious economic drivers for communities near them. To remove monument status now for perceived short-term gains, will have a tremendously negative long-term affect on the local environments and communities.National Monuments were created with the intention that they remain monuments forever. It is our responsibility to not let our children down, and to ensure that they do.Sincerely,Leon Leid

The review of these lands should not revoke the status of any of them. Our national parks and monuments are national treasures and our most precious resources -- and not for their mineral content but for their beauty, ecology, and wildlife. There's no reason to revoke status as we have already drastically increased our domestic energy production. We need to preserve these lands in the Republican tradition of Teddy Roosevelt.

The United States is privileged to have an enormous landmass for the size of its population. The United Kingdom, as an example worthy of comparison, has a population of 60+ Million, one fifth of the size of the US, in a land mass the size of Illinois. Given the enormity of the land resources available there is no pressing reason for us to exploit every last inch for commercial gain. We can be enormously successful while still be thoughtful and limited in our use of our natural resources. We should treasure what we have and preserve it. It is so important to understand that these decisions are rarely reversible--once a natural resources has been exploited it can rarely be returned to its pristine states or returned to public use. Please, respect the value of what we have and preserve it for future generations rather than exploiting for short term and unnecessary commercial gains.

The value of these areas to all of the general population has already been assessed when they were assigned to the monument's listing. Any review which deems these lands available for private use would seem contrary to the purpose which these protected lands were intended!

The vast majority of people in this country, including those in Utah, want the Bears Ears National Monument. Do you understand that, or are you so blinded by greed that you would sell your soul like the BUFFOON in the White House?

The world is already full of man-made structures. Part of our duty as humans is to help preserve nature and its wonders. If we can't keep a designated amount of space human structure-free, then we're just being greedy motherfuckers for the hell of it. Leave these spaces free! Keep them under protection!

These areas must remain protected for the good of the environment and the benefit of future generations. Short-sighted economic development opportunities are not worth jeopardizing the environment or the vast natural beauty with which we as citizens of the US have been blessed.
These beautiful and sacred places in nature should be saved in their natural state for future generations to share and experience.
These lands are some of the most beautiful in the nation. To allow them to go unprotected would be a lasting tragedy.
These monuments are national treasures and should be protected such that all future generations of Americans can enjoy them. Please make them available for my children.
These resources should be preserved and protected for all future generations. To do otherwise is irresponsible and insane.
This is an affront to the values of America. We must protect our natural resources for all future generations, and for the sake of our planet.
This is embarrassing that our politicians are this corrupt that we have to have open comments and a debate on whoring out our future.

This is my plea to leave all current National Monuments as they are, and not remove any protections surrounding them. They are national treasures, which, I understand, bring money into the economy of the local areas, and jobs, along with being wonderful places to enjoy the outdoors. As the pace of life gets more hectic and technology-based, we need more natural places to get away to refresh our lives, not less. Please keep all National Monument designations as they are. Thank you.

This land belongs to the American people, all of us, and should continue to do so. This area is not only important to me as someone who uses it for recreational purposes, but it is also important to the Ute and Navajo tribes that I work with. This land is sacred to them.The opposing viewpoint supports the concept that the land should no longer be available to the American public for recreational use and enjoyment. The privatization of this land will deprive more than 320 million Americans the access to these beautiful and culturally rich lands.

To be a truly civilized society requires a balance with nature, otherwise we are in jeopardy of increasing slums; which would ensure or status as a third world nation. Our parks and monuments are places citizens enjoy regardless of their political affiliation or lack thereof. Please I encourage you to preserve our natural history.

To Secretary Zinke,In response to the proposed rescindment of the Bears Ears monument I wish to express my support for this action. As a resident born and raised in Blanding, Utah I have a vested interest in this conversation. Blanding and the surrounding area is a small, but passionate community; you have the ability to not only declare this land a monument or rescind that declaration, you hold power over the way of life in that place. The people who live on or near monuments understand the effect that they have on the community much better than those who live in distant Salt Lake or Washington DC. We understand that promises to allow our way of life to continue will, sooner or later, be broken.Before this monument became a topic of public discourse, the average Utah'n would have no idea where the Bears Ears, Blanding, or San Juan County were(if they even knew they existed). They have nothing to lose or gain from your actions regarding the monument. If the designation stands they can come down and bike, hike, and camp and appreciate the beauty that is there. If the designation is rescinded they can still do the same. The local residents are the ones adversely impacted. I implore you to listen to those who are actually being affected.Please note that the land is in pristine condition. Why is that? It is because it has been kept out of the public eye which has reduced traffic. The locals have been good stewards of the land as well. There is reason to change something that is working so well.Those who have been pushing so hard for the monument have acted dishonorably. They sling propaganda and lies to further their cause, backed by money (and money to be made or lost based on the designation) and deceit. They stand to gain from the designation of the monument and care nothing about the adverse impact to the residents who occupy the land.One last point; I have visited the many national monuments in Utah and in other places. They are beautiful. The glut of tourism cheapens the experience, however. How can one commune with nature while there is trash, noise, and pictures being taken everywhere? Buses, traffic, and government employees create barriers to enjoying the true beauty of these lands. I don't say this because we want to keep people out, but because we want people who come here to truly respect the land and love it as the locals do. It is one of the few places with that kind of unique circumstance left.

To the Department of the Interior;America is a vast and beautiful country. In the past few years my family has made it a goal to visit as many National Parks, Monuments, Historical and Cultural Sites and doing so has repeatedly shown me and demonstrated for my kids why America is such a great nation with natural areas that need to be preserved and protected. These lands belong to all Americans and attract people worldwide who gain so much from walking through these magical places. All these people spend money along the way, eat at restaurants, hire guides, stay in hotels, get snacks at the local mom-and-pop shops, invigorating renewable economies that will last long after the last oil has been drilled or the last mines emptied of their minerals.These lands belong to the people of the United States. Do not take that away from us or the future generations. Leave a legacy of stewardship, improvement of the environment, reverence for our naturally diverse land.Nicole

To whom it may concern,As Americans, it is our civic duty to consider the long term implications of such action the as redesignation of the National Monuments. The natural and historic beauty of this country make up the foundation of its greatness. I urge you to uphold the best interests of your constituents and the future generations of Americans by protecting our great lands as our most respected and revered leaders like Theodore Roosevelt have done. These majestic monuments draw attention and admiration from American citizens and honored foreign guests alike. They should never be tampered with, rather preserved and expanded whenever possible.

To whom it may concern,Our nation's wilderness areas are some of the richest and most important parts of our heritage. While they can be easily lost and destroyed, once gone they can never be reclaimed. We can not afford to lose something so important to who we are as people and as a nation. As a child I camped in these places, as an adult these are still some of the places where I go to understand who I am and, honestly, just to enjoy my self, and these are the places I want to someday bring my children. We must continue to support and protect these areas, because if we don't then they will be gone forever, and we will be immeasurably poorer for it.Best,Caleb Wexler, U.S. citizen and voter

To Whom It May Concern,I live in Washington. Additionally, I have traveled our beautiful country extensively. I adore our public lands that have been set aside and protected from development. I have witnessed first hand, the positive results of setting aside tracts of land in preservation status, preventing alterations and resource development. Future generations deserve to experience our lands in a preserved, unaltered state the same as I have had the pleasure of doing. Our planet is under constant assault and to preserve even small portions of it creates a lasting legacy we can look back on with pride and gratitude. Land development can never be undone. Please leave the listed land, water and ocean tracts listed, in their current preservation status.Respectfully, Michela Miller Ferree

To Whom it may concern,Please do not change the status of any of the monuments, their designation was made to keep that place preserved for future generations to enjoy. Most of these monuments have significant cultural meaning, on-top of the recreation opportunities that they provide. Recreation is a huge growing industry and needs to be taken into consideration. I sincerely hope you reconsider trying to re designate these monuments.Thank You

To Whom It May Concern:I am a strong supporter of the Antiquities Act and the monuments it allows a President to designate. I believe this review of monuments to be in err of the spirit of the Antiquities Act. I fully support all monuments as they were originally designated and would like to see them remain in their current size, or even expanded as the original monument designations often left many acres of wilderness unprotected. I especially support the recent designations of monuments in Utah, like Bears Ears and the Grand Staircase Escalante monunment from President Bill Clinton. In fact, as a supporter of America's Red Rock Wilderness Act, I would support them being expanded as their current designations left over 600,000 acres unprotected that could've been included in the Bears Ears monument designation. Utah holds some of the world's most renowned lands and should be protected as such - from Delicate Arch in Arches national park, which began as a monument, to the Wave in Vermillion Cliffs National Monument - Utah holds the world's treasures when it comes to outstanding landscapes. It demands these monuments be as large as they are if not greater. Please do not rescind or look to remove lands from protection. The acting Presidents did their duty in using the Antiquities Act and the monuments they designated should be upheld; especially the recent designations of Bears Ears and Grand Staircase Escalante in Utah.

To whom it may concern: Bears Ears, along with all of our other national monuments, are a great treasure to this country. They are beneficial to the local communities, they show our commitment the lands of this great nation, and they are a draw to tourists both local and abroad. Please maintain the status of Bears Ears as a national monument and continue to protect all national monuments and let America recognize the beauty of our great wonders.
We must keep all our designated national monuments. They must not be leased or mined or fracked. Please!
We need to preserve the Maine woods, not open them to exploitation by the few. Climate change is already stressing our woods. Development would destroy them.
We need to protect or national monuments and plublic land. These lands need to stay in federal hands and away from the states.Ross
We need to protect these lands for future generations to come. This should not even be something under review.
We stole their land once, how can we morally do it AGAIN?..Please vote no on undoing the Bear Ears Monument designation.Thanks

What is the goal with the review? I highly doubt "the people" have complained that there are way too many national monuments. If the goal is to appease big business, honestly there is more than enough land to go around that can be destroyed by mining. Leave these monuments alone as there is no turning back once they are left to human hands. To add a human element to all this, I happen to live in the shadow of one of these monuments which is on the table for review, San Gabriel Mountains. I can whole heartily say that thanks to this monument, it has allowed the nearby cities of Arcadia, Sierra Madre, and countless other cities to benefit in the many ways. It has helped mold our communities and culture with immediate access to hiking, camping, and many other outdoor activities. It also adds much to our scenery which I know influences property value and the desire for people to move out here. That being said, I know this is not an isolated experience with countless other cities living in harmony by their national monuments. So I ask of you again, please leave these monuments alone. In a country of plenty, surely there is enough land to go around. Unlike the review of the National Monuments, the XL pipeline has been something that people have been asking for help. For months, people have been camping out in the cold to protest the construction of the XL pipeline going through the only water supply for the local natives. When Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument was designated in 1996 it was declared to be "The Science Monument" because it held within its boundaries a wide variety of soil types,wildlife habitats, archaeological and paleontological resources, remarkable geological formations and critical watershed resources. In the 20+ years of its existence many scientific studies and reports have been produced, the body of knowledge about arid ecosystems has been increased immeasurably and the public has had access to the vast array of canyons, slickrock benches, sagebrush plains and lush riparian areas.At the same time private stock raising has continued almost ubchanged since before the designation. This traditional activity has provided a semblance of a living for a few families in Garfield and Kane counties, albeit heavily subsidized by state and federal funds. While it is true that some visitors are entertained by evidence of "cowboys on the range" the true value of this activity lies in the potential for improving management of livestock on arid lands. Alas, this has not happened to the extent that it might have, given the influence of some powerful local interests, but it still could. This would require maintaining the acreage on the Monument and allocating sufficient funding and personnel to study and adapt grazing management. Any reduction of acreage would stifle scientific inquiry and potentially lead to increased stocking on the un-designated acres, which would only exacerbate the already significant damage done to the landscape over 100 years ago.I am sending, in a separate email, a US Forest Service report from 1944 entitled The Story of Some Sick Land, which details the effects of over 50 years of overgrazing in the Escalante area. The report deals mainly with higher elevation lands, but of course, activities on the uplands significantly impacts conditions downstream in what is now Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument. This report is instructive in that it describes conditions that still exist in the Monument. The only way to keep a "handle' on this activity is to maintain the Monument intact and improve livestock grazing management.

When resources like coal, oil, history, and beauty are used up, they are gone forever. Whatever reasons are offered for downgrading the status of Bears Ears National Monument, it's hard to argue that the resources to be exploited have more value than the resources that will be destroyed.Once Native American historic and religious sites are changed, those changes can never be undone. Once ecosystems are interfered with, their changes are forever.This area of rare beauty and historical significance was set aside to preserve it for future study and enjoyment. This preservation should continue.Please, keep Bears Ears National Monument status.

Why would anyone want to REMOVE national parks and monuments? These areas are part of our national and natural heritage and should be protected and expanded. We need to protect our future, not throw it away to the highest bidder.

With the history of Utah and favors granted to coal and oil extraction industries (e.g., the $54 million public funds pledged to developing Oakland's port for shipping Utah coal oversees--a policy benefitting very few Utahns other than coal companies), I see a strong need to protect the delicate and culturally/recreationally important lands Utah has been blessed with having.The argument that the protected lands need to be available for development by the mineral extraction industry to build the economy is relatively weak. For most of my growing up years, my father worked underground in a coal mine in Central Utah. After nearly 10 years working underground, his hourly wage was around $14 per hour. As the sole wage earner for a large family, this was not a sufficient wage to cover family expenses and we ended up needing supplemental government support to meet living needs. While many of the recreation industry jobs that will increase as a result of monument designation are also relatively low paying, the economic argument for reducing or eliminating monuments to expand extraction opportunities is not warranted (especially with rising costs for mineral extraction in comparison to other sources of energy).Additionally, the designation of Bears Ears as a National Monument is important to the indigenous people in the United States. The joint management arrangement put in place as part of the monument designation shows respect and aknowledgment of the cultural and religious value of the area to the native inhabitants of the area.We had a chance to vacation in the Bears Ears area last fall prior to the monument designation. We were awed by the beauty and the history of the area and my seven year old daughter is asking to go back and explore more. As a Native Utahn, a respector of the native people, and someone who wants to see the land and the legacy of the Bears Ears area preserved for future generations to enjoy, I admonish you to maintain the Bears Ears monument designation to preserve and protect this land.
